  4304. Normally, I would have to shave every other day so this has been a time saver for me.
  4305. but the second time I used it (which was 2 glorious, itch free WEEKS) I could hardly feel it!
  4306. I used it on my legs and arms and it took less then ten minutes, and I'm very
  4307. now I notice not only less hair growth, but it is much thinner..
  4308. It took me a solid half hour on each leg, but I really wanted to be thorough.
  4309. its easy to use, especially over time as your leg hair starts to thin out.
  4310. My hair isn't super thick or coarse or anything; its medium hair.
  4311. If you have deep, coarse, hard rooted guy hair, you are going to tire of the pain and repetition quickly.
  4312. Even after I got used to it, the areas around my ankles and knees were always the most sensitive, but not so bad with this new model.
  4313. having spent so much for this I expect it to last a very long time.
  4314. Especially for the armpits, it just makes all the hair grow at least 3x slower and when it does grow back it isn't an issue waiting for it to get long enough to epilate again since it's so light now.
  4315. Not long ago I went to a local laser hair removal tech to get an estimate on getting my back and shoulders done.
  4316. The only problem is that if your hair is not long enough it won't work.
  4317. Which is fine but a pain in the behind.
  4318. I'm use to Epilators so for me there was absolutely no pain as I've read in reviews for other epilators, but those people may be using them for the first time.
  4319. overall recommendation is that if you are not willing to purchase the top of the line Braun Silk Epil 7 which can be used while charging, then buy this emjoi because all the other one's will last you 6 months if you use it as heavily as I do.
  4320. overall recommendation is that if you are not willing to purchase the top of the line Braun Silk Epil 7 which can be used while charging, then buy this emjoi because all the other one's will last you 6 months if you use it as heavily as I do.
  4321. The gear in the handheld part driving the head is the weak point, Don't expect more than 3-4 years from this machine as the gear starts slipping and eats itself up.
  4322. When I first turned it on I jumped a little!
  4323. first time I used it, the noise was a little intimidating, but no longer!
  4324. Even when it was working I found it broke off more hairs than it pulled, the large head made it difficult to get into tight areas such as my pits and bikinis line.
  4325. Even though the Emagine looks large and heavy, it's not at all.
  4326. You will have to wait for hair to grow long enough and you will have to use this often, consistently and after several weeks of using this for 45 minutes or longer sessions, you will find that the hair is sparser and less course.
  4327. After only a few months and only a few uses it no longer pulls out my hairs easily.
  4328. well, I was gritting my teeth and ready to scream, but as I saw this little contraption spinning around and ripping my leg hairs out, I sucked up the pain and pushed forth.
  4329. It took a little while to get it all done, but my skin is so much smoother.
  4330. In its defense ... I do have very fine hair, but again it is performing worse than other epilator
  4331. But it is true that it hurts less and less with each use.
  4332. I would put this upwards of a 4 on the pain level for as little as I got done; the machine really was too big to get any closer than the outer edges of the bikini area.
  4333. It does a decent job of removing 85% of the hair from the root, but the rest just gets cut down really short
  4334. It leaves little bumps for a few hours but the next day your skin is smooth.
  4335. I've always started at my ankles and worked my way up because it hurts the least there and a little more the further you get up your legs, and when I started at my ankle there was almost no pain.
  4336. Up near the \\"bum\\" on the backs of my thighs (where the \\"seat\\" and thigh meet) was a little sensitive; that's probably a solid 3 for pain.<br /><br
  4337. It is very loud it drowns out every other noise you may have going in the room.
  4338. />Emojoi only came with the cord and a cleaning brush, but considering I never once used the other attachments provided from Braun, Emojoi wins this catagory as well - less is sometimes more.<br /><br
  4339. but to me that would be throwing good money after the bad.

  4. Ok. I have been using this epilator now for over 4 months and can tell you that it is wonderful. I use it under my arms, my entire legs and the girlie areas. Yes, the girly area hurt like a mo-fo the first time, but just like other reviews claimed, the pain is less the second time, significantly less the third time and pretty much non-existent thereafter. My legs remain good for 2 weeks before they need another run with the epilator. And I have noticed that the hair is growing back much slower. I am hoping/expecting that in time, less and less of it will be making an appearance.

The motor makes the right sound, but the tweezers don't spin at all. I checked my warranty. It is good for a year. I checked my purchase date - a year and 2 weeks. I gave this product 3 stars because it did what I needed it to do, but only for one year. I will be purchasing another epilator - I will never go back to shaving - but I think I'll try the Braun Silk Epil Female Epilator Se7921spa. We'll see if this helps with ingrown hairs.   21. I am a male (cyclist) with course body hair, and this was my first time using an epilator, so my review will be base on the manufacture claims, against its performance, and targeting other first time Epilator users.<br /><br />Claim: 72 Tweezer Heads for Fast, Long-Lasting Results<br />Result: I was expected the one pass as promised, that did not happened, in fact I needed a few passes in some areas to achieve the desired results. This would be a mojor issue if a user cannot tolerate the discomfort assosiciated with the process.<br />Claim: Antimicrobial Protection<br />Result: Is getting bacterial injections from using epilators an issue? I had no sign of infection prior, and none now..<br />Claim: User-Friendly Operation<br />Result: It could not get easier, extremely easy to use.... Not so easy to keep engaging however.<br /><br />The term \\"gentle\\" is used quite often in the product description, \\"gentle\\" is relative, based on your ability to cope with discomfort, I read the reviews and as such expected some pain/discomfort, from having my hair pulled from the roots. I believe I would have been better prepared mentally, if I the manufacturer did not use \\"gentle\\" so often. As a first time user, I hoped considering the discomfort associated, the process would be fast, and long lasting. For me it was not fast, it took an episode of \\"Game of Thrones\\" to completed both legs, this included discomfort breaks. It will get the job done, but not quite as claimed. I will post an update on how long the results last.<br /><br />UPDATE: I have reduced my rating from 4 to 3 stars.<br /><br />After using the product, I could not see any hair left, but I could feel the stubble left behind. I believe this was the result of the hair that was broken by the device as opposed to being pulled from the roots. If your desired result is for smooth finish this will be a significant flaw. I wanted to hair removed and it was,, I did however, because of manufacture's claim expect a more smoothend result (again take my hair type into consideration, maybe softer/thinner hair will break less..)<br /><br />My hair growth was noticeable after five days. I had to epilate again after seven days. My \\"Long Lasting Results\\" is one week.<br /><br />My hair was much less course when it regrew (compared to shaving)and epilating this time resulted in significantly less discomfort. There still is the stubble, and there was more irritation.<br /><br />I still like the product, I wanted my hair removed and it was, just not as smoothly, gentle, and long lasting as the manufacturer's claim.

  25. I've been dying to write this review! Ok, first off I've had a nightmare dealing with shaving, especially inbetween my upper thigh area and back thigh. I get ingrown hairs, red bumps...you name it, it was very unsightly. It looks gawd awful when wearing shorts. I can't even begin to describe how it makes me feel. I look down and that's all I can see...and I think that's all anyone else can see when they look at me (even my 8yr old asks me what's wrong with my legs and why they are all red etc). I've tried creams (which just burn like heck and eat my skin), I've tried all sorts of razors. I've tried all sorts of diff shaving creams, plucking, etc. I even looked into laser hair removal...but for $2600 and the uncertainty that the hair could possibly grow back, yeah I wasn't going for it. Then I came across this and I read the reviews so I instantly purchased it. Took 3 days for it to ship and OMG I couldn't wait to open it. I had about 2 days of hair growth on my legs when I first tried it. My first reaction was... well, I was gritting my teeth and ready to scream, but as I saw this little contraption spinning around and ripping my leg hairs out, I sucked up the pain and pushed forth. I'm not kidding when I said it was painful though. I'd rather go through another child birth than that! Afterwards my legs were red and where the hair was pulled out swollen. I was bummed because it looked like how my thighs normally do. But then I read that this can be a normal reaction because your legs/skin aren't used to this type of treatment. So a couple days went by and lo and behold the redness went away and there was minimal hair (I could see where I missed a few spots or where shorter hair was starting to grow to the length where I could epilate it). It is now not painful at all to use on my legs, nor do I get the red bumpy reaction like I initially got. I've tried this on my ummmm nether region/bikini area and again, it was a teeth clencher the first time around but since then the hair takes FOREVER to grow back (standing ovation) and it doesn't hurt as bad either when I do have to go over it. I tried my under arms and that lasted a whole 15 seconds, LOL. So far the most painful area...I've since tried my under arms again and was much more successful. And can I just tell you that I've yet to shave my under arms and it's been a month!! I'll get like 5-10 hairs that I either missed or couldn't get inititally so I just whip out this bad boy and GONE. I'm completely amazed by this product and even though I've had some painful experiences, it's been bareable and the results are by far unbelievable. I also want to add that I prefer the plug-in opposed to the rechargeable only because it does take a bit of time...I think I'd be recharging non-stop just to finish one leg.the hair takes FOREVER to grow back (standing ovation) and it doesn't hurt as bad either when I do have to go over it. I tried my under arms and that lasted a whole 15 seconds, LOL. So far the most painful area...I've since tried my under arms again and was much more successful. And can I just tell you that I've yet to shave my under arms and it's been a month!! I'll get like 5-10 hairs that I either missed or couldn't get inititally so I just whip out this bad boy and GONE. I'm completely amazed by this product and even though I've had some painful experiences, it's been bareable and the results are by far unbelievable. I also want to add that I prefer the plug-in opposed to the rechargeable only because it does take a bit of time...I think I'd be recharging non-stop just to finish one leg.
  26. Once in a while, you come upon a product that is a total game-changer. This epilator is one of them. I have fair skin and dark, coarse hair that grows fast. I was shaving 3-4 times a week to stay completely smooth, especially during the summer months. Even then, I could still see some dark stubble on my inner thighs and under my arms. Since I switched to the epilator, I do a some minor spot-checking once a week. I could probably go two weeks. The hair grows in lighter and finer. Gone is the rash that I would often get from shaving frequently. I am also hoping that after a few years of this, I will do permanent damage to the hair follicles and they will cease to grow new hairs at all. I am really frugal and strapped for time. I could not justify going to a salon or spa and spending a ton of money and time getting waxed, especially when I have fast-growing hair. This is cheap in comparison and it takes me 45 minutes max to do my arms, legs, and underarms.<br /><br />Word of warning: This will hurt the first time you do it. I consider myself to have a decent threshold of pain, and it took some serious teeth-gritting and deep breathing exercises to get through it, especially under the arms. However, it becomes less and less painful with each go, and it doesn't hurt now at all. Just accept that it's a one-time deal IF you keep up with it, and that the results will be TOTALLY WORTH IT.
  27. The product does rip hair out, as it advertises. I used it on my chest. It took me a few days of doing bit by bit, because it is quite painful.<br /><br />It is advertised as being able to rip out 1 mm long hairs. That was not my experience. It has trouble pulling shorter hairs... which is a bit of an issue. As the hair grows back, it creates stubble, which nobody really wants. Unfortunately you are waiting for the hairs to grow out a bit before the Emjoi can grab them. The stubble is not as bad as from razor shaving though, since (I am guessing) the hairs are growing back at different rates.<br /><br />Ingrown hairs are also an issue. It says you get less ingrown hairs using this product. I don't really notice a reduction in ingrown hairs vs. shaving. I think your skin and hair-type are the greatest factors for predicting ingrown hairs.<br /><br />The hair takes longer to grow back than shaving. It does not hurt nearly as much now, as during my initial use. That is likely because it is pulling out less hairs now (as hair grows back in in stages).<br /><br />I am not sure if I will continue to use this device. The stubble, and having to wait for hair to get long enough to pull out, are annoying factors. Overall this devices does what it claims to do - rips out hair.
  28. I really enjoy my Emjoi AP-18 Dual Opposed 72 hair remover. It gets almost all of the hairs and you can use it anywhere on your body. It leaves little bumps for a few hours but the next day your skin is smooth. A lot smoother than the other epilator I had and gets more hairs. I have to use it about once a week because my hair grows fast and I don't wait until all the hair is the same length before tweezing it. Overall I'm really pleased with this model and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who hates razor stubble or the pain of waxing because it doesn't hurt at all, unless you're really sensitive.   29. I've been using this method of hair removal since the original Epilady came out. I figured, with 72 tweezers, this was bound to be more effective and faster than models I've used since. First of all, if you follow the directions and move the machine in the direction of hair growth, nothing happens. So if you go in the opposite direction (as if you were shaving), it clearly breaks off the hairs instead of pulls them by the root. Second, after using Emagine's two rows of tweezers on my thighs I can say they are more irritated than they've ever been with epilation. It is also simply too big to get anywhere near the bikini line. Finally, what I'm left with is a surface of stubble rather than smooth skin. I do NOT recommend this product and wish I had kept the packaging so I could return it.
  30. This is my third epilator in the last 20 years. So far it is the fastest although not quite as fast as I'd hoped.   31. I am unable to shave because I get such terrible razor burn and break outs so I have had to turn to MANY other hair removal methods. For the past year I was getting my legs waxed every 3 weeks, which was getting quite expensive. In the past I had used other epilators but they were painful and took forever to remove all the hairs so I was hesitant to try another one but waxing was just getting too expensive! I did a lot of research before I purchased my Emagine and I am so glad that I ended up choosing this one! Since it has almost twice as many tweezers as other epilators it works a lot faster and hurts a lot less. In fact I dont even feel it anymore now that I have been using it for a few months. I will admit the first time I turned it on it was a lot louder and moved a lot faster than other epilators I have used and/or seen in action so I was a bit scared but once I used it I feel in love! It takes a third of the time it would if I were to wax my legs, it doesnt make a mess, and I can use it on just about any part of my body! When I travel I am able to take it with me, and it only takes a few minutes when I just need a touch up. The epilator paid for itself in less than 2 uses and is a durable, reliable, and portable method of hair removal. I would recommend exfoliating your skin regularly and using a good lotion that doesn't irritate your skin.
  32. I owned the Emjoi Optima first, for 6 years, and loved it. It finally died on me recently, so I purchased this newer model. Overall it works pretty much as promised. It seems a bit faster and and is slightly less painful than the optima. It somehow feels smoother over the skin. Ergonomically much better than the Optima too, so you can get a better grip on it. My only issue with it so far is that for the sensitive underarm area, sometimes I've had to run it over more than twice to get a few remaining stubborn hairs. When i do this, it sometimes scrapes my skin raw, which is extremely painful. It's not often that this happens, but when it does, it really sucks. I've taken to trying to tweeze the remaining stubborn hairs instead of running the epilator over it too many times. Which is fine but a pain in the behind. That said, most of the time and on legs it's totally fine. As an aside, before buying this one, I tried a Braun Silk Epil - the only model I could find in Germany, where I'm living now. That one pulled my skin into the tweezers, basically pinching it and stopping it from working. So utterly painful. I will stick with Emjois from now on!

However, when I had leftover hairs still visible, I went up, from left, from right and as soon as I developed a nice rhythm with it, it took no time at all and my legs were immaculate. Hair free.   36. The Emjoi has a very fast rotation and a large number of tweezers, which pulls the hair out faster, thus reducing the pain and making it more efficient. Even with it pulling it pulled more hairs at a time, the speed made it hurt less than the braun I had been using. Compared to my braun, it takes me 1/5 of the time and has 1/10th of the pain and does a much better job on most areas. I found that the braun broke the hair off, the emjoi pulls hair out at the root which leaves my legs feeling smoother longer. Specific areas and pain...the hard facts Legs: The first time I used this epilator on my legs, I wasn't sure I was using it correctly because it didn't hurt. I could barely feel it pulling out the hairs, even though it was doing so much more efficiently than the braun. underarms: does a fabulous job- just be sure that your skin is 100% dry before you begin or it will really hurt and won't be very effective. fine hair on arms and stomach: Worked great, this one grasped the fine hair much better than the braun and only required 2 passes. Bikini area: Emjoi produced the smoothest result. This area did hurt the first time I did it; but it was tolerable...eye watering pain, not screaming in pain. Also, I was able to make it through the whole area in one sitting. I had tried this before with the braun a few times and the pain had been so unbearable I had to stop. I do like the braun features of the light and that it is cordless; however, the power that the cord adds to the emjoi makes being tethered to the wall not so bad. (the cord is fairly long.) I would buy this one over the braun any day....the time I am saving is astounding! FYI, any epilator you get will be easier on your skin than shaving - shaving causes your skin to lose its elasticity. Also, the epilator will never cut you or get dull!
  37. My left leg was left with irritated red bumps for WEEKS that wouldn't go away. Maybe I'm just too sensitive.<br /><br />I really wanted this to work :( I don't mind the noise or pain (although it's not exactly a plus) but the fact that I don't even get smooth skin means this is NOT worth it for me....
  38. Tell ya what, I was hoping this was better than what I was led to believe. There was not a lot of pain with the item. I did not like the fact that when the hairs start to pretrube out there were bumps on my legs, something I do not get with regular shaving with the razor. Bottom line, save your money and stick to using a razor!

But instead it cuts the hair and doesn't pull from the root as I have examined after each use. I love this product even though it doesn't completely pull every hair out from the root. But I wished that it pulled every single hair from the root so that i wouldnt have to \\"touch-up\\" every 2-3 days. It does take a while to go over an area. It can get time consuming and eventually the skin feels raw-like.
  40. I got this after using the Braun 5270 X'elle (the highest rated epilator here on Amazon) for about 1.5 years. And although I do love the Braun, this epilator is easily 2X faster! For me this is the biggest advantage. Before it would take me 1-1.5 hrs to do my whole legs, but now it's half that! I'm so happy with it. I'll agree with some reviewers that say it's almost too powerful. I do appear to have better luck using the lower setting, it seems to get more hairs. Also, it's not a miracle worker, you do have to go over certain areas more than once. In addition, it seems like hairs have to be a little bit longer for this one to work than for the Braun to work. And, it is much less painful than the Braun, huge plus! Cons: no light, no hair receptacle, no shaver head included, can't get to small areas very easily, especially difficult on knees. The Braun has the shaver head, and it's easier to manage. But, if I were to pick one, it would be the Emjoi AP-18 Emagine, hands down.

You have no choice but to buy the parts direct from Emjoi, which means you're screwed. If they'd like my business back they can send me a new head for free.

  61. This is our second Emjoi epilator. We used the other one until it finally gave out from exhaustion. So we ordered this one because it is more powerful.<br /><br />For those of you wondering just how painful an epilator is, I will spill my guts here, and you can decide for yourself if the pain is worth the end result. Since we are on our second one, we obviously believe it's worth it, but I won't lie. It smarts. The epilator rapidly pulls out hairs by the root, leaving your legs, arms, or wherever you choose to use it, smooth as the proverbial baby's butt. Arms and lower legs give a bit of a stinging sensation, and you can tell you are getting close to finishing an area when the stinging stops.<br /> Here, I should mention that the hair being pulled should be about a quarter inch long, tops. Just long enough to rip out. If it's longer, it will hurt more, so trim what you need to.<br /> Will it give you ladies the \\"Telly Savalas look\\" in the \\"nether reigons\\"? Absolutely!(Hubby and I secretly call this the \\"Bush Hog!! ) As I said, trim the hairs short, first. Will it hurt? Absolutely! But believe it or not, as time goes on and you continue to use it, the pain is less and less.<br /> One of the reasons for this is that the hair grows back softer, thinner, and smaller. And less dense. Consistent use of the Emjoi will keep you smooth longer and longer, and take less and less time to use. Hubby is a body builder/power lifter, and they too, go for the smooth groomed look, so our epilator gets a GOOD workout!<br /> We love it. I can't imagine going back to nightly shaving of legs and arms. I loove the feel of smooth skin! Two thumbs up on a great product!!

  63. WOW!!! I am fairly pain tolerant though, so if you are more sensitive-use with caution. Start with the lower setting.<br />the sting was akin to the feeling you might get when using an electric razor and a longer hair gets caught and pulled momentarily. It did not sting on every pass-or on every hair-so it was a minus one on a scale of one to ten-ten being intolerable. Barely noticed the occasional sting. I was expecting far worse!<br /><br />Speed and ease of use were terrific. took me maybe all of 15-20 minutes to do both lower legs to a satisfactory finish. I did use an exfoliating sponge with warm soapy water on my skin first.<br /><br />It has two settings, lower is less ouchy in general- but you remove more hairs per pass on the higher setting.<br />Smoothness factor-was about an 8 out of ten. I can see a few hairs I missed, not many- and not sure of the re-growth that I will see in the days to come.<br /><br />The noise was a surprise-but not much noisier than any other electric razor I have used.<br />I would highly recommend this tool as a great way to stay hair-free and smooth this summer.

So as one last try, because the Epilator removes hair for a longer period of time and when it grows back there are no stickers, I tried the Emjoi AP-18 Emagine Dual Opposed 72 Tweezer Head Epilator. Glad I did, it works pretty good at removing the hair, needs to be used only once or twice a week, no stickers and the very best thing is it won't take a bite if you get close to tender skin. The only thing that could be improved is it needs a slower speed. Even set on slow speed it tends to break a few of the hairs off instead of pulling them out. But I would guess it's getting better than an eighty percent pull rate. Get the rest of the hair the next time.

  70. I had to return this item. There were two issues which did not work well for me. 1. With 72 tweezer heads, I thought the product would deliver faster and/or more efficient epilating. This was not the case. I feel it does not have enough power to drive the heads. 2. The concave design works in an anti-efficient manner for my legs. A convex design would have been more appropriate. Because the devise is curved, I had to press very hard on the parts of my legs with athletic curves, particularly the back part of my thighs. Too much work. I ended up purchasing the Braun Xpressive, which I am completely happy with. The Emagine may be a great device for a lot of people, it just depends on your needs.

It will always be painful to pull hair from the root; if you expect it to be painless, you must be a cyborg. Reality is, you ARE pulling hair off your skin. The trick is to have a machine that works fast so you don't feel it as much. The other trick is to have your skin as dry as possible, so I apply baby powder as it also lifts the hair and makes it easier. This machine does exactly that. I am allergic to razors, so I have no other choice but to do depilation. If you have the need for a reliable machine, this is the one.

  86. I can tell that the people giving this item a negative review don't really understand how epilating works. It takes a few weeks to get all the hair off but after that it's smoothness all over.<br /><br />I'm glad there's finally an epilator for us vets. I've been tweezing for many years now and I just want an epilator that grabs it all. It doesn't hurt in the slightest any more. I've owned just about every brand of epilator out there and this is my favorite by far.
  87. I have used epilators since the first one on the market, Epilady, in the 80's. Having very heavy hair growth, shaving was a nightmare. I'd have a prickly \\"beard\\" within hours of shaving. At least with epilators, the \\"beard\\" problem disappeared and regrowth was soft. But the process of doing both legs could easily take 30 minutes, sometimes much longer. I have used several generations of Epilady, then a Phillips and then a Braun, on which the light was a very good feature, but decided to try the Emjoi when the Braun died. This is like having a Jaguar rather than a Chevrolet. I can do both legs, lower and upper, in less than 15 minutes! I have never been bothered by discomfort with depilitating since getting used to original Epilady, but do find the Emjoi causes even less of a pulling sensation. If you need a heavy duty \\"machine\\" this is the one for you!
  88. I had an Emjoi caress gold for many years, it did a fairly good job, if slow,and I used it primarily on legs. The switch broke so I was in the market for a new one and after reading reviews bought this. It arrived yesterday and I love it. Very impressed by function and speed. If I say I did lower legs, arms (that I rarely do since hair light) and underarms,(usually shave) right out of the box I think it is an indication of speed and ease. Paid for itself already vs waxing, and a good price on amazon. Of course it hurts, you are pulling hair out by the root, but for such a shorter amount of time it is definately worth it. In fact so fast on an area with light amount of hair that I thought it wasn't working when the sting of the removal stopped so quickly. Only consideration might be need for power cord in right location for light/mirror since no battery option. No broken hairs or any left behind after moving over area a few times. Overall excellent.
  89. It hurts, that's for sure - but no more than waxing and it hurts my wallet considerably less than waxing! If you soak in a hot bath before you epilate, it's much easier on your skin. This really does work well and it keep hair away for a long time, longer than waxing usually does for me because it gets the tiny hairs too. I am very glad I got this.
  90. Today is 1/17/2011. I purchased product 12/16/2010. It seems to be working as described; however, more time for evaluation is needed. I can say that I feel little to no pain--barely prickly.

  93. I actually was replacing an older Emjoi - an upgrade - and am I glad I did, there is so much power - I absolutely love this little machine - I can remove any unwanted hair so fast and my skin is just absolutely smooth and soft after. I'm use to Epilators so for me there was absolutely no pain as I've read in reviews for other epilators, but those people may be using them for the first time. I would highly recommend this product.
  94. Although I must warn those who are extremely sensitive to pinch-like pains, I absolutely love this epilator. I've used the Panasonic wet dry one before this, and decided to go for a dry one this time that did the job quicker. Even though a lot of people will try to persuade you that a wet epilator would 1) hurt less 2) be easier to clean, i think both claims are misleading. I don't like getting my bath water mixed with hair, and it takes too long to shower if i use it in the shower. I also find it more difficult to clean. I just like it dry better. Anyway -- my advice is if you're looking for an epilator for the bottom half of the body and perhaps underarms too - i use it there all the time, it hurts yes, but it is tolerable and you can just push through it if you're determined enough to not have hair for a month after - this is your best option. Being corded is a HUGE plus too. My old panasanoic took forever to charge and even if the charge wasn't out all the way, it started losing power. Besides, it's not like you're going to epilate anywhere other than your bathroom, or room, or just home - at least, i wouldn't. Lots of power, efficient, quicker than most, tolerable pain. I love it!
  95. I have sensitive skin, fine hair & have been using epilators for many years. With my last one wearing out, I decided to try this two head model. I didn't necessarily believe that it would be quicker or less iritating, so I am pleasantly surprised. SO far I have only used it on my legs, it's size and power make me hesitate to try more sensitive areas. Pros: For my skin/hair type it is quicker and my skin is much less irritated aferwards. It does a good job of removing the hairs with one or two swipes. Cons: Noiseier than expected and not cordless. Neither of which is a big deal.
  96. This is my first epilator but I am not convinced it's worth the money. I have to go over the same spot on my legs slowly and several times to get them really smooth and I thought I wouldn't have to, not with the dual opposed 72 tweezer heads. It still beats shaving every day and for that, I like it a lot.
  97. Seeing the great and not-so-great reviews, I was having second thoughts after I placed my order for the Emagine epilator. When it came, I decided to try it out and I can't believe how easy and fast it is. I have an average pain tolerance and even underarm hair removal just stings a little (and I expect I'll get used to it). I'm allergic to depilatories, waxing is a pain and shaving leaves me with cuts...I'll be using the Emjoi from now on. I was trying to decide between this one and one of the cheaper cordless Emjoi models, but I'm glad I went for this one. It feels sturdy and I'm convinced the pain factor is less because of the 72 tweezer head. Most of my hair was removed with one pass, only a few areas needed to have more than one pass. I can't recommend this unit enough - if you're trying to decide, having a cord really isn't such a big deal when you can do your arms, underarms and legs in less than 20 minutes!
  98. I just received my Emjoi Emagine last night. I have thought about buying one of these devices in the past, but it just seemed like it might be too painful for me. I've tried depilatories (sometimes they burn me), wax (for my face), the Epicare coil (ow!), and tweezing before I bought the Emjoi. I figured that even though it might hurt, with 72 pairs of tweezers, at least it will be over quickly. I don't consider my pain tolerance to be particularly high, either, but I've gotten used to using wax over the years. After about 20 minutes of hovering this thing over my leg and not being able to place it on my skin, I finally gathered up my courage. It stung like a mofo....for the first minute or so. After that, the pain decreased significantly. My legs had a few days worth of razor stubble on them, so the hair wasn't really long. I think that might have helped me. As soon as I stopped, there was no lingering pain, and my legs were smooth! Today, I was even able to use it on stray hairs under my chin (thanks, birth control pills!) and it was MUCH faster than waxing. When I used to wax the facial hair, it took forever because the hairs were never removed on the first pass. The emjoi got the hard-to-see hair in a few minutes, where waxing could take 20 minutes or more, and I wouldn't be 100% hair free. I'm really pleased with this product so far. I thought it would take me a week or more to get used to the feeling of an epilator, so I'm incredibly happy that I'm adjusting to it so well in just two days! I'm so happy that I won't have to buy wax and razors anymore. So, if you're worried that you won't be able to handle the pain, you might just surprise yourself!
  99. this is a good epilator..
  100. It works very well but it does hurt and the machine noise does set off your nerves before and during use. But it works well so I use it.
  101. Pros: it really gets rid of the hair & less & less grows back & what does grow back is lighter & finer. It's especially fantastic for getting all those tiny chin hairs! Cons: It takes longer to shave than a regular razor, so you have to go fairly slowly. My electric shaver was faster, but then, I had to use it every day. I read a ton of reviews (mostly for the Braun 5270) & besides the pain a lot of women complained about, I had gotten the idea that you only had to use the epilator once every 4 to 6 weeks. This is not possible; as our hair does not all grow back at the same time. However, after the first couple of shaves, I only have to shave my legs & underarms about once a week to get the few hairs that grew in since the last shave. I especially love using this on my chin hairs! I have spent over $1000 on electrolysis & that only partially worked. I was still plucking 20 -30+ chin hairs every morning! Now, I use the Emjoi every couple of days on 2-4 hairs! It even gets the peach fuzz. One of the Braun reviewers (Mark Twain) has good advice for the first time users: shave (with a razor) 5-7 days before you're going to use the epilator. Then, when you're ready to use the epilator, take a bath to open the pores. Shave in the direction the hair grows and stretch the skin for the area you are shaving - very important especially under the arms & crotch areas. The first few times it is a bit painful, but keeping the skin stretched really helps. It's like plucking your eyebrows - it hurt the first few times, but you got used to it & it stopped hurting. A couple of times the epilator caught a hunk of skin because it wasn't stretched. It doesn't hurt at all; it just scares you the first time. Shaving under the arms is much easier than it seems it would be - again, make sure to keep the skin stretched. Also, I find the underarm hairs that grow back are much lighter, finer & fewer. The only problem I've experienced is hairs growing back just under the skin in a leg area; I can see them, but can't reach them until they've finally grown through the upper layer. These areas are just on the outside of my calves, by my by knees & I think it might be because I always wear pants & sit all day & that area is tighter against my legs. Several reviewers remarked about making sure when bathing to scrub the shaved areas well to exfoliate & I don't always remember to do that. I bought the Emjoi about a year ago & have been very happy with it. It has an electric cord that plugs into the bottom of the shaver & reaches over 8 feet. A nice option would be also rechargeable, but I definitely would choose electric above battery-only; you need to keep the constant power for shaving. I'm surprised that no one (consumer companies/websites) has made an effort of comparing epilators by shaving one leg with one top brand & the other with another top brand for easy comparison's sake! Regardless of whether you buy the Emjoi or the Braun, IT IS WORTH IT - especially for you ladies who have the embarrassing chin hairs!! Jan 2013 update: I'm still using this great epilator & loving it. My underarm hairs are so light and sparse that I can pretty much get away without saving for a month or more (between living in AZ & my hot flashes, I always were sleeveless blouses). My chin hairs have also pretty much disappeared - I still shave every 3 or 4 days, but instead of hundreds of chin hairs, there are only about 5-10. The growth of hair on my legs is interesting - very few from the calf down, around my knees, and thighs, but somewhat more under and above the back of my knees, but still 1/3 of what was there before I started using the Emjoi. One thing: I shave my legs about once every two months, so if I had done it more often & regularly, I'm sure the hair would be much sparser. It's pretty much painless to use everywhere, except the pubic area, which I think is because the hairs are so much thicker than everywhere else. I can still highly recommend this! April2017 Update Sometime after my last update in 2013 the tweezers head on the first Emjoi started catching, i.e. stopped turning, at first it was every once in a while, then more often, until I just couldn't use it any more. Luckily, I had bought a warranty with Square Trade and got a full refund, which I used to buy a new Emjoi. After three or so years, the electric cord/adapter for the 2nd Emjoi stopped working. I didn't have the one from the first Emjoi anymore and my Square Trade warranty had expired, but I found another that fit at one of the big box stores. The issue I’ve been experiencing the last month or so is that epilator seems to be shaving instead of epilating. I started noticing that the hair is growing back much faster and there’s a lot more of it on my chin. Also, up until the last month or so, when the hair on my legs grew back, it was always soft and I could barely feel it, but now I feel the stubbles, like I used to get from shaving. So, this leaves me with two options: 1) buy another Emjoi AP-18, or 2) some other epilator brand. Once again, I have spent many hours reading hundreds of reviews, and based on the reviews, have (once again) narrowed it down to the same Emjoi, or one of the Braun models. End result: I'll buy another Emjoi AP-18 because I don't want to be stuck with hair on my legs, face, under arms, or bikini area due to a dead/empty battery. Since the hair on my legs and underarms has become so sparse (before I started epilating 10 yrs ago, it was very heavy & dark), I usually only use the Emjoi once every 4 – 6 wks, but it takes me a good hour at least. The Brauns are only good for about 40 minutes. Also, several reviewers complained about the battery completely dying within 6 months to a year. My own experience with most things with a built-in battery is that they start slowing down as the battery drains and eventually completely die (cell phones, Bluetooth, tablets, tooth brush, electric razor, handheld vacuum, etc.) which is why I buy cameras that use lithium batteries and buy spare batteries. Even though I’ve had to replace two units after 2.5 and 4 years, I still feel that the Emjoi works great and is worth the $80 (which has not gone up in price since the first one I bought 10 yrs ago)! And, again, I can still highly recommend this!

The double heads actually do remove the hair more efficiently than my previous epilator that only had the one. My only complaints are that this model does not have a light and it isn't rechargeable. The cord can be somewhat awkward... All in all, totally worth the money.

  106. I bought this a while ago and at first it worked wonderfully. Then 2-3 months later it started to jam once in a while. Pretty soon it was jamming every 3-4 seconds while epilating and I'd have to push the wheels to get it spinning again. This became tiresome as you can imagine. I then took the head apart (completely apart) and cleaned out the gears from debris. I assumed this would fix it. It didn't. The jamming continued until I couldn't take it. I caved and bought a replacement head ($30) hoping maybe the initial head was just defective. Surprise - the Same thing happened. Clearly the person who engineered this device failed. The postive reviews are either from people who reviwed too early or people trying to sell this to you. Do Not buy this product.

  108. For years I have tried different methods of removing hair. At home waxing, yuck messy and doesn't do the trick. Then 2 1/2 years ago I bought a Panasonic epilator. Yes, it did work but got ingrown hairs and some scarring not to mention some slight scarring and hated those red bumps that lasted a few days. In January a purchased a No No. Well that was rather a waste as it really didn't do anything that burn the surface hair and not a good job at that. I finally broke down and bought this Emagine. This is wonderful. It is a close to shaving as one could ask for and not painfull to my legs and upper thighs and bikini area. I was brave enough to do my underarms. Since this was the first time with my underarms there was a tiny bit of discomfort. I know that this will go away the more that I use it in this area. If you are new to epilating you will find that you hair really does come back slower and some will not come back again after using awhile. I had no red bumps at all with this. I am so happy that I splurged for this it was worth every penny. Now I know some people complained about they wish it was cordless but truely corded will keep its power. I already own a little Energizer battery pack that I can plug it into so I can take with me in any chair, room, etc so I can get plenty light and I don't worry about having an outlet. Really gals, spend the money on this it is truely worth it.
  109. I have been using Emjoi epilators for the last 15 years, but this one by far is the best one yet! It is alot faster (since it has so many heads) and does alot better job than my previous ones and with less pain. Yes, when you first start using an epilator it hurts because you have so much hair, but the more you use it the less hair returns so the degree of pain lessens considerably. After 15 years, I only have to use it every three weeks or so. The hair that does return is so soft you hardly know it there. I am definitely recommending it to anyone I know.
  110. Thanks to this epilator I am enjoying a razor-free summer. It did take a while to epilate both of my legs the first time (at least an hour), but after the first time it goes by a lot quicker. I epilate every couple of days to get rid of any new growth, and it takes about 10 minutes. I have noticed that my once extremely thick and dark leg hair is now a lot thinner and lighter and takes a lot longer to grow. In addition, I am getting a lot fewer ingrown hairs than when I was shaving. After seeing such great results on my legs, I decided to start epilating my upper lip and underarms. The upper lip is not bad pain-wise, definitely better than waxing (and better than the wrinkles that waxing ultimately causes), but the underarms were quite a doosie the first time. I have a pretty high pain tolerance, and I was gritting my teeth the first time I epilated my underarms. After I was finished, I was amazed to see that the dark roots were completely gone, my underarms were the same color as the rest of my arm! I felt like I could be a deoderant model! I have been epilating both for about 3 weeks now, and the pain has decreased dramatically as well as hair thickness and growth time. It is just one of those things that you have to get used to, but the pros definitely outweigh the cons.<br /><br />Friendly advice for anyone having problems with pain and/or red bumps. I have found that exfoliating with a loofah and salt or sugar scrub in a warm shower helps a lot before epilating. I typically exfoliate once every three days, just to prevent ingrown hairs (I am very prone to them). I also recommend rubbing witch hazel on any areas that get red bumps after you epilate. I had bumps on my thighs after the first time , and after applying the witch hazel, they were gone in about 5 minutes. One last thing to do is take care of any ingrown hairs with a pair of pointed tweezers dipped in rubbing alcohol.<br /><br />If you are like me and despise shaving everyday, I would highly suggest investing in this product. This is my favorite beauty buy of the year.product. This is my favorite beauty buy of the year.

  131. This definitely takes out the hair from the root, however it won't leave your skin silky smooth like a razor does. There are some pretty tiny puny fine/thin hairs on your leg that this cannot grasp, so those small ones will be left behind. For the most part though your legs will be hair free. I tweezer out some of the leftovers myself if they aren't too many or if they are bothering me too much. At first I was intimidated by this product because I saw the tweezers rotate so fast, I thought it would hurt. It does hurt to an extent. I'm used to the pain of waxing so this did not bother me too much. Also, remember to clean out the hair that was pulled or else it'll get too crowded with hair in the epilator. Overall I really do love this product. Saves me from cuts from razors and saves the trip and cost of waxing. Plus I don't have to wait forever to have my hair grow out long in order to wax. Anddd you don't have to worry about the expensive razor refills either. This epilator is a good investment even though the hefty price tag looks pretty expensive at first. It pays for itself after a while and saves you money in the end. Get it!

  135. This product is great! I wish I would have known about this years ago. I have very sensitive underarm skin and due to shaving, it gets very very irritated and has become discolored. This product has helped to lighten the skin on my underarms and I no longer have any irritation. I use this about every two weeks. However, I've noticed the more I use it, the longer it takes for my hair to grow back, which is great! When the hair does grow back, it's much much thinner. It's true, the first time you use this product it can be a bit painful, but honestly, it's not that bad at all. And it's really only the first time you use it that it's kind of annoying, because all the other times after are much less painful (barely noticeable) due to the thinness of the hair. It's not as quick as shaving, but you spend less time overall in that you have to wait a few weeks to remove your hair, as opposed to a razor where you have to shave every day or every other day. I've recommended this to everyone I know. It's much better than waxing.
  136. My first time ever epilating was after purchasing this Emagine, although I have EXTENSIVE experience with all other types of hair removal; I've been getting professional waxings for the past 10 years, and I also am in the process of both laser and electrolysis treatments on my legs. Let me say that I CANNOT BELIEVE that I didn't try epilating sooner - what was I thinking not buying this thing years ago!?! This is now my very favorite method of hair removal!! The biggest downside to waxing is waiting that ~3 weeks for the hair to grow out so that you actually get your money's worth when you pay for a salon waxing (and on that note, the cost of professional waxing is a huge downfall, as well)... but with the Emagine you can epilate, and then continue to run the thing over your legs weekly/every few days to grab those few hairs that either weren't yet long enough when you first epilated or that possibly broke off during the process. It is SO great to feel like I'm \\"in control\\" of the process any time instead of waiting for my next salon waxing. The Emgaine also amazed me with the short hairs it was able to grab - it says that it will remove hairs as short as .5mm length, and that is absolutely accurate (another big advantage over waxing!). In regard to the pain factor: yes, epilating is very painful. However, after a ton of waxing, laser, and electrolysis treatments, it honestly doesn't phase me much. But be aware that the pain IS more agonizing than waxing, as the process is much slower - at least with waxing a large section of hair can be removed in one second... but with the epilator you can expect the consistent pain to take awhile. On that note, it took me about 2 hours in total to epilate my full legs and entire bikini area the first time; but as I mentioned, I've spent only a few minutes each week maintaining since then. The one possible negative I do want to point out is that I have dark, coarse hair with the exception of my outer thighs, where the hair is lighter & finer. While the Emagine worked INCREDIBLY on the dark hair, I didn't get quite as astonishing results on the light hair (I think the machine may have broken off some of the lighter hairs, even when used on the Low setting). So if you have very fine hair, I'd say that the Emagine (or epilating altogether?) may not be for you.
  137. This is the first epilator i've ever owned, having shaved all my life, it being the easiest and least painful option for hair removal. i did a lot of research online before deciding on an epilator, and even more before deciding to try this one. i have a very low pain tolerance, so i was quite sceptical, but willing to give it a go given that i'd read in a number of places that epilators are now nowhere near as painful as they used to be, and i had read many reviews stating that this one was around the least painful there was. i have just received my new epilator and used it for the first time, and i can definitely say that it is really not that bad at all. Yes, there is a very mild pinching sensation as each hair is removed, but its definitely well within my ability to tolerate it, and even do an entire leg at a time. It is far easier to see whether the you've been successful with removing the hair with an epilator, and with this one, you do need to go over the same spot a few times sometimes, but mostly, it does a great job first time round. i doubt there's a hair removal technique yet invented that really never needs to go over the same area twice. Like with all hair removal, you will need to do it regularly at least to start, because your hair grows in cycles, and when you do it today, you're not catching the hairs that are still growing in the pores and haven't peeped out as yet. One cannot complain about fast regrowth or ingrowns in relation to epilators, because that's really individual to each person's body, so the factors i believe are important are: * Is it painful? - Not enough to worry about. Also, i could actually feel a sharp, pricking sensation in a number of the pores for a while afterwards, but nothing disturbing. * How fast can you get it done? - For me, this epilator was perhaps a couple of minutes faster than shaving, but nothing to write home about. * How smooth are you afterwards? - Very smooth, very smooth. * Is it easy? -As easy as shaving with this one. * Can i attack multiple parts of my body with the same tool? - Yes - the same head can do the upper lip, underarms, legs and bikini area. However, the instructions say that when using on the upper lip, one should only target individual hairs at a time, and use only one of the heads. * Can i use it wet and dry? This one is dry only, but i don't see that as a problem. * Is it easy to use? - Very. It sits easily in your hand, and while the instructions state which way round you're supposed to hold it, the shape of the body makes you want to hold it that way anyway. The on/off/ slider is easy to intuit, and really, its much like shaving from there, except that you're supposed to pull your skin taut as you go. Easy peasy. * Is it easy to clean? - Yes. It comes with a little brush that is easy to hold and easy to use on the epilator head. The head is detachable for easier cleaning if you wish, and comes off as a completely separate unit, with no internal working exposed on either the body or the head when it is removed. All you need to do is brush off the hairs and you're done. * How noisy is it? - Moderately, but quieter than many electric razors. Its not quiet, per se, but it didn't scare my cats when i turned it on next to them. * Can i go out looking fab straight away? - i would say no. This is a small drawback i guess, to epilators in general, not just this one. i have quite white skin, and it was decidedly marked with little red dots for a while afterwards. * Is it worth the money? - Admittedly i should probably answer this question after at least a couple of months usage, but so far, i'd say yes, and based on the majority of the reviews i've read (many of which are after a significant period of use), i would say yes.
  138. I owned a Braun Silk-Epi for a while which I loved. I let my sister borrow it and never got it back (she loved it too!). I looked at instruction manuals, on-line recommendations for use, and perused the reviews here on Amazon hoping to find out what I was doing wrong. No luck. It doesn't work for me, but I am not sure why. I am not overly hairy and my hair is not overly course. Guess I will have to go back to the Braun...

My previous Emjoi lasted for almost 10 years. So this is pretty disappointing for me, given the price.

The key to smooth epilated skin is exfoliation, exfoliation, exfoliation; so make sure you do that everyday after you epilate to prevent ingrown hairs. I've used it for two weeks so far on every part of my body and I am sold.<br /><br />**********************CONS************************************<br />It does not come with a shaver/trimmer head, for the cost I would have expected that too.

  144. Really!! Good quality love it
  145. Great machine! First time epilator...you always feel the prickliness and the first epilating process...it wasn't as bad as I thought and I loved the results. My pores did get irritated but healed quickly and the hairs are much finer and didn't come back in immediately and I know it will only get better. I had the big, thick hairs on my legs, too.
  146. I have owned this product over a year now, and love love love it. It is painful at first, but once your legs get used to it, it is sooooo worth the reward of not having to shave every day. The key to minimizing pain is to pull your skin taught while epilating over your skin. Also, keep your skin hydrated and use a pumice stone on any areas you epilate EVERY TIME YOU SHOWER. This prevents ingrown hairs which then have to be tweezed to the surface before you epilate (I have to do this some). My armpits still hurt the worst, but again, pull the skin super taught--grin and bare it. Sooooo worth not having to worry every morning about shaving. If you can, epilate outside so as not to worry about sweeping up all the hairs that are left laying around after their death (mwahahaha). Bikini area is too difficult for me, so I only tried a couple of times. Epilating is like shaving, you're not going to get every single hair with just one sweep of the epilator. Be realistic with any product you buy--the more you go over the area, the more hairs it picks up. Go over the area softly and kind of floating and don't grind the epilator into your skin, it will bog it down anyway. Happy Epilating :):)
  147. I have an old Emjoi (white)I purchased at Sharper Image at least 10 yrs ago for about 50 bucks. It came in a white box with a \\"loofah\\" pad, and an auxiliary electric razor head. It's a LOUD, but effective workhorse. I saw the Emagine in a catalog, (and was seduced by the snazzy, red color more than anything), and figured that my old Emjoi HAD to be less effective. I was wrong. This product takes twice as long to depilate as the old one. It's light and slightly less noisy, but who really cares about the noise anyway? It hurts less, but it takes longer. The old one's head is much easier to clean, i.e., one could see what was there and rinse it off, then set it aside to dry. This head is more enclosed; I can't tell if hair is inside the head, and it's not clear to me how well rinse water will evaporate, if at all. There is no auxiliary head included to do the final smoothing which was, for me, the key to achieving the smoothness of a razor without having to use one. At first, I used the red one to start, and finished with the old one and the auxiliary head. Now I'm just using the old one. I should note that I'm not a hirsute person, and I'd imagine that a particularly hairy or coarse-haired person would find this product even less effective than I do. And as for \\"using one side of the head for facial hair\\"--do so only at your peril. If you use one side, it does nothing; if you use both you'd better be pulling your skin super tight or it will suck in half your face! I won't say I'm thoroughly disappointed, but I've gone back to using the old one exclusively.

It also had a light which was very helpful for seeing those thin fair hairs. I only decided to replace it because lately it had been taking longer and longer to epilate as I think the tweezers were getting a little dull or maybe I wasn't keeping them clean enough.<br /><br />Anyway, I wanted to get what I thought would be a more high-end epilator. I have heard good things about Emjoi and saw this beast of an epilator that had pretty decent reviews. And I figured the dual head action would speed up the epilation, considering my biggest gripe is how long epilation takes.<br /><br />But the Emjoi AP-18 turned out to be a massive disappointment. It doesn't even get the hairs AT ALL. I have rather coarse dark leg hair which is why I started epilating instead of shaving. Maybe that has something to do with it, but it just seems that this epilator cannot get the hairs. I have to go over an area 20 times just to get a single hair. I have tried every direction too-- with the growth, against, SIDEWAYS, and nothing works. I've tried all speeds--slow or fast it matters not. I can even leave the epilator in place spinning over a hair for 20 seconds and it won't come out. It takes FOREVER to make any progress. It seems totally random or luck that I get any at all. It's also pathetically bad in the bikini area where you have curves to deal with.<br /><br />Not to mention, even after I spend forever trying to get rid of the hairs and it finally gets a few, my legs do not feel smooth AT ALL. I can still feel small stubs of hair. Such a waste of money. I would recommend a different brand entirely.

  164. I'm a long time Epilator user. I've been using these products since 1990 - so I feel that after 20 years, I'm a pretty good judge off them. This particular epilator does not work as stated. Yes, it pulls the hairs. And under the right conditions, it will pull the hairs faster than the other Epilators. But the conditions must be that you're working in an area which has a lot of hair. Where there's a lot of hair, it pulls them out like crazy! But if you are working in an area where there isn't a lot of hair, it has a hard time picking up the fine single hairs. And it creates a problem that even if you're very hairy and working in a more densely hairy area, this product will leave small fine hairs behind. Then you are left to work very hard at getting it to pick up the hairs which were left behind. Getting the small hairs takes so much time that it negates the amount of time you thought you saved when working in the very hairy area. Also, the shape of the head is different than the others. It has a hard time around bony areas - like around the knees and in the bikini area. The most important thing is that I had to pull out my old Braun epilator (which is slow, and on its last leg (haha -no pun intended)) to do my bikini and knee area along with pulling out the stragglers all over the rest of the legs that the Emjoi left behind. This was the most expensive of all the epilators. But the performance does not justify the cost. I don't like it and now I must find a way to get a different one. As stated above, I've been using an epilator for 20 years now. I was excited to try the Emjoi because the process really does take a lot of time and I hoped that this could cut that time in half - as stated. It didn't. Bottom line - This is not better, in fact - it's inferior.

  182. After seeing many of the beauty gurus of Youtube give reviews about the epilator, I had to have one. The first time is the worst and it does get better. The hair does thin out and its appearance becomes lighter.<br /><br />I use my epilator once a week fresh out of the shower for best results.<br /><br />It works great, is easy to clean, and has a cute little storage bag.<br /><br />It is not chargeable, it does not have batteries. You plug it in and go, which is great! No one wants batteries to die in the middle of tweezing, so having a plugged in device aids in avoiding ingrown hairs that were half pulled when the little tweezers died.<br /><br />I would recommend this to anyone who wants to get away from shaving and waxing.<br /><br />By the way, this device has gotten rid of underarm shadow and gives me the smoothiest underarms ever!<br /><br />Great product!!
  183. Love this. Hurts on your face but gets the job done.
  184. I have just begun using this item, and I think it will work for me. The hair doesn't grow back as quickly as when I use a razor. For those of you who have tender skin - it's going to sting, especially so behind the knees. Also, I don't have a lot of under arm hair, and using this Emjoi did leave some small red spots when the hair was pulled out.I don't recommend using this on your face. Overall, I am satisfied with this product. Any red spots went away in a very short time. There were no residual discomforts after using this device. My suggestion is to take your time when using this tweezer device, and treat yourself with your favorite body lotion when done.
  185. Very quick and painless removal! Just in a matter of a few minutes. With the double sided rotation it relay does the job right!
  186. I am a man, and this was the best thing I've bought in a while. The price at Amazon was amazing. I bought the men's version of the ap-18 and I am very happy with it. I would have been happier with the red version, but only slightly because the edges on the head slope up on the men's version and down on the ladies. This causes some problems getting into some areas of my skin. I like to be hairless from the neck down, and I have some very coarse hair in places, but this thing plucks even the thickest hairs almost painlessly. There are some tricks to this though.<br /><br />First off, if you have never waxed or epilated before, it will hurt like a mad man. What I mean is if you are starting off with old growth, thick shaved hairs, you will most likely cry from using it on most places, but if you are using it on fine new growth you will not feel pain just a gentle and mild sting. One thing I have learned is that you should use baby powder. It makes the hairs stand up and the epilator glide over your skin. Unfortunately I didn't figure that out until I had used the thing for a whole week. Baby powder makes the process ten times less painful and at least two to three times quicker.<br /><br />I found that I could not predict what body parts would hurt the most. For instance, I figured that the crack, taint and hole would have been the most painful, but it was the least. That did require some slight acrobatics to accomplish. My wife could not stop laughing at me. I also found that my ribcage was almost unbearable. It was intensely painful and tickled so much I could not hold still. My wife had to do my back, and that also hurt. I found that if someone else did it I could not anticipate the pain so it was worse. If you are very hairy I suggest that you wax first or do something called sugaring. Sugaring is less painful than waxing, but more time consuming and more messy.<br /><br />Anyway, the ap-18 is the best and most effective epilator I have ever used. The head spins sofast and there are so many tweezers, that the hairs just seem to fall out.<br /><br />I just love this product. It makes me so smooth and it is luxurious to use. My wife loves touching me now that I have no sharp stubble. And it makes me look amazing
  187. This product is so easy to use. Especially as I had help from my husband. Never had a bikini or leg wax, in fact never have removed the hair on the bikini line. For legs and under arms had always been a razor girl. However, I decided that it was time to spice up my life ( just turned 50). Anyway with hubbies help, I now have a new \\"look\\" , although I have to say there was some distractions along the way with his help :-)<br /><br />Just a hint, make sure you keep the skin taunt, as this allows a good grip but also reduces pain. Although I have to say that the pain is minimal, it is more the shock/surprise factor for first time use. Also important that you trim hair to a reasonable length to allow the tweezers to grab closer to skin. Great result, highly recommended.
  188. As far as epilators go, this is a great product. It's stronger then the battery operated ones I've used, and with the extra tweezing capability it gets the job done faster. Of course it hurts a bit at first use, as some reviewers have mentioned, but tweezing hair will most likely hurt,especially in sensitive areas. The trick to using it and making it less painful, is making sure you take a hot bath or shower prior, and pulling the skin as tight as you can in the area your using the epilator. The tighter the skin, the better contact it has with the hair your trying to remove, and the less it pulls at the skin, which often creates some of the pain. You can also tilt it so only one of the heads is contacting the skin until you get used to using it. In areas where the hair is thicker, you may have to make several passes to get all the hair. Once you use this, if you continue to do maintenance on the tweezed area before all the hair grows back out, it won't hurt as bad as the initial use. It also has a nice safety feature that prevents you from pressing the heads down to hard upon your skin, which is a great added feature. I had only minor skin irritation in the area that was tweezed, and it lasted only briefly, so do it a few hours before your planning on exposing the area. I also find moisturizing after tweezing helps diminish this problem. I think it is especially nice in the bikini line areas, where razor bumps are often a problem, there was no redness except for the initial one mentioned before, which is gone very quickly. I went on a camping trip for a week and could stay in shorts with no razor stubble growth, that's a bonus!
  189. An excellent product but ouch. Expected with an epilator. Effective at removing hair.

  201. This is the first Epilator I have purchased, so I felt it was unfair to give it a full 5 stars, since I had nothing to compare it to. I read several reviews and watched even more on Youtube. I am very happy I bought this particular model as my first epilator. Surprisingly, I get better results from this thing on my bikini line, than on any other part of my body. My trouble spots are my shins and armpits, but after 3 months of use, I honestly feel they're getting better. At first, my shins never felt fully smooth after epilating, but now that the hair is thinning out, they're finally smooth. My armpits on the other hand, seem like the hair is breaking more than I was hoping it would. Yes, I am getting better results over time, but I still wish the hair didn't break off as often. After the first month of use, I noticed the tweezers didn't pick up the hair as well. I called in and the lady told me to use a little rubbing alcohol, and that worked a little better. But I found the best way to clean the epilator, was to use an old toothbrush to actually scrub out any build up in there. I keep it clean and it works perfectly. I'm especially glad I started using this in the off season when my legs weren't \\"on display.\\" I am confident I'll be ready for the summer with this thing. Oh, one more thing. I had issues with ingrown hairs only on my shins. Those suck. They're not painful by any means, or even red. They're just growing under the skin. So rather than picking them out, I let them grow themselves out, and I'm having less of an issue with them.
  202. So far I like this epilator. It does not catch all the little hairs especially if they are thin but in my experience it is less painful than other epilators I tried (e.g. Braun). It has a cord so there is no issue with it dying in the middle of epilation (and having to wait for it to recharge).<br /><br />One negative is that there is no light on the epilator (which Braun has) so sometimes it is difficult to see the hair.<br /><br />If epilating often, it does not take too long (for me it took about 0.5 hour for both legs plus some &#34;cleanup&#34; with the tweezers). After shaving it would take longer and possibly would be more painful as there will be more hair to &#34;take care off&#34; (after shaving, more hair will grow at the same stage which will look like more hair). If you never epilated before, I suggest not to start with hair that's too long and to start with lower legs. Those will be less painful. Underarms, upper legs and bikini will be more painful. With time the pain will not seem that bad. And of course there is an issue of ingrown hair, which happens with all epilations as as well as waxing. Exfoliation may help. I sometimes like to alternate shaving with epilation which may help with ingrown hair but then the process takes a bit longer.<br /><br />Overall happy with the product so far.
  203. Great for legs, underarms, and the bikini area. I would suggest used 5% Lidocaine numbing cream to numb the area before using it.   204. Of all the things on my daily personal maintenance list, shaving my legs is at the top. I can't stand the stubble as it rubs against my pants, and my husband gets a little queasy if the hair on my legs is longer than his buzz-cut head. As women, I think we've all played around with epilators, and the love/hate division is right down the middle. Of all the epilators out there, the eMagine by Emjoi has the most aggressive design, including 72 tweezing elements that Emjoi boasts is the most on the market. While I never look forward to \\"epilator night,\\" I keep telling myself that six weeks' worth of smooth legs is worth the discomfort. The eMagine is efficient and feels like an epilator feels--there's no getting around that. The eMagine is comfortable in the hand, glides easily across the skin, and has two power settings for fine or coarser hair. The eMagine is not rechargeable and must be plugged in to operate. The blade housing can be removed from the unit, and I clean it with keyboard air-based cleaner. As far as epilators go, the eMagine is a tough machine and should provide the user with 6 weeks of shave-free strutting.
  205. I had the Braun SE7681 Silk-&eacute;pil 7 Wet and Dry Epilator and the battery was starting to die, so I decided to try a Emjoi. I wish I had Emjoi first! It is MUCH much better.   211. This is the most amazing epilator I have ever used! I swear to you, it is like magic!<br /><br />I got my first epilator about 10 years ago and loved the convenience, but it wasn't that powerful and ran through batteries like crazy! After about a year, I upgraded to an Emjoi Golden Caress (I think that's what it was called) which could be plugged in or charged. The charging function was kind of ridiculous because you never knew how long the charge would last and it operated at a reduced speed when it wasn't plugged in. I just used it plugged in all the time. Then, when we moved overseas 4 years ago, despite using adapters and what not, my epilator died (same thing happened with my blow dryer and 3 of my husband's electric razors). Since I thought the same thing might happen to a new one, I waited until we moved back to the US to buy a new one. In the meantime, I went back to shaving my legs and waxing my arms, underarms, upper lip, and bikini area.<br /><br />I was very satisfied with my previous Emjoi when I used it while it was plugged in, but the difference between the two models is absolutely night and day! The Emagine is much faster. The first time I used it I would guess that I hadn't done anything to remove my arm hair in over 3 months, so there was a significant amount of hair. It took me less than 15 minutes to get both arms completely hair-free! With my previous model, that definitely would have been more like a 30-40 minute job and I probably would have had to put in time later to go back over any areas that weren't perfect. Not only was the Emagine quicker, but I didn't require any touch ups - it seemed to really remove the hair uniformly.<br /><br />As far as pain goes, this is definitely the most comfortable epilator I have used. I really think that it just feels like a weird, prickly sensation. There's also something comforting about being in control of the epilator; if you're trying to remove hair and it hurts and you want to take a break, you can! Ithink that the speed of the model also seems to reduce the pulling sensation that you get with some other epilators. I really don't think that this model hurts at all, but I think the fact that I've been waxing and epilating for a while has made me a little more tolerant of discomfort.<br /><br />I know a lot of people are more familiar with wax than they are with epilating, so let me compare them a little. If you've waxed before, I think that epilating is definitely less painful because it doesn't grab the skin. I also think it's much cleaner than wax. For example, you don't have to worry about the wax being antimicrobial or the aesthetician dipping the spatula in it more than once or if the wax is going to make you break out. Epilators also grab hair much closer to the skin level than wax can, so you can actually spend more of your time smooth! I always HATED waiting for my hair to be long enough that I could wax again! Also, between waxing and epilating, the cost difference is a no-brainer: At one of the spots here in Dallas that I think is clean, well-priced, professional, etc., it would cost me over $160 to get my legs, arms, underarms, bikini area, and upper lip waxed. That's more than double what the Emagine cost me! And I never need an appointment to epilate!<br /><br />A word of advice, though: Don't use an epilator for the first time if you have somewhere you need to be! Even after years of doing it, I get bright red dots on the areas that I epilate and they usually last for 2-3 hours. I don't know if this is a common reaction or more obvious on my skin because I'm downright pale, but I certainly wouldn't say that I have sensitive skin.<br /><br />I really couldn't be happier with this product!

The head is somewhat narrow compared to the other one, but the power behind it is nice.. it rarely bogs down unless you are pressing entirely to hard against the skin. There were a couple times I got my finger nipped by the middle part and it stung a bit but wasn't really painful. Overall a great quality product.
  240. I tried this product two days in a row, following the instructions, but was left with stubble. I went to try again the third day only to find that it wouldn't even turn on. There was no power. I'm returning it for a refund.
  241. awful service. awful price
  242. First use will be painful. You're pulling hair from the root...what do you expect? After repeat use your hair will return finer. I always use the Emjoi immediately after shower as pores are open. As with shaving you should exfoliate. Successful for upper lip, chin, underarm, bikini line, legs...NOT eyebrows. Eyebrows require precision. It may appear at a higher price point although consider how much time and $ you're saving by doing it at home. Additional bonus is you can do a touch up at any time rather than making an emergency appointment at your waxing salon. enjoy!
  243. This is my first and only epilator. When I first turned it on, the sound was a lot more frightening than I expected it to be. Since it's my first one, I don't know if it's any louder or quieter than other brands, but there is definitely a loud sound.<br /><br />It's easy to use, there are only 2 speed settings and an off switch. Cleaning it out is easy; I just use the brush provided and sweep through it after each use. It's corded (a very very long cord), and has a plastic cover that I can never seem to keep track of.<br /><br />I go over my legs several times to be sure as much hair has been removed, and it takes 10 minutes tops to finish with both legs.
