  245. I bought this product after seeing some youtube reviews on epilators. This particular one received the best reviews and so I decided to purchase it after some major contemplation (considering the price and the fear that it would hurt too much). I tried this the day I got it and I will say...it hurt. I wont say though that it hurts more than waxing. It's a pinching pain that you get used to eventually. I have used this all over my body. As for underarms...it's quite easy...if you stretch the area you only have to swipe twice to be done one side. Arms are the least painful. As for my legs, because I'm skinny, I think it hurts more on my lower legs than thighs. I'm not too hairy but this has definiely lessened the darkness on my underarms and I usually do not need to epilate more than twice a month. Great product, I would recommend to all my friends. In fact, my sister bought one after using mine!

  252. I ordered this from amazon after reading the reviews and deciding that I need to try something new from shaving everyday for keeping my body hairless and smooth. I am very hairy with thick black hair especially on my legs. This works 90% of the time for me. It does not \\"pluck\\" hair out 100% of the time, more like 80-90%. The skin is not as smooth as it would be if you were waxing your body, but it is much easier to use and way less messy. I have to use it at least couple of times a week to keep my arms and legs hairless. It take about 15-20 mins every time I use it. I have used it on my legs, hands and underarms. It is not as painful as I expected it to be and you get used to the sensation after couple of uses. But I was familiar with waxing and threading before I started epilating. I do make sure that I have a hot shower and exfoilate before I epilate. So far - so good. I would recommend the product to a friend.

  255. I just got this epilator and have only used it once. I still feel a few prickly hairs, but that is to be expected. You cannot expect it to get them all on the first use.   256. Like the headline says, this epilator works well up until the cheapo plastic drive gears on either the epilator head, or the epilator itself wear out due to regular use.<br /><br />These would be much better suited to have at least brass gearing to stand up to dude hairs with regular use (weekly to monthly in my case).<br /><br />For reference, I have both owned and worn out 3 of these. The most recent was purchased on Nov 17, 2014, which equates to approximately less than 3 months of regular use before they have crapped out on me.<br /><br />Cheaper than waxing? For sure.<br /><br />Worth the money for the lifetime I have experienced? Not really.<br /><br />That being said, I would gladly pay an extra $5-10 dollars for Emjoi to get their act together and use quality materials for the gearing on the heads/body of this epilator.   261. Works better than waxing and cuts down time. Yes removing hair is painful. However, after it's been pulled once, the pain level lowers because the hair follicle gets use to it, and comes back slower. I would not recommend for the face unless you are a man. The product is a little hard to get in the creases (not including underarms), but other than that I will not be returning this one. You can use this epilator any time of the day, as many times in a day you want, and you do not have to &#34;wait&#34; in more ways than one, like wax, and clean up is easy. Helps lower or stop the pain you get from shaving and does not remove skin like wax does. Also, exfoliating with a sugar scrub will help with ingrown hairs.
  262. The Emagine is a great epilator-I'm impressed with how thorough it is. But it does have a few draw-backs. First, you really need to us it every day for the first few weeks in order to get maximum results. It's really tough to do anything else while you use it,so that's time that has to be dedicated to that specific purpose. Second, no matter how often you epilate, it's very tough to get smooth enough to pass the touch test. I've noticed that it is particularly difficult to get smooth results over boney or prominent areas like shins and knees. On the other hand, it's truly fabulous on slower-growth areas like the bikini line. The third draw-back is how noisy it is. The manual recommends using the Emagine at night to give any redness a chance to fade. But I have 7 children who are trying to SLEEP at night, so I have to hide in a far corner of the house so as not to keep them up. Still, I am very happy with this purchase. Consider it an investment. Much easier and cheaper than waxing,and you save money on disposable razor costs.
  263. ... and this one takes the cake! Absolutely amazing. And compared to others, this one is practically pain-free. I could feel the difference in the results between this and the single row of tweezers models. Powerful and quick. One pass accomplishes what it took several to do with every other epilator I have tried.   264. Let me just start off by getting to the facts about MY experience with this epilator. It's just like any other epilator meaning you have to keep going over areas because it doesn't remove the ingrown hair, or the fine hair within one stroke like it states. The settings is either too fast or too slow when it comes to removing the fine hairs. I used this 3 times within two weeks because I hate to admit I'm a pretty hairy person. That should tell you your hair will grow back within a few days. Not 4-6 weeks. If you have a lot of testosterone and your hair grows fast like mine I would say you will be hair free for 2-3 days max! I used this last Friday and I have little hair spikes throughout my legs already. The Emjoi post epilation cream doesn't work either, otherwise I wouldn't have had to use this 3 times within two weeks. The other irritating thing is once you think you're done removing your hair, you go back and find some stragglies that you know you ran the epilator over but can't figure out how you manage to miss that certain area thus causing you to have to go over the same spot again. Now the good thing about this is that when I started on one leg at 8:23 p.m., I was done with both legs probably before 8:56 p.m.. I cleaned up my mess and forgot I was timing my hair removal and remembered to look at the clock at 8:56. The reason I timed this was because my old epilator took me about 48 minutes to an hour to remove hair from both my legs. That's very time consuming to me. I say this OK because it is fast but there's nothing special that this does that my other epilator don't.
  265. I wish I had heard of these like 15 years ago! I felt like a body hair expert (because, for a female, I have dark, coarse body hair and shaving leaves stubble and ingrown hairs, waxing is alright but expensive and obnoxious to have to go get it done all the time and/or it hurts and sucks to do it yourself. I have gotten some laser hair removal but its so expensive! I'm probably going to get the tria (at home laser hair remover) but I got this in the meantime until I save up for the tria.<br /><br />It works great! Now, it is painful as hell sometimes. I have a decently high tolerance to pain and yet sometimes I'm like gritting my teeth trying to just hurry and get through it. It's basically tweezing a million hairs at once so you can imagine the pain of tweezing a hair somewhere sensitive but times a million. That's my warning, is that it can and usually is painful. BUT, I've noticed it gets less painful each time. Also, I always take advil or some type of pain reliever before doing it. It helps some. (Probably not good to do this but I also did it while slightly intoxicated once too and it was still painful but not bad since I was too buzzed to really care haha). First time is a killer. Especially in some areas... for me, the tops of my thighs, the bottom (or underside) of the top of my calves (like right below the back of the knee), etc. Oh, I also recently started doing my underarms with it too which is awesome to finally see them look nice and practically hairless but that is PAIN! I mean I would have bitten down on a belt strap if it had been nearby. haha. I think its because my legs are at least used to past torturous methods like waxing and hair creams, etc but my underarms have ONLY been shaven. They actually bled a bit but I just showered right after and put on a soft dove deodorant and all was well. There are also numbing creams or sprays you can buy too but I haven't tried any yet.<br /><br />Aside from the pain issue, its amazing. I use it pretty much everywhere. Arms, legs, underarms, bikini area, even my lower back and happy trail. Oh and sometimes the back of my neck. (I'm not THAT hairy, I just don't like hair and mine is a bit darker so I feel better without it. -And I have a weird hairline on the back of my neck). Sometimes the first few times I got little bumps. Maybe irritation or something but it went away. Oh, I've also used it on my face because I have little whiskers on my chin I always tweeze and because I have peach fuzz on the sideburn area. It worked great for that as well and really does get all the littlest hairs whether separate random hairs or tiny peach fuzz. Sometimes you want to go over the area again and again until you see or feel its all gone. I mix up going up and down where the hair is and then will go around in circles (which is usually what works best). I thought at first that you would go against the hair slowly but it actually works best (in my opinion) to go somewhat fast in circular motions over the hair you want to get. Like on my legs I'll usually go over them first from down to up in strips as if I was shaving and then I'll go over numerous times in circular motions. Just hold it to your skin close but not pushing and its pretty easy to follow the directions and all so just hold it to where the button is closest to your skin. As in it is supposed to be held a certain way to go against the hair follicles a certain way but not really anything different than how you would shave or wax, etc. There are videos on how to use it and to watch people use it which I felt helped to see because it shows you the pace and circular motions, etc. Otherwise I wouldn't have probably known that and just went up and down. Anyways, there's a lot of different epilators out there but I did research and chose this one because I liked that it had the most tweezer things. (72 I think?) I was wondering if it really would do what it says and would get hairs that are like .05 cm or whatever the ad says. Well, for the most part it does! Sometimes you have to go over and over or push a little or whatever but for the most part it gets everything.<br /><br />One downfall, since hair grows in waves or phases (I think thats the more technical term or what the laser hair removal technicians call it) but you can use this epilator and get all your hair but days later have a tiny bit of stubble. It's mostly probably hair that was in the &#34;just budding&#34; phase (anagen phase?). Anyways, for me I was a little disappointed at first thinking I'd still have to shave along with doing the epilator. I did maybe the first week or 2 and haven't needed to since. I think that the more you keep up with epilating your (talking about legs here) hair, the less it grows back and honestly I sometimes don't even remember the last time I've used a shaver on my legs at all! My bikini line is immaculate and I've never had that before. I was a swimmer in high school and always felt embarrassed for having razor burn around my bikini line and also never felt like I could show my legs unless I had shaven that day. Now, I can and will put on shorts or walk around the house (with boyfriend) in underwear or wear leggings and can pull them up without worrying because they are always hairless and even if they need to be done again its only sparse hairs here and there. It's an amazing feeling for someone like me who thought that until I spend a fortune and years on laser hair removal treatments that I was just a hairy girl that always hid my body with clothes and spent too much money and time on grooming and different things that never REALLY did enough to give me the confidence of smooth legs or no stubble or razor burn, etc.<br /><br />I'm rambling but I wanted to say that this is an amazing product and that it works and that yes, it has cons like the pain, but, it pays for itself in like 1-2 uses compared to paying for waxing, it hurts about the same as waxing (it's just more constant as you're going on and on around and around rather than just the initial burn from each wax strip being pulled off) and it can be helped with advil, numbing creams/gels/sprays, etc, booze and narcotics (no I'm kidding). It's worth it and the only last thing I'll say is to clean it out and sort of like use the little white bristle brush thing after every few good rounds with it to get any hair out of the tweezing area. It comes out during use but it works best if you keep stopping here and there and just clean it out a bit sometimes. Do this somewhere you can either vacuum or sweep or on a towel because the hairs all fall and shoot out and they get all over the floor and such.<br /><br />Alright, thats it for my novel. Good luck and I hope that was useful to anyone. I am really glad that I purchased it for myself.

It has A LOT of heads, which makes it work faster, and as I said, it doesn't hurt. This is much better than the other model, but still can take a couple of passes to pick up all the hair (hence the 4, not 5 star review). If you haven't epilated before, I highly recommend it. I used to have thick stiff stuble on parts of my legs when I shaved, and had to shave a couple times a week. Now I epilate about once a week and the sparse hair that comes in at all is soft and fair - very hard to see even when it gets longish. It takes a little getting used to, and still leaves little red pin prick type marks, but those go away quickly. I much prefer this to shaving. I've also used this on my underarms (not too painful if I epilate weekly) and my upper lip (ouch), but it works so well. Be careful in areas with more \\"soft tissue\\" - if the skin isn't relatively taught it could pinch - so be smart about where you use it.

  288. I've been epilating for years now and started with a really simple Philips which did the trick until it recently broke. While researching my next model, I found most epilator reviews ridiculous and unhelpful! Basing a product review on \\"it hurts\\" is quite silly, as the whole point of the product is to rip hair out of your body - which frankly is not a marvelous experience no matter how hard core you are. Plus everyone's pain threshold is completely different, so please don't ever base your purchase on that sort of feedback.<br /><br />I made my decision to go with the Emjoi based on a few simple reasons: 72 tweezers have a better chance of a quick efficient process than 20 or 40, for a 72 tweezer-head epilator the Emjoi is well priced, and the product itself has a very robust design that appeals to me. After a really quick delivery I have been using the product now for about 5 weeks and am really happy with it. It is substantially faster to do my full legs in comparison to my old Philips which is a huge plus. Time is precious and I would rather not spend hours doing my legs if it can be avoided. Aside from that I am not going to evaluate the \\"pain\\" issue, but one quick tip: every epilator will hurt more if you leave your hairs grow long. If you epilate regularly the hairs will be much finer and extract without much ado after a hot shower.<br /><br />Overall: I am delighted with the Emjoi and would highly recommend it!

Would really like to try the \\"no no\\" system next. Happy hunting!

There is also a safety feature of automatic shutoff if you push too hard on your skin to prevent injury. Great with more sensitive regions of the body that require more gentle removal of unwanted hair. The only downside is the corded operation, I would prefer cordless and don't know how I missed that one detail, however, the AC cord provided for power supply is quite lengthy and does not interfere much.

  297. 3/12/14 update: **Originally 5/5 stars, now 1/5**<br /><br />I basically did not use it after that summer. This was way too time consuming and painful. I think waxing is less painful and more efficient, but it comes with a learning curve. I feel like this rips out hair instead of pulling it. This has been sitting in the back of my drawer for the last 3 years. Waxing is not perfect but it wins for now...<br /><br />------------<br /><br />Below is my original review from June 2010:<br /><br />This device is only for people who have serious issues with body hair. (I am one of these people.) Think about it - Who in their right mind would subject themselves to something like this? If body hair bothers you enough that you will inflict considerable, repetitive (though short lived) pain upon yourself, then yes, this product does work.<br /><br />My favorite thing about this is that it absolutely gets the hair by the roots! I just did my underarms for the first time and there is NO HAIR THERE! Not a single \\"black dot\\" can be seen. That alone makes this worth it to me. They are a little red and tender, but I am sure it will heal overnight.<br /><br />There is a learning curve. It sounds simple enough to hold it as instructed my Emjoi, but there is a technique to it, and you naturally get better the more you use it. I have started moving it in all different directions (left/right, up/down, circles) in short motions and it works great. I have been doing my lower legs every few days for almost a month and my last epilation was by far the best! I feel like I got ALL except for the extremely smallest of hairs this time. Keep in mind that hair grows in cycles. So when you have hair 2 days after you epilate, it's not the same hair growing back. It's DIFFERENT hair, that wasn't there when you epilated.<br /><br />When I first used it on my legs, I was not satisfied at all and questioned my purchase. Now that I have been consistent and patient, I have no doubts! I have a lot of \\"bald\\" patches and my legs simply LOOK 50x smoother because the roots are gone. If I wanted them to pass the \\"touch test\\" I would still have to shave, but they look great.<br /><br />A few tips from my experience:<br /><br />1.) The first swipe is the worst. If it's your first time epilating, I would recommend \\"tapping\\" that area with the epilator instead of \\"sweeping\\" it in a smooth motion. After you have tapped an area about 3-5 times, the \\"sweep\\" is infinitely more tolerable.<br /><br />2.) After epilating, I use a cotton ball + witch hazel and then apply a triple antibiotic ointment. This prevents infection and red bumps. To prevent ingrown hairs, I exfoliate daily in the shower using some rough gloves. After I get out, I use the towel to rub away any dead skin. If I see any ingrown hairs, I sometimes use a pumice stone. UPDATE: Be careful about this! Early on, I was exfoliating too harshly and it left my skin looking red and bumpy. Be sure to give your skin a break to heal. It will look and feel a lot smoother. To moisturize, I use olive oil - no fancy fragrances/ingredients that can cause irritation to the inflamed skin.<br /><br />3.) Give it time. Don't expect to do all of your body in one day. Do small areas at a time. Don't try to be 100% thorough the first time. Just do a little bit each day.<br /><br />P.S. A.) It is extremely loud. B.) The cord doesn't bother me at all.
  298. This epilator was quick at removing hairs and completely painless, but unfortunately it did not remove the hair roots. I have had a Braun epilator for years that is painful, but does a great job at ripping out the hair roots. If you want an epilator that actually removes the entire hair root, do not buy this one!

  301. I have used epilators for as long as they were available. Since EpiLady.<br />Before buying this one, I used Norelco Satinelle for maybe 18 years. I have fine sparse hair and am used to this technique of removal.<br /><br />This Emjoi is hands down the best ever. It is fast so it is not as painful. Pain is a subjective thing that depends on length of use, and thickness and coarseness of hair. If you are prone to ingrown hairs this method may not be the best for you. With each epilation, hair roots seem to get less sensitive so it gets easier to use. I can get by on two uses a month; your mileage may vary.<br /><br />I like the cord. It has the power you need to do the job. Battery run ones are too weak and slow, it requires many passes to get anything done, and the batteries constantly run out.<br /><br />It is the only epilator I have used on my face that does not hurt a lot, especially in the sensitive area above the lip. Highly recommended for people familiar with this type of hair removal.
  302. Wasn't sure about this item but it is much better than most for it's purpose.
  303. The first epilator I purchased was a Braun Silk-epil 7 for $120.00 vs $80 for the Emojoi brand. The Braun worked great, as my first epilator I was excited to skip shaving for a couple weeks, vs having to shave every day. It had 40 built in tweezers, two different speeds and was cordless in operation. After about a year, I had to replace it, and decided on the Emojoi.<br /><br />Speed:<br /><br />Both the Braun and the Emojoi came with two speeds. Compared to the Emojoi the Braun might as well have been slow and slower. It would take me at least an hour to do both my legs with the Braun, that time is cut in half by the Emojoi. This was also probably helped by the fact the Braun has 40 tweezers vs Emojoi's 70.<br /><br />Performance:<br /><br />Using epilators for awhile now, I know epilators do not remove every single hair. I'd say maybe 5% of the hair is broken or missed when epilating and I've come to accept this. Sometimes you have to go over it again, or wait a day or two for it to grow before epilating again. With consistent use, this gets better. I'd say the Braun and the Emojoi are about the same in this regard.<br /><br />As an added note, occasionally I had a problem with the Braun where it would grab onto my skin with the tweezers. It was incredibly painful and would leave red marks/tiny scratches on my skin. I have never had this problem with the Emojoi (thank goodness!).<br /><br />Cord vs Cordless:<br /><br />I may be different from others, but my favorite thing about the Emojoi is that it is corded. Why? No internal battery to deal with! The Braun worked great at first but after a few months the battery would die in about 15-20 minutes - which did not work if it took an hour to do my legs. What's worse, it would take two hours to charge. So that is over three hours dedicated to epilating and trust me, it got old fast. I hated epilating, it became such a chore I just shaved most the time. Dealing with a cord (which is conveniently very long) is way better than worrying about a dwindling battery life and a two hour charge time.<br /><br />One downside is the Emojoi corded unit cannot be used in the bath or shower. I rarely used my Braun in the shower. I did not find it any less painful or more effective, and it was just easier for me to epilate outside of the bath. So the lack of this feature in the Emojoi does not bother me, but might be important to others.<br /><br />Accessories:<br /><br />The Braun epilator came with a wide variety of different caps / attachments including one with a razors to shave any left over hair. All of which I never ended up using. I'm not sure if I am alone on this, but the attachments seemed pretty pointless so I considered them a waste of money. The normal cap worked just fine for my legs and armpits, though I never used the epilator on my face.<br /><br />Emojoi only came with the cord and a cleaning brush, but considering I never once used the other attachments provided from Braun, Emojoi wins this catagory as well - less is sometimes more.<br /><br />Comfort:<br /><br />Emojoi claims to be 'gentle' and if you've ever epilated, you know there is nothing gentle or comfortable about ripping your hair out at the root. However, I did find the Emojoi considerably less painful than the Braun.<br /><br />Smartlight:<br /><br />The Braun comes with a built in smartlight which was actually very helpful in spotting short or very light, thin hairs. This is a great feature that the Emojoi lacks. It might seem silly, but you'd be surprised how helpful it is!<br /><br />Overall, compared to the Braun, the Emojoi AP-18 wins. It is faster, overall less painful, and more efficient with a corded operation.

  309. I'm going to come back after 6 months to a year to give an update., but so far I'm pleased with this epilator. My 10+ years old Emoji epilator, which I hadn't treated too well, like the cleaning instructions said, lasted a long time, but eventually the epilator gears were too stressed to properly come together (I can still use the shaving attachment on that ancient thing, so its still of benefit). I did a lot of research before deciding to stay with Emoji, and particularly this model. My cost/benefit analysis saw this as the best option. Sure, it might not catch fine hairs, which a razor can catch and &#34;smooth&#34; things out; however, it will get the thick, noticible hairs and a good amount of fine ones if the skin is properly exfoliated, and the product will continue to get the fine hairs if the head is cleaned as the instructions say. And its just like mowing a tall grass lawn: don't do it while its wet and don't move the device fast, or you'll miss some hairs and burn out the engine. I never want permanent hair removal because it reduces skin firmness, but I do have neurological issues that cause muscle spasms and the only scars I get are keloids, so this device works great for me and the with the updated gear design in this device, I know its going to last for years to come.

  326. I was excited, though nervous, to try the Emjoi Emagine (AP-18 Dual Opposed 72 Tweezer Head Epliator) because the hair on my legs grows fairly quickly, meaning that the results of shaving don't last very long. As a reference, I shave every other day and don't wear anything that will expose my legs on the off day because my hair is already noticeable. So, after reading reviews, I purchased this epilator. Not knowing how long the hairs had to be (ok, .4mm, but seriously, who can measure that?), I waited for over 48 hours before trying it the first time. I then, due to very limited success, tried again the next day (greater than 72 hours at that point). Below are my thoughts on various categories:<br /><br />Pain: This is what was most concerning to me. I have to say, this is the one area where I was pleasantly surprised. Do you feel it? Yes. Is it unbearable, even the first time? No, not to me. Sometimes I'd be targeting a specific hair (more on that later) and, after a pass, be thinking that it hadn't worked because I didn't feel anything, only to be surprised that it was gone. Sometimes, though, I specifically could feel that I had gotten it. The sensation is a little like a light electric zap, not really like a pinch. After using it, my legs felt tingly for about an hour. Not really painful, just noticeable and unusual. As a side note, I did use it on my underarms and that was more painful and I'm not sure I actually got any hair. To be fair, the hair there was much shorter, having been shaved the day before, but I suspect I was mostly experiencing skin pinching not hair removal.<br /><br />Ability to remove hair: Not so good. I tried many different approaches - with the growth (as the guide says), against the growth. Long passes, short passes. Quick passes, slow passes. No pressure, light pressure. The thing that seemed to work best was light pressure, slow, short passes. Direction seemed hair dependent - sometimes I'd have no success for several passes going in the growth direction, then I'd go against the growth and get it the first time. Other times it'd be the exact opposite. After about 15 minutes I began targeting the hairs I could see, specifically. Contorting my leg in various ways to get the light to hit it just right to see a patch of hair, then going over and over and over it. Eventually, in the end, I don't think there was a single targeted hair that I ever gave up on, but some took several (i.e. more than 10) passes. For hair I couldn't see (light in color or very fine) I didn't stand a chance. I gave up after about 30 minutes and went and shaved my legs.<br /><br />Look of legs after use: Not so good. The epilator, on both uses, left red bumps on my legs, similar to the kind you get with razor burn or heat rash. These bumps were everywhere I had pulled hair from which, though not a lot, was still not a pleasant sight. The bumps seem to go away in about half a day, but I would not have been able to wear shorts either day after use without the bumps being highly visible.<br /><br />Overall: I'm returning it. I could see how this might be useful to minimize the amount of shaving you'd have to do on a vacation, but it wouldn't eliminate it. You'd still have to shave at the same interval, there'd just be less hair to remove. I would say this certainly wasn't worth the time, pain, or effort. I was prepared to be in pain to look good and save shaving time, but in the end I got less pain than expected, but also fewer results. This is the first epilator I've ever used, so I can't say that this is a bad product when compared to others, but compared to expectations, this falls way short.veral passes going in the growth direction, then I'd go against the growth and get it the first time. Other times it'd be the exact opposite. After about 15 minutes I began targeting the hairs I could see, specifically. Contorting my leg in various ways to get the light to hit it just right to see a patch of hair, then going over and over and over it. Eventually, in the end, I don't think there was a single targeted hair that I ever gave up on, but some took several (i.e. more than 10) passes. For hair I couldn't see (light in color or very fine) I didn't stand a chance. I gave up after about 30 minutes and went and shaved my legs.<br /><br />Look of legs after use: Not so good. The epilator, on both uses, left red bumps on my legs, similar to the kind you get with razor burn or heat rash. These bumps were everywhere I had pulled hair from which, though not a lot, was still not a pleasant sight. The bumps seem to go away in about half a day, but I would not have been able to wear shorts either day after use without the bumps being highly visible.<br /><br />Overall: I'm returning it. I could see how this might be useful to minimize the amount of shaving you'd have to do on a vacation, but it wouldn't eliminate it. You'd still have to shave at the same interval, there'd just be less hair to remove. I would say this certainly wasn't worth the time, pain, or effort. I was prepared to be in pain to look good and save shaving time, but in the end I got less pain than expected, but also fewer results. This is the first epilator I've ever used, so I can't say that this is a bad product when compared to others, but compared to expectations, this falls way short.
  327. I bought this epilator after much research and review-reading, hoping that it would be the perfect replacement for my older epilator (used regularly for 3 years) that wasn't as effective as it had once been. My first thought upon using this was, \\"Wow, this really DOESN'T hurt as much as my old epilator!\\" And then my second thought was, \\"Aw, man, it's not getting even half of everything.\\" I mean, I'm no epilating newbie: I expect it to be at least a little painful. Pain free (or less painful) without efficacy does not cut it for me.<br /><br />For an epilator that is touted to get more hairs in fewer passes, it just didn't fit the bill. It took me just as long to epilate as with my old one (Braun SE 5 series.) Also, it didn't get my soft, fine, blond hairs that tend to lie flat against the skin. So basically, it really worked about as well as a 3 year-old less expensive appliance.<br /><br />Furthermore, if you look at the way the head is designed, it obviously can't get right next to your skin because of the way the head is built up around the tweezer wheels, and the wheels themselves are almost concave, so if your legs/underarms/what have you aren't curved in the same degree that the heads are, you're gonna be sitting there for a while. It also kind of grossed me out that there's no way to really clean the tweezer heads. Combined with the lack of an LED light (which I was really used to in my old appliance and depended on), the significant learning curve of the current angle to which you need to direct it to your skin, and the reduced efficacy, I returned this item and purchased a different one.<br /><br />Obviously many people love this epilator, and I love that it's corded (doesn't lose steam, as it were) and the pulls really are MUCH less painful, but I just couldn't justify keeping it. So maybe this isn't a good choice epi for natural blondies.
  328. I use this item on my arms and upper lip. It is faster than using tweezers and easier than using wax strips. Really great machine.
  329. I've used Emjoi products for years and have always been happy. This is a new and improved model. Seems to work great.
  330. I was so excited to receive this Emjoi 72-Tweezer Head Epilator because I LOVE the Emjoi EpiSlim so much for my upper lip and underarms.<br />Unfortunately, it's been a huge disappointment and waste of money. It barely captures any hair on my legs (I have to try it at different angles and go over the same area at least four times before it will capture the most obvious hairs) and the \\"comb\\" in the middle is pointless--It does nothing.<br /><br />It does work decently on my bikini line, but I could just use my EpiSlim there, so that's not much of a saving grace.<br /><br />I really hoped to give this a high rating, but I just can't do it.
  331. I have been using several kinds of epilators and this one is by far the best one! I used to have a cordless dry/wet Panasonic and a Braun Silk Epil - both good machines but none nearly as fast as this one. Definitely beats the heck out of cordless epilators in terms of power. That being said, if you are a newbie in epilating this Emjoi maybe a little overwhelming because it is REALLY powerful and I would imagine it would hurt if you have been shaving before. My advise would be to get professionally waxed first and then epilate as hairs regrow, it would hurt way less than if you just do it after having shaved for years. If it hurts a bit (and it will) just take it and keep epilating, I promise it will stop hurting after a few times and you wouldn't have to ruin your skin shaving every other day!
  332. I purchased this epilator primarily to remove the hair fuzz on my face. I really love this product. You won't be sorry if you make the investment.
  333. I've owned two of these in the past 2 years. In general terms, I like this epilator more than any other I've tried in the past, and I've tried many. The two rolls of tweezers work to remove hair faster and it misses less hairs than other devices, though it still misses quite a few. My main problem with this epilator is that after a year or so of use (I use it once a month during cold weather, and probably once a week or every other week during the summer time) the gears in the rollers break and the thing gets stuck and stops working. This has happened twice already and I'm on the fence on whether I want to spend another $80 in a product that I KNOW will BREAK again in a year. I wish they sold the attachment on its own, but I haven't been able to find it.
  334. DO NOT BUY THIS!!!!! I went over all the amazon reviews for multiple epilators and chose this one. Big Mistake! It gave me so many ingrowns and I didn't even realize it until it was too late (1-2 months after first use). My hairs are growing in multiple directions including inwards. I've popped ingrowns that released 3 inch long hairs. You can see dark spots where it's jammed in and even lines across my leg where the hair is high enough to see but deep enough that I'd bleed if I tried to pick it out. I went to a dermatologist and they told me the only way to stop it is to do laser hair removal and then have multiple incision operations to get the rest out. This may not happen to you but I thought that same thing about the bad reviews I saw myself. IT'S NOT WORTH THE RISK!!! I think part of the problem is that the blades go in two different directions, but I still wouldn't recommend trying others.

I do miss the little light on that one,with this one you don't need to look.The emjoi is getting all of the hairs so no need to keep looking. However with the Braun 7 I would have to go over and over to get all the hairs.<br /><br />This Emjoi is amazing. It did not hurt it was weird. It was almost as simple as shaving, just a little longer. I was done in no time. Usually I have to spend hours on a saturday or sunday. It just came tonight and I though well I will just try it and see how it works. It was so easy , I just kept going and was finished with both, legs armpits in 30-to 45 minutes.My back would actually hurt from doing it to long with my old one. I can't seem to do around my mouth very easily with the Emjoi like I could with the Braun ,maybe I am just chicken I will try again another time.<br /><br />The price of this is way better than the Braun plus I had the extra expense of the other attachment with the other one.   336. The Emjoi AP-18 Emagine Dual Opposed 72 Tweezer Head Epilator is quite simply the best epilator I have ever used. It's easy to use, has plenty of power in its two power settings, and the 72 tweezer heads significantly reduce the amount of time epilating takes. Other epilators could take me an hour to do my legs, since I would have to go over the same area repeatedly to get all of the hairs. With 72 tweezer heads and plenty of power, I think the Emjoi AP-18 takes under 10 minutes to do both legs. It's not very noisy to operate, and if you're used to epilating, the hair removal isn't painful. If you aren't used to epilating, any epilator will be painful for the first several uses. Even cleaning out this epilator is easy. The only thing I would change about this epilator would be making it cordless. Then again, they may not be able to keep the power level consistent enough while running on battery power, which may be the reason it's operable only while plugged in to an outlet. The Emjoi AP-18 is pricier than many of the other epilators on the market, but the superior performance makes it well worth the price. I wouldn't trade mine for anything!
  337. I bought the Emjoi AP 18 because it was time for me to either wax or shave my legs. I read about a lot of other elipilators and how long it took to use them and the varying results. I am still in awe with how well it works. It does sting a bit but if you pull the skin taut, it hurts significantly less. I have hairfree legs and have had no adverse reaction to it. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes silky smooth skin. Hand down, it is one of the best investments I have made. I wish I had bought it years ago. After 32 years, I will no longer be waxing or shaving. This is THE product for me.

I cannot recommend this product enough, especially to women who never shave, opting for wax/electrical epilator. It is fast, easy to clean, and although bigger than other epilators, it is the size of the tweezers that matters. They are perfectly conceived, so they'll solidly clip the hair and pull it so swiftly that you don't even notice it is gone. The size and position of tweezers allow for the hair never to break, leaving the skin smooth and silky. It works PAINFREE on my underarms too, so I can skip my weekly visit to wax my underarms. I never imagines that an electrical epilator can compete with the benefits of waxing, until I tried this Emjoi.

  356. This was the second or third epilator I've ever used, so I'm not new to these. After my last braun epil 7 locked up prematurely I went for this one because it had a cord and was supposed to be the fastest epilator around. So it is quite fast, and hurts a bit less than some of the other epilators I've used. However... the reason it hurts less is because this epilator doesn't make good contact with your skin and/or doesn't seem to grip the hairs as well as other ones I've used. I do have very course thick hair, which could be part of the issue, maybe this epilator is good for people with finer hair? Either way, the shape of the head on this epilator is really bad for getting at any part of your body other than your legs (and its really challenging to get your knees with it). Other epilators have some flexibility in how they make contact with your skin, but this one is just fixed and open faced, so even if there's more tweezers and it goes faster, you're going to lose time making passes over the same area because it hasn't made contact with your skin. Another annoying issue related to time is that because you're spending so much time going over the same places/taking so long in general, the epilator starts to heat up and burn your skin. It took me a while to figure out that was why epilating became more painful over time.<br /><br />Pros: corded, fast, somewhat less painful than other epilators<br />Cons: horrible unflexible head that wont make contact with your skin, heating up and burning you<br /><br />All in all, maybe this works better for people with lighter hair, but after using it for about 6 months, I'm buying a new braun epilator since they actually make contact with your skin.

It specifies on the packaging that you must use a proper power source. I know there are converters, but it is my understanding that those converters only change the voltage and not the wattage. For many of my appliances, that will not do. I'm not sure where this product falls, so it may or may not wind up on the &#34;don't take to Finland&#34; list. I'll have to research that.   385. I've been a fan of epilators ever since the 90s. I love that they can get the shortest of hairs, so I don't have to grow my hair out to have it waxed, and that I can remove hair from my entire body without having to go to a salon. I've been considering a dual head epilator since the emjoi optima came out, but could never convince myself to spend the extra money. I've shelved it since, but decided today to get it back out to try again.<br /><br />Since my legs weren't that bad, it didn't take long, but I still didn't feel it was working miraculously fast, and when I had removed as much hair as the epliator could, my legs still felt somewhat stubbly. That gave me the idea to compare it to my old epilator.<br /><br />I got the Philips back out. Started by running it over my legs. Yep, they felt smoother. Then I decided to time it. Since my legs were done, I decided to do my arms. To keep it fair, I used my dominant hand (left) to hold the Emjoi and my right hand for the Philips. It took the Emjoi five minutes to clear as much hair as possible my right arm. It took seven with the Philips on my left. However, again, my left arm was noticeably smoother than my right and the Philips' single row of tweezers felt more nimble going over bony areas. I ended up finishing off my right arm with the Philips.<br /><br />The only upside I found was that the Emjoi seemed less painful than the Philips. I could see using the Emjoi to start an area that had been neglected for a while. Still, as a daily epilator, the Philips, and the Braun before it, were both far superior, if a tiny bit slower.

  387. Hi, my name is Katy. I'm eighteen years old, and hopefully this review will help you decide whether this product is for you. :D<br /><br />Shaving over the years almost never gave me the smooth legs I wanted. After a few months or so of shaving, I got horrible red bumps all over my legs (that wouldn't go away), you know, razor bumps, and occasionally razor burn as well. No matter what I did - shaving cream, conditioner, brand new razors, etc., I just never got the results I wanted. Shaving wasn't for me.<br /><br />I recently discovered the epilator. After researching online looking for the best one, I decided to purchase this one, the Emjoi Emagine. I made sure I knew how to use it and was prepared for the pain that people talked about. Despite that, I was so excited and used it minutes after it arrived, I couldn't wait to have the smooth legs I had desired for so long!<br /><br />Well, to my dismay, the results were not what I was looking for. I could still feel the hair on my legs, it wasn't much better than shaving, and it hurt. It hurt a lot.<br /><br />Still, I didn't give up on epilating.<br /><br />And I'm soooo glad that I didn't!<br /><br />This epilator is likely to break hair instead of plucking it -- IF you use it incorrectly. I think there are a few reasons why I didn't instantly get the results I wanted. I had very dry skin. I sped through epilation. I used the higher speed right away even though my hair is very fine. Epilating irritated my skin at first. I didn't exfoliate.<br /><br />It definitely takes some practice, but at this point I am incredibly happy with how my legs feel and this epilator's performance.<br /><br />Here are some tips for those of you who are having problems:<br />- EXFOLIATE. This is one of the most important steps. If you don't exfoliate often enough, your skin is going to be harder to epilate. Exfoliating also helps to maintain smooth skin when there isn't hair.<br />- Buy a moisturizing body wash, moisturizing bath salts,etc. Use them when you exfoliate, especially if you have dry skin. This did wonders for me. (I have Walgreens bath beads with Vitamin E and mineral oil, it's really cheap and I love it!)<br />- GO SLOWLY. This might be the most important thing. I recommend starting on the lower speed, even though it may be more painful, you will get better results. I find the best technique is to go in slow, tiny circles in the direction the hair grows.<br />- Be thorough. You may think you're done, but if you can feel hair, it's there.<br />- Don't do it too often! The hair does have to grow a bit so the epilator can grab it. Don't worry - you probably won't even see the hair once it's long enough. Every few days or once a week per area is plenty.<br />- Stick with it! It's not instantaneous, but I'm confident that if you dedicate yourself and are determined, you will eventually get great results. :)<br /><br />I hope this helped you, I know this product is expensive and lots of people depend on these reviews when deciding whether to purchase things or not. Good luck!
  388. Doesn't get all the hairs and takes multiple passes; however I used it on pretty short (shaved three days previous) hair that is blonde and fairly thin/fine! I like it cause I can use it while a watch a show and not worry about nicking myself and also save on my water bill since when I shave I do it in the shower with the water running! Another slight problem is it doesn't get the hairs on my knee cap, but even regular shaving does not do really great job on that area for me... not sure why!<br /><br />I'm pretty pleased overall and I can already see it getting better with time.<br /><br />I didn't feel much discomfort, but I have fine hair like said before and exfoliate very often :)

I finally switched to the Emjoi epilator in October 2011 and couldn't be happier with it. I love the fact that it has two rotating heads - it gets the job done so much faster! I still have to go over some areas more than once, but I've had much better results than I did with the Braun epilator. I also swear I have way less ingrown hairs than I used to have. I even use this thing on my husband's back (sometimes I find pleasure in torturing him, LOL) and I can get his entire back done in 20 to 30 minutes (vs a full hour with the Braun). Highly recommend!

I have had this epilator since the week of Christmas and so far I really like it. As it has been stated , it does hurt when you first use it but with frequent use , it gets better after time. i use this on my legs and pubic area. My legs are so so as i have a mixture of fine hair and coarse on my legs. i would rate this a 5 star if it would get the finer hair. however its amazing for thick coarse hair!!! i do wish i can clean the head of the emjoi a bit better. i have to brush it with the brush it came with and shake it a little bit after detaching the head. i use a q-tip with alcohol or witch hazel to clean the tweezer heads. I attempted my arm pit, but it was too tender for me, i will attempt it later on when i can figure out how to hold the skin taut for my arm pit LOL. I epilate the &#34;happy place&#34; as in the mound, bikini line area, the &#34; happy place curtains&#34; and all the way to the anus ( tmi, i know but it may help some one who likes a complete bare look ;-) ) . here are some tips i hope can help :-D<br />****first shave the area you will epilate or trim the hair down with some clippers some. if you shave wait a day or 2. if its too long it will hurt a whole lot more than needed.<br />*Take a shower bath or whatever you use to keep your self clean. i like to use a apricot scrub to exfoliate before i epilate.I LOVE THAT WORD..EPILATE LOL!!! .<br />*rinse and dry off really well. place a towel or something underneath you to catch the hairs. makes for easy clean up as well.<br />*depending on your &#34; happy place anatomy&#34; , figure out a way to hold the skin nice and taught. brace yourself ladies and gents, the pain will come but it is very brief.<br />*move the emjoi in fast circles. i change the direction of my circles in an area as pubic hair grows in different directions untill the area is smooth. work in small areas at a time. take a break if you have to. the first time epilating the pubic area will take a while, especially if its your first time. it took me almost 45 minutes to pretty much give my self the hollywood. ( i use to get waxes a while ago but stopped as it was expensive to maintain)<br />*have a flash light and mirror on hand too.<br />*after you are done, apply whatever kind of lotion or gel or whatever on it. My &#34;happy place&#34; looked like the skin of a raw chicken. just all bumpy form the hairs being pulled but it went away the next day. over the next few days i epilated the region again as hair grows at different rates. it hardly hurt, just a prick. the less hair the less it hurts. i kind of like how it feels lol. Takes me 3 to 5 minutes to touch up areas where the hair has grown . after the first week, it was a week before i noted i had hair growing back. i felt the prickly hair and i epilated again. i think im adicted to epilating, i love it. My ingrown hairs are gone down like 98% . Just keep exfoliating every few days . its to early for me to note if my pubic hair has gotten finer, i would need atleast 5 more months to notice.

Also, despite the two rotating heads, I have to try epilating in all directions to get the finnest or the random isolated hairs off.<br />The Emjoi Emagine misses a lot of hair, and when it doesn't, it doesn't always get it right, breaking the hair instead of pulling it out. I have to use my epilator every week instead of every other week now...<br />I don't see much difference between the 2 speeds provided.<br />Also, I didn't think I would, but I miss the light I had on the Silk Epil, which helps you see what you're doing.<br />Finally the last critic is that the bulky head makes it difficult to take care of curved areas such as knees or armpits.<br />The only good thing I found is that using the Emagine is relatively painless, which would be good for beginners. However, it is also reflective on the lack of efficiency, again, breaking the hair instead of pulling it out.<br /><br />All in all, if you are a beginner and have the time and patience to use the Emjoi, it might be a good machine for you. However, for about the same price I truly believe you can get a better epilator.<br /><br />Cons: lack of efficiency, breaks half of the hair instead of pulling it out, no light to help you see what you are doing, harder to clean than other epilators.<br />Pros: relatively painless.

As a waxing aficionado of having a professional set-up at home for 6 years I began to dread the once a month set-up and clean-up.<br />I was ecstatic and alarmed the first time I used the Emjoi AP-18 Epilator. Ecstatic because the little machine achieved similar results as waxing in a short amount of time with little set-up/ cleaning. Alarmed due to my first reaction of the tweezers on taut lower front calf skin as if I was being electrically shocked a billion times and I almost instinctually threw the little machine at a wall. It hurt. Over time, I learned to brace myself for the first 30 seconds on the first leg. Very different feeling from waxing oddly.<br />Over time I noticed I had to epilate more often than waxing due to the root of hair not being pulled out. That was okay. Every 3 weeks of 15 minutes is great!<br />After nine months of use, the little torture machine has begun to disfunction. After 11 months it's dead. The rollers of tweezers do not rotate- they lock up and jam. This is directly due to the tiny gear beginning to strip which transfers motion from the motor body of the little machine to the tweezer head rollers. Possible cause of the stripping? Maybe pushing the moving head too firmly to catch all those little leg hairs not removed like they would be waxing...<br />I don't mind the little leg fuzzes but I do mind this $77.69 machine dying in one year. It's beyond the return window too.<br />So, I'm pondering what to do with my hairy legs, I'm on Amazon shopping for the same epilator thinking that I could not press firmly this time, or I could try another epilator, or resume waxing (dread), or just shave again (lazy short term solution)...<br />Three stars b/c it worked well when it worked (5 stars) and -2 stars because it has proven not to be a well engineered little machine past nine months.<br />If you buy it, take care not to press firmly and brace yourself for that first 30 seconds. It's shocking!<br />UPDATE 1 year later:<br />I bought a Braun epilator 6 months ago and found it worked, but not as good as the Emjoi on my legs. It does out-manuever in bikini and underarm areas. So, I bought another Emjoi AP-18. I am so happy I did. It efficiently does a detailed job on my legs. I purchased the 2 year warranty from Square for $7 covering 100% malfunction if it dies in two years. Maybe if I do not press with it, the gears will not strip. Smooth leg wishes to you all!

Too bad it turned out to be a marketing gimmic. Firstly, this epilator is loud, even for an epilator. The thing will blare at you which is a tad annoying, but it's not a big deal. Where the product ultimately fails is that it is simply horrible at getting hairs. It takes way too many passes for something with 72 tweezers to grab hairs and even then, it does a poor job. One thing that I noticed was that was almost painless which really bothered me for good reason. Very often, the Emjoi does not even pull hair out from the root, but just shaves it off somewhere near the top. It leaves behind very visible hair follicles and is very prone to ingrown hairs. In short, it takes way too long to do anything and it does a terrible job on top of that. I'll certainly return this within the next two weeks; and will probably go for another Braun, but a corded model this time since their epilators seem to actually work well.

I was very excited to try this when I took it out of the box and I was not disappointed! I've always started at my ankles and worked my way up because it hurts the least there and a little more the further you get up your legs, and when I started at my ankle there was almost no pain. The pain on the rest of my leg was definitely less than what I had experienced with my old epilator, though I wouldn't say there was none and it took significantly less time to do them. I was very hopeful to try this on my underarms because it had always been way too rough for me and I have a high tolerance for pain, but it still hurt very badly and I even noticed some little drops of blood where hair had been pulled out on the spot that I tried. I haven't tried it on my face as I don't have much of a need for that. My only complaint is that it doesn't have a shaver attachment because my old one had one, as well as a plastic piece to put on the shaver that trimmed your hair to a shorter length that was still long enough for the epilator to easily grab it, but not too long that it pulled more than it needed to, and I think that was helpful.
  440. I have owned an epilator for a few years and have had good success with it until more recently when I started to get nasty red bumps on my legs every time I epilate. I thought maybe it was the epilator getting too old so I decided to try this one because of the reviews. It does work but seems to take many, many passes before all of the hair is removed and even then I am left with strays. Not sure if I am doing something wrong? It is definitely not as painful (can barely feel it, actually) as compared to my previous epilator but seems to pull fewer hairs for sure.   448. I've had a couple types of these. Yes, I use this on secret garden. The trick is to pull the skin taut, so it WON'T flap your skin around like pulling on the whiskers of a hound dogs mouth. If you try to use this on the back end near your back door, then good luck. It's too wide for me to try and tidy up that porch. Otherwise, this is BY FAR the quickest, easiest, way out of all hair removal I've had for my secret garden. I've seen what other reviews have said, and yeah it hurts. You're pulling hair out.   481. So I bought this epilator after having seen a review on it from a youtuber named Naptural85. I'm an African American woman and needed something to get rid of hair since shaving my curly hair constantly ended up with ingrowns and painful bumps. After hearing the review from her, as well as a few other bloggers and youtubers, I thought that I would give it a chance. With tax and shipping, this was around a $80 purchase and I'm not sure now if it was worth it.<br /><br />First things first, I like the packaging that it comes in. The box comes filled with everything from a brush to clean the device with to a full blown, down to the nitty-gritty manual. I did exactly what the directions instructed that I do:<br /><br />-I took a warm bath and exfoliated all areas that I was going to use the device on with a loofa<br />-Made sure all areas were dry and free of lotions, creams, powders, etc<br />-Turned it on, made sure the logo faced me, and began epilating in the direction the hair grew<br /><br />Now, what I heard from others was that it only took a few strokes for this device to get all of your hairs and leave you with smooth skin. I have no idea how many times I went over the same small patch of skin trying to make sure that all of the hair was removed only to find that IT WOULD NOT GET ALL OF THE HAIR. I was left with a scattering of stubble, irritated looking bumps decorating my underarms, and I could have just been panicking but I could have sworn that my underarms were darker afterwards.<br /><br />They are not smooth, they are bumpy. The hair is not gone. I was unhappy.<br /><br />Also, I followed the directions in the manual of how to take the device apart to clean it and that was fine, but in trying to put it back together, I accidentally put the silver ring that surrounds the tweezers on backwards and now it won't come off. Because it won't come off, I can not put the device back together and now I can not use it. I only just received this device today. I'm not blaming this on the device or company since it was MY FAULT that I put a piece back incorrectly, but I am saying that it would have been nice to have a bit of room for error since my $80 purchase is now obsolete because of one simple mistake.<br /><br />I can't say overall that this was a bad product (since I did not have much time to use it before it became unusable), but for being on the closer end of $100, I could have just stuck to using electric clippers and saved my money. I am giving this 2 stars because my hopes for this product have been severely dashed.<br /><br />~~~~~~~~~~~~<br /><br />Edit:<br /><br />I managed to get the silver ring off and put back on correctly. It was not easy by any means, I had to use a screwdriver. Still, I can use the device again and I noticed that after applying baby powder (which I recommend to anyone epilating) and waiting over night, the bumps were not as bad. I still had to go over my underarms again, but they did feel softer. I am hoping that it gets better the more often I do this and that the bumps were just a result of my sensitive skin not being used to be tweezed.<br /><br />All of this considered, I will change my rating to 4 stars since this does work wonderfully on my legs.
  482. I bought this mainly for my bikini line, but, I am using it also now for my legs, the first time hurts a little, but you get used to it quickly; and in my opinion it is much better than shaving every other day. I had the smaller one before, but this one is much quicker.

  492. -Entry below asterisks is my previous review- As I suspected a bit over a year ago, the sad undersized gearing ... smaller and narrower than those in our Phillips Satinelle or our Emjoi Erase which both still work, stripped awhile back rendering the unit unusable. Either increasing the width of the gears or improving materials would make this the best epilator we have used. It's a shame if they haven't since it was our favorite of 3 epilators and isn't cheap. We are debating whether to go ahead and buy it again every two years or try a higher-end Braun or Phillips in hope that it works as well and lasts 4-5 years. A problem that corded epilators face is the adapter cord tends to stress inside the plastic and break over time I really don't care for cordless batteries dying even sooner, so that option is ruled out I will affirm what many others have noted. Having a Phillips Satinelle in addition allows getting hairs the Emjoi misses, and vice-versa. ************************************************************************ This unit surprised me a bit in both plus and minus columns. A plus, the opposed tweezer heads do a good job of getting more done in one swipe, and have a rubber element that tries to lift flatter hairs for better removal. It does this quite well, though some smaller finer hairs seem to get missed. Truth be told, my old unit of another brand did no better in that regard, and didn't do as thorough job overall. Minus is my previous unit had a larger gear system which made me suspect the small, single gear on this Emjoi unit maynot hold up. So far it's doing fine. I will follow up if that changes in the future. I would at this point recommend this product.
  493. Earlier last year, I bought a [[ASIN:B0077PLNNE Braun SE7681 Silk-épil 7]]. Of course, it was painful since it was the first time I'd ever used an epilator, but I kept with it. Over time, the pain was easier to withstand, but some places still hurt.<br /><br />I've been using the Braun every week or two since then, but the downside is that it's battery-operated only (the cord is for charging, only). Since I'm a guy and have a tad more hair than the ladies (although, it's much thinner and more sparse since I've been epilating), it takes a little while longer for me to do the job (and I've got to do my thighs, chest, torso, and arms, ugh!). I could only get one arm or leg on one charge, so I'd have to either wait between areas for a charge, or spread out my epilating over a few days to get it all done. That, and it seemed to break the hears more often than actually pulling them out.<br /><br />I bought this Emjoi because I liked that it was corded, which meant unlimited power that wouldn't fade. I really don't need the portability of a battery operated epilator, nor do I need it to be waterproof (epilating in a dim shower really has no benefits, I found). The light on the Braun is very handy, though.<br /><br />I used the Emjoi for the first time last night, and let me tell you, WHAT A DIFFERENCE! It's noisy, and it has no light, but it sure gets the job done. I got both legs done in less than the time it took to do just one leg with the Braun! And since I didn't have to wait for a charge, I was able to do my entire body all at once.<br /><br />Here's what so amazing, though: the heads on this Emjoi seem to run much faster than my Braun, and because of this, I experienced a LOT less pain! I did not expect this at all! I assumed all epilators offered the same amount of pain.<br /><br />Anyone who's experienced with epilating knows what broken hairs feel like: visually, the hairs are gone, but you can feel the tops of them at the surface of the skin. Withthis Emjoi, I felt smoother than I ever have. I was weary, though, because I didn't have the same amount of redness that I'd grown accustomed to after using the Braun. But, the smoothness doesn't lie.<br /><br />There is only one downside to the Emjoi, which will cause me to continue using my Braun. It doesn't get into the very small areas. Since I'm a guy, I have hair on my hands and fingers. The Emjoi is much too bulky to fit close enough on my fingers and hands. So, the Braun works great for that.<br /><br />Overall, The Emjoi is a HUGE improvement over my Braun. Not only is it faster, but it's also more effective and causes less pain and redness. Trust me, this is a much better buy!

  496. I ordered this product in hopes that I would be better able to cover large areas such as my legs and arms for longer hair removal; specifically for summer time. Pros- -fast, the extra heads do what you would expect, cover large areas more efficiently. -less painful than other epilator varieties....the function that presses down on the area does help ease the pain as the alternate side pulls out the hair...keep in mind that the angle does have to be correct, but that is not too tricky -dual speeds, one for softer one for rougher hair....I tend to use the faster speed anyways but it helps with comfort to start with the gentler speed then transition cons- dont, dont, dont, use this on sensitive areas such as the face or armpit or even the bikini line.....at least for me. It says that you can if you manuever it correctly, but trust me its easier to use one of the smaller units made more specifically for these areas or to simply use another method of hair removal. must be plugged in during use...not a big deal but never the less price- but then again, just one trip to a salon will cost you pretty much the same

  501. I used the Emjoi gently silken epilator for about two years before getting the Emagine - definitely happy with my purchase. I had read the reviews on several different websites before buying this product and it is definitely less painful than my previous epilator. Works quite fast as well - I use it for maintenance after getting my arms and legs waxed and it works like a charm. Few tips - make sure to stretch the skin to help reduce pain and try to do it after a shower so that the hair is a little easier to pull out. Also lay a towel or something to catch the hair because it tend to fly around a little when it is plucked out by the machine.   502. I was really hoping this product would work out. I have a bad back, and shaving can be a pain. I figured to use this once every week or so was better than shaving every day. WRONG. It did pull out some of the hairs, but for the most part, it snapped the hairs instead, leaving me worse off then when shaving. The snapped hairs led to very painful ingrown hairs, VERY quickly. I hardly ever got an ingrown hair when shaving, so this really surprised me. I ended up with tons of little cuts all over my legs from having to dig the ingrown hairs out. On top of that, my legs always felt like I had not shaved in two days; NEVER smooth. My sister tried it thinking she might have better luck and buy it, but it was so painful for her that she could not do more than a square inch; needless to say, she regretted letting her hair grow out all week. Within two to three weeks, I returned it. My back hurt worse than ever because it took so long to get those ingrown hairs out. Don't waste your time.
  503. I purchased an Emjoi AP-18 last May after my old epilator (Braun) bit the dust. This product is AMAZING. Fast and effective. I can do both legs in just under 30 minutes. My old epilator used to take an hour or more. I use the Emjoi on my under arms and I experience considerably less discomfort. I would highly recommed Emjoi AP-18 to anyone interested in purchasing an epilator. The only thing I miss about my old epilator is that it had a light on it... but who needs a light to search for hairs left behind when there aren't any?
  504. I purchased this product exclusively for the removal of hair on my face. I do not have hair on my legs, arms or under arms, but as I've gotten older, I do have patches of hair that grow under my chin (over my top lip, around the lower sides of my mouth, and on my chin). After carefully researching and comparing epilators, I bought this one because it seemed most ideal for my specific need. I also thoroughly read the instructions that came with the unit. There was no mention by the manufacturer that this epilator painfully pinches and grabs your skin while in use. I am a seasoned user of facial wax, so I know that hair removal is not a pain-free process by any means. My first use of the Emjoi produced somewhat satisfactory results, but I still had to tweeze some hairs away. Not wanting to give up on this unit, I cleaned it according to the instructions, and stored it away. I waited the 6-8 weeks for the next round of growth, and to my dismay, was not happy with the results (not to mention the almost unbearable pain of the pinching and grabbing of my skin by the machine). I contacted Amazon, and there is basically nothing that can be done. I wasted money on a product that cannot be returned at this juncture, and most certainly one that I will never use again. Perhaps I can sell it at a garage sale and recoup some of my money.
  505. I purchased this hoping that I could shave less often. I waited until the hair on my legs was grown out to the recommended length to use the epilator. However, it didn't pull out the hair. I went over my legs multiple times and still, almost no hair was removed. I have fairly light and thin hair, so perhaps it didn't work for that reason. I had to return the item because it simply did not work.

  507. Works well but is so hard to use!
  508. There are pros and cons to this product as with any.<br />I will start with the cons: it lacks a light. You have to be in a very well lit room or outside to see the lighter or finer hairs on your legs. My vision is fine, I do not require glasses, but with out the light, I am straining to see the backs of my legs and lower down near the ankle. Also, it will not work if not plugged in. It isn't a charger cord, it's a power cord. This is annoying because you can't use it wherever you want in the house with out something ridiculous like an extension cord. I mean, why not just shave? Additionally, there are two speeds, 1 is slower, 2 is faster. At first, the slower speed was more efficient because the fastest speed would just tear hair in half instead of pluck the whole follicle. As time went by, the motor got weak and the faster speed was the better choice. And I have to say it is a little pricey. Around $70 for something that had better be worth it. And for my final con- the motor gave out. I bought this about 4 years ago. I took good care of it, I cleaned it, I stored it with the cap on and kept it out of damp, moist areas. None of that mattered to the little motor that couldn't.<br />As for the pros: it is easy to use. The double sided heads are good for one reason, not because they pluck double the hair, because any seasoned epilator knows, you have to come to hair at the right angle, but because you can go back and forth on your arm pits with out having to turn it around. And if you are someone who has hair growing out of your legs every which way, then you might consider the double sided heads to be more efficient, otherwise, its really only an arm pit benefit.<br />I keep trying to think of pros, and I think I might just be super irritated that this thing no longer works after 4 years, but c'mon, can't anything last anymore? Why must everything be made so cheaply? There is no true quality anymore. So, I give it a two, because, while it lasted, it did the job.
  509. Very disappointed. I bought this one instead of my Braun on which the battery failed after about a year. I was very happy at first, since this is an epilator with a cord, so I thought it should definitely last longer. I am sure it will, except that for me there is no use in it at all. This epilator hardly pulls any hair from my skin. Big plus is that it never pinched my skin, no matter what direction I go. Huge minus is that it leaves short hair untouched. Unlike Braun it does not lift a hair at its root, passing over it instead. I need to spend twice as much time, manually trying to lift my hair so the damn thing grabs it in the end. The whole process now turned into a disaster, with me spending 40 minutes every other day. I need to use it that often because it leaves so many hairs behind. I've been embarrassed to come to the office recently and now switched to waxing again. I think I will go back to Braun. Even though it lasted a bit less than a year, it was a year I never had to worry about smoothness of my legs.

  538. This is my first ever epilator. Being sick of waiting forever for full hair growth to was, and not a big fan of shaving, I was considering laser hair removal and then a friend suggested I try epilators. I looked online for different ones, and the Emjoi had the best reviews so as always, I trusted the reviewers, and I'm so glad I did!<br /><br />Firstly, this is a corded epilator, but the cord is long (about 7-8 feet). Using a corded epilator is better because there is no question of the battery charge lasting, and it is faster (as I've heard from friends that use battery powered ones). I just wish it came with some kind of suction system that would suck up the hairs.<br /><br />The Emjoi has two speed settings, and even the speed level 1 is faster than the Braun. Speed level 2 almost makes hair removal a super fast and easy task. It does a good job with hands and legs, stomach, bikini line, underarms and even chin, leaving your body smooth and worry-free for at least a week or more, depending on your hair growth. And the best part is, you don't have to wait for hair to get long. This epilator can pull out hair as small as 2mm in length without any trouble! And it almost takes the same time as waxing yourself, but with much lesser mess and clean-up later.<br /><br />What's included: The epilator, power cord, loofah, cleaning brush and a handy pouch that fits all of these.

  579. I have had a Braun Silk-epil for a few years and recently decided to upgrade. The Emjoi is higher quality, as you would expect with a much higher priced epilator. The tweezers are metal on the Emjoi, I assume steel, but plastic on the Braun. I expected better performance but this is much better than I expected. The Silk-epil required multiple passes to removed all of the hair and you could feel it tugging and losing the hairs, particularly painful in more sensitive areas. The Emjoi pulled much better and did not tug on hairs but grabbed and pulled them out much more quickly, meaning a much less painful experience. I found this definitely worth the extra money.
  580. The rotators depend on two set of gears. One set is in the head piece and the other in the body of the epilator. I am sure they could cut down 10 cents on the profits and put in a more durable gear. I think they expect us to keep buying the head piece but to me that would be throwing good money after the bad. I am buying a Philips....

  584. This is my first epilator and it is ok. Not as painful as I thought it would be. My only problem is that it doesn't seem to have a close shave feel afterwards like a razor does.
  585. EDIT: After a few months of use.... this product has led to so many in-grown hairs that I almost considered going to the hospital. It's foul and I hate it and I threw it away.<br /><br />First of all, ignore anyone who says that using an epilator doesn't hurt. What does it feel like? It feels like it's using 72 tweezers to rip 72 hairs simultaneously from the root out of your God-Knows-What-Part. Of course it hurts. It does get much easier if you keep it up because then you'll only be covering 1/3-1/2 of your hair. Still, though, ouch. However, I have gotten certain sensitive parts of skin &#34;stuck&#34; in the epilator, which sounds extremely painful but was actually not bad--their safety feature stopping the heads from spinning works great! (Thankfully!)<br /><br />Second of all, precede epilation with the consumption of half a bottle of wine.<br /><br />Third, it gets kind of hot? I'm worried about it burning me.<br /><br />Fourth, the coverage isn't excellent. It's hard to get all of the hair in one area. I think I still have to train myself not to expect the perfectly smooth results of shaving, though. So that may be common among epilators.<br /><br />Fifth, in-grown hairs result from un-tweezed hairs snapping back into the folicles. Not all of the time, but it never happened to this extent with shaving or waxing.<br /><br />HOWEVER - It doesn't result in razor burn at all, and it is nice (especially during the summer) not to worry about hair removal for a week at a time.
  586. I have tried many epilators and this one is by far the best epilator I've ever had!!!
  587. So, this is the second epilator I've tried. My first was the Braun 5270 Xelle Silk-Epil, a device so torturous that I didn't try again for 4 years. Before the Braun, I'd occasionally waxed. Now, I only shave. So, I knew to expect a much higher sensitivity.<br /><br />So, I steeled myself for what I knew would be mind-blowing pain and proceeded to epilate, and it was... uncomfortable? Even the bikini area was pretty okay. The only problem was that it took soooo many passes to clear an area, but, even with the multiple passes, my skin didn't really get red or irritated.<br /><br />It's taken me 2 weeks, epilating for an hour every 2 days, to clear my legs, underarms, and bikini area. I'd stop after an hour, not because it hurt, but because my patience had run out. It really does take a LOT of passes to clear an area. Now, though, I'm just doing touch-up, which only takes several minutes.
