  591. I felt compelled to write a review since I almost did not buy this product based on the negative reviews. I am so glad I bought it! History: I have been a long time epilator and have a 2.5yr old Braun 5270 X'elle. I have no complaints nor does my old Braun owe me anything, it just wasn't grabbing the hair and would take three passes to pluck a hair. So, I ordered the Emjoi AP-18 Emagine. Design: Seems to be designed well based on the location of the gears versus the Braun. With the Braun, periodic cleaning of the gears was required since hair would fall down the gaps. The Emjoi has the gears located on the sides which makes more sense, but time will tell if this design is better. Results: It took me 15 minutes to do my underarms, bikini area and legs; 5 minutes to read the manual + 10 minutes to do the work. It does work, and well at that, provided you follow the given instructions. I had no issues even in small spaces. It pulled out the hair in a single pass (I could see the root base so it was not breaking the hair), and it did a stellar job. Thank you Emjoi for a great product! Amazon has always been great shipping things to me, so 5 stars to Amazon too!

  595. I have had great results in most areas of my body and only noticed major discomfort in the center of my chest and armpits. The pubic area was nowhere near what I anticipated it being due to some of the reviews I read. I am still in the trial and error stage of what works best for me (ie. once or twice a week, after a shower VS after a bath, pre or post loufah use, etc...). There were suggestions given in the instruction manual and in the reviews of other users, I will eventually try most to find out what works best for me. I prefer using the slower speed as it seems to pull the hair from the root where the faster speed seems to break a lot of the hairs off at the surface, meaning a faster regrowth and more frequent usage. My regrowth has been reduced, a lot of the hairs don't come back, and the ones that do seem thinner and softer, also, the weekly use in the beginning is now around every two weeks, however, there are the one or two hairs that are fast growers and the ones missed because I can't see some areas. One improvement I would make is the addition of a light since most room lighting is eye to ceiling level, not in the shadow areas of the body or below the shoulder level. All in all I give the item a very high rating, but not at the very top, maybe a 9 out of a possible 10.

  597. I bought this item a long couple of years now and it still works great. Except that I don't have so much hair to remove from my legs and under arms. My first time using this, I must admit, it was tickling painful, but I got used to it. From there, I use it less and less now because I don't have so much hair any more. I use it after a shower because the water and scrubbing opens the hair pores which makes it much easier to tweeze. Another note, tie up long head hair and clothing when tweezing your under arms because you can pull your long hair into this tweezer and... I seriously dont know how you would get it out, but to turn off the device and pull out the hair/ thread itself. I like the fact that I dont need to continuously buy batteries for it because it comes with a cord. It's not like I will be tweezing my legs in public. The item also came with a carry bag and a little brush to clean the tweezer head, the cord, and the cover for the tweezer area. Also, this is a some what loud device. I first saw this product review on You Tube and I thought I should try it. I did and I'm glad that I did because with a couple of minutes use and the hair doesn't grow back as fast.   598. My old Emjoi was destroyed and I found myself searching for a new epilator. I love my old Emjoi. It was much less painful that other epilators I had used in the past. When searching for it's replacement I was happy to find this newer model but wondered if it was worth the higher price. It was. This model has plenty of power and the dual heads do make a difference. More hairs are picked up faster. Now, I have noticed that it doesn't always get every hair, but that may be more my fault. I have neither the time nor inclination to ensure every single hair has been plucked. One of the beauties of epilating (and why I switched all those years ago) is that, over time, the hairs grow back much thinner and weaker. Besides, I have never had an epilator that gets every single hair. Back when I shaved my legs, I would have to shave them every, single day (twice a day if I had a date that night). If I missed a day or two the stubble was thick and dark, and noticeable rough to touch. I tried epilating once in a while but found it too painful. Only with the Emjoi was I able to stand it long enough to really get the long term effects. Dont' get me wrong, even with the Emjoi, the first few days were like torture, but tolerable After several years of epilating, I could miss even a whole week (camping) and the stubble was sparse and thin and softer to the touch. I have been using an epilator without switching back for almost 10 years now so it isn't really a big deal if it misses a hair or two here or there. Besides, anyone noticing that one missed hair has bigger issues to deal with :-).

Being of Indian decent, I'm a female who unfortunately has battled with every form of hair removal with little success - until I found epilation. After about a year of using the Braun with little decrease or resistance build up to the pain I started searching for another alternative and found the Emoji Ap-18. After reading such positive reviews I decided to bite the bullet and make the purchase and haven't looked back since! The Emoji is so much less painful that the Braun! I guess the 72 heads help minimize the pain, although on the flip side, I find that the Emoji doesn't get as many as the finer, smaller hairs that the Braun used to. Although I have to make a few more passes with the Emoji than I had to with the Braun, it's totally worth it due to the minimized pain levels! I definitely recommend the Emoji AP-18 to anyone looking for an efficient, low pain (no epilator will be pain free) Epilator.

  636. Let me start by saying this thing works great. It preformed way beyond what I was expecting. I am a male, So if it removed my hair as well as it did it should work wonders on women. I really don't understand how folks have given it bad reviews. I followed the instructions and had amazing results. Now for the cons, Because everything has it's drawbacks. It hurts a lot! Well at first anyways, I think my body turned off pain signals to prevent me from going into shock... Well it is not that bad but here is a brief run down of my experience. From the neckline to the bottom of my pecs was painful, But very tolerable (I'd give it a 1-2 from 1-10, 10 being very painful). Bottoms of my pecs to my bellybutton gradually got more and more painful the farther south I went (I'd give it a 3 from 1-10). Belly button down hurt a lot so prepare yourself(An easy 7 on the pain scale... mind you my tattoos were all 3-4s to include to one on my rib cage which is a very tender area). It was not painful at all around nipples (I was very worried that area would hurt a lot! It was maybe a 1 from 1-10) Arms are not that bad to do either (maybe a 1-2 from 1-10) Tops of my feet (yeah, stop laughing) was about a 2 on the pain scale. I don't shave my armpits or legs, So I do not know how that feels.. I do not have back hair so don't know how that feels either. I used it on the same areas for about 5 days in a row, the last time I used it was 7 days ago and have not noticed ANY new hair growth after the last session (remember your hair grows in cycles, so it takes about a week to get all of it, then you should not have to do it again for about 3 weeks) I found that a glass of wine before, then enjoy one during helps a ton with the pain. Also in my experience, the first session was the most painful, the ones that followed were not as bad at all. also make sure of you plan on using this in a area that has not been groomed in awhile, TRIM the hair first! I learned the hard way. Well that's all I got, I hope this helps someone. I gave it 5 stars, Because it works great! I have not had to do grooming of any kind in a week, so it is well worth the little bit of pain.

  645. First let me say, I don't write reviews. I was initially going to complain about how long it took to get my emagine, but it was well worth the wait. I normally pay to get waxed or use a hair removal lotion. I haven't done either in a while. I took a warm shower before I used my epilator. I started with my under arms. The last time I had them waxed I wanted to slap the lady when she ripped up the strip. It was so painful. I felt almost nothing using this. There was no irritation at all. I didn't use deodorant directly after using this but I feel like I could without it burning (after waxing or using the removal creams such as nair or veet I can't say the same). Next, I used it on my legs. It did sting, but again waxing is more painful and the creams are more irritating. I even used this on very tender areas. I have gotten brazillian waxes before, but I only planed on \\"cleaning up\\" around the edges of the bikini area. It was such an improvement to waxing I ended up taking more than I started out to and taking it all off. As far as breaking hairs... there were a few pieces of stubble left. Not much at all and definatly not enough to complain about. I will epilate again in a week to get those. I figure some hairs are weaker than others, finer than others, and different lengths (plus I am new to this and was practicing how to hold it and how much pressure to use). I have very sensitive skin and I usually feel horrible after waxing and even after using creams. My skin feels warm and a little like I just had a massage vs removing hair. Advice- do not apply any pressure. Just glide it softly over the skin. Lie down and relax your arm while doing underarms or it can prove to be very difficult. Hold skin taut everywhere. Start at the edge of an area and work your way into the hair little by little by using small back and forth strokes until you have cleaned the area. Last of all go back over clean areas in the perpendicular direction of what you first used to make sure you get any wild hairs growing in a different direction. Enjoy your Emjoi!

  647. In our household we have 3 Emjoi epilators (all from Amazon) and we like them all for different things. So I will post this same review for all three. We started with the AP-9T Tweezers - about $13.95. It is a small battery-operated unit. At first we had to learn how to use an epilator - how to hold it, etc., but once we got all that down, we found it worked really well for the small areas like upper and lower lip. Unless there is a massive amount of hair, it is not painful but you can feel when it \\"makes hits\\" - like a tweezer pull. It is not particularly useful for underarms and it would take too long to do the legs. But since we had got quite addicted to being hairless (and didn't have to run out to be threaded every 3 weeks), we decided to buy another so that my daughter and I would each have one. This time we went up a notch to the Emjoi AP-9L Epi-Slim. It is about $14.77 at Amazon and also battery operated. We like it much better. It too is great for the small areas like the upper and lower lip and chin. But we decided to also try a more expensive one. This time we bought the Emjoi AP-18 Emagine Dual Tweezer set. It is about $74.71 and it is more like the size of a men's shaver. It is corded and more powerful. This one does great under the arms and on the legs and even in the bikini area. It is not so good on the small areas like the upper and lower lip because the dual heads don't fit that well. But it will do the rest of the face and quite powerfully. The first time we tried to do the cheeks and the side of the face, it hurt - like little electric shocks as it pulled all that baby fine fuzz most of us have there. It makes your face so smooth. But once you get past the first few times and the bulk of the hair has been pulled, it is not painful. Ladies, there is no reason to be hairy! These gadgets really work.
  648. Always a great product. You would be crazy not to use these. I know In america they are not as popular, but the rest of the world uses these all the time, its unique and does what it needs to over any other product. I never have a time when I don't have this in my house!
  649. This is a very well designed product, but considering the amount of pain involved, this is just not for me. Prepping my skin takes far too long (exfoliating etc) and this epilator seems to miss quite a bit even on spots where there are hairs long enough to grab with my fingers. I would like to try the optional shaving head (which was not included!) but it doesn't seem as if Amazon carries it. This was a wasted $80 in my case. The epilator itself is very sturdy, and although it did hurt, it didn't once pinch my skin (a worry when doing my underarms).
  650. I'm 24 and that's my first epilator. I was afraid to be in pain. I wanted to buy this one because the head is larger, so I thought that will be stronger and faster. And I was right: of course that hurts, but because the head is strong, you do little rounds and you know the hairs are leaving. You don't need to pass over and over at a spot to remove all the hairs, and that's awesome. So I did my 2 legs and thighs, and then I even did my \\"bikini\\" zone ( even if that was my first time with an epilator :)! ). I did that 6 hours ago, and I still have little red dots, I'll see if there is a cream or something, but.. really great product! ( And I like the red color. )

  655. The Emjoi Emagine Epilator is a good device for removing unwanted hair. It does hurt at first, in some areas more then others but after the second or third use the pain decreases. After using this epilator my skin was smooth and most of the hair was removed. I found that if you take your time and go over each area twice the epilator will remove 90-95% of the hair. This product works good for your legs, underarms, bikini line and where ever you have unwanted hair. I would recomend this product to any women who are sick of shaving all the time and hate the rough stubble feeling when hair starts to grow back after shaving. After using the epilator hair grows back much slower then with saving and also much finer. The hair that does grow back seems to be soft baby hairs that are easily removied by the emjoi emagine. Over all i think this is a very good product. It works like its suposed to and is worth the price. This is my first epilator so i cant compare it to others but from what i researched this is one of the best on the market with the most tweezer heads. I could not emagine another epilator being any better! ;)

  664. I have two other corded Emjoi epilators, both of which I am happy with, and particularly satisfied with the Emjoi Divine. But, I thought that I could upgrade and order an item that would do the work in half the time. I didn't have a problem with pulling out hairs with this item--in that manner, it did do it's job. However, for some reason, the surface of the machine is very abrasive where it feels like it's cutting into your skin. My only guess for the difference is that this machine has no buffering on the sides where the other Emjoi Divine is curved and provides buffers for pain release (meanwhile still satisfactorily pulling out the hair). If you don't have sensitive skin, like I do, you may not have any issues with the machine. But for myself, I'd rather use something that doesn't feel like it's tearing my skin apart. Needless to say, I returned the item.

  676. I have used many Emjoi products for a long time. This epilator stopped working after almost a year from date of purchase. I returned it to Emjoi within 2 days they replaced it with a new epilator. Great epilator, great customer service and Amazon is #1!!!!!!!!!
  677. Whoa. This is great! I've had a couple of the smaller epilators which were really noisy and flimsy. It would take an hour to do my legs with those, let alone arms. I can do my arms and legs in about 15 minutes with this larger model. I don't think it's as noisy as my smaller ones. I prefer the corded models because (a) batteries create waste and (b) batteries lose charge quickly in a device like this. If you're new to epilators, realize that you get what you pay for and don't go cheap and then complain. Also realize that the first time you use it, it will be torture (unless you're used to waxing); but before too long it'll be just a minor discomfort. Keep some solarcaine handy for afterwards if you think you'll need it. Also, it only works if you hold it absolutely perpendicular to your skin, unlike an electric razor which can go off the 90-degree angle and still work (I think this may be the source of some people's complaints that epilators don't work for them). Best thing: I don't have to shave again in 2 days. What a savings over constantly buying razors!
  678. I have been using this almost a year consistently, and am overall pleased with it..It is my first epilator to use and do not regret it. At first, I would get little bumps on certain follicles and I almost gave up on it but after doing research online, I found that is common especially on people with thick hair, which I definitely had (I use it on my legs and underarms), one solution I found was using this product right out of the shower so pores are open, and cleaning the areas with witch hazel afterwards and using non-comodogenic lotions after that..I am glad I kept using bc now I notice not only less hair growth, but it is much thinner..I hope that in due time, I have to use it less and less. My mom told me to try this years ago, oh how I should have listened then lol..I recommend :D

  682. As a person with terrible eczema on my legs, I have struggled for YEARS to find a solution to my leg hair removal problem. Everything I had tried irritated my eczema further and caused flair-ups - shaving with a razor, shaving with an electric shaver, neet, the sandpaper type leg-hair remover, home waxing...until I began getting professional leg-waxing. That seemed to be the only thing that my legs could tolerate and didn't cause my eczema to get out of control. I even tried at-home Brazilian waxing to try to get a cleaner hair removal at home without the expense of the professional services every month, all to no avail. When I was a teenager, I had owned an Epilady and couldn't stand the pain of it so I only used it once, but I knew that with the pain of childbirth behind me and being used to leg waxing, I should now be able to handle epilation without a problem. I don't know what made me think of ordering an epilator at this time. I have let my hair go for quite some time. Not having the finances or local resources (only one place near me does it and they did a HORRIBLE job the one time I went there) to get professional leg waxing done, I really had no choice. I was getting desperate and broke down to purchase the Emjoi AP-18 Emagine Dual Opposed 72 Tweezer Head Epilator after reading the reviews. I rationalized the expense with the fact that professional leg waxing costs anywhere from $65 to $90 a visit depending on location and full/half leg services. This thing would pay for itself in two uses if it worked...and work it did. I just used it for the first time. Not only did it take half the time of a professional leg waxing, but the discomfort was SO MUCH LESS AND the hair removal was even better! I am thrilled to have found a leg hair removal system that works for me. My legs responded the same way that they do to a professional leg waxing as far as my skin is concerned and my eczema seems to be remaining unaffected! I am ECSTATIC and, I should also mention, so is my husband! :) I am so GLAD that I broke down and made this purchase and I will be HIGHLY recommending it to anyone and EVERYONE that I can!o mention, so is my husband! :) I am so GLAD that I broke down and made this purchase and I will be HIGHLY recommending it to anyone and EVERYONE that I can!

If you press too hard, it slows down, so press it just up to the point right before it changes sound. I would guess I have 70% reduction in total hair and thickness from Silknsense on my stomach.<br /><br />Basically, this product works. Does it work better enough for the price tag? Debatable. Is it a long term practical solution for a guy in deep rooted areas like the chest or stomach? Absolutely not. If you are looking to be hair free for a season, or an occasion - this works. If you have deep, coarse, hard rooted guy hair, you are going to tire of the pain and repetition quickly. Just realize this is NOT something you are going to be wanting to use every couple of weeks.

It's not unbearable. I imagine it is very similar to getting a tattoo. After a few passes your skin starts to go a little numb. It takes some time, longer than shaving. I had to go over several areas more than once. I only did my calves. They immediately got red bumps ALL over. But by morning the red bumps were gone. It was just irritation.<br /><br />So back to the speed of these tweezers rolling around the barrels... it moves fast. I was terrified to set it against my skin! And after the first month it works even less, even after being cleaned. What a waste of money.
  721. My old emjoi epilator broke several years ago. After shaving for a couple of years, I decided to go back to the epilator and purchased another brand. The other brand seemed to break the hair more often than tweeze it out so I returned the device. Subsequently, I ordered/received the Emjoi 72 Tweezer head epilator.   722. I love only having once a week, and sometimes less in the winter. Your hairs grow back soft so you don't notice rough nubs. Occasionally I get an ingrown hair but it doesn't detract from the benefits. This is the best one I've tried. It does take several swipes with the razor but you are only doing it once a week wo it's worth the extra time. Hairs grow at different rates, so I don't find I can wait 6 weeks like the product says. I've used an Emjoi Epilator for years and won't go back to hand held or electric razor. I am sold on the product and they last for years!!!
  723. I have been epilating for a while now and needed a 2nd epilator due to travel, etc. I have a Silk braun Xelle that has a cord and it has worked wonderfully for me. I couldnt find the same model I have, so decided to try this one, thinking that the dual heads would make it easier to epilate hard to reach areas where the hair follicles grow in different directions. When receiving this item the first thing that immediately disappointed me was the lack of a built in light. My Silk epilator has a small light near the head that clearly illuminates the fine hairs that are otherwise very difficult to see, even in a well lit room. My next disappointment was the fact that the unit does not come with any form of trimmer head. The trimmer is necessary to shorten the hairs and make them much easier for the tweezer heads to grab. Other then that, the epilator works, but definitely doesnt work as well as the braun. It seems to have a harder time grabbing fine hairs and doesnt do as good of a job of removing hairs after a single pass. The only positive is it really doesnt cause much pain, but I think that is because its not pulling the hairs like it is suppose to. If I was able to return this model I would, but I kept it for a while to try it out. Will definitely be looking for a replacement as it doesnt work well enough to meet my needs.
  724. I have been using a single wheeled epilator for years and was happy with everything about it, except how long it took me to do my legs. It would take 20-30 minutes PER leg because my hair was so thick. So, the epilator I've been using finally just got to be useless and I decided to treat myself to a new one. This one is AWESOME. I had each leg done in about 4 minutes and it did just as good a job as the other one!<br /><br />I can see how this might not do as good a job if you have really fine hair. It does rotate pretty fast, and I can't tell if it would actually pull out the fine hairs or just break them, but if you have coarse hair that is hard to pull out, this is the epilator you want! It works extremely well and leaves the skin hair free and smooth, but I swear to God that I felt like punching my daughter in the face if she didn't stop. Luckily she didn't. This is the second Emjoi product which has failed me after less than 2 years due to breakage of the wheel's plastic spokes. So be prepared to replace this item more frequently than should be necessary for its cost. I'm no engineer, but it seems to me the wheel should be made of metal, not plastic.

  750. In 1998, I bought my first epilator, which was the Emjoi Gently Gold and I used it primarily on my underarms, bikini area and the inner and back area of my legs. I should also say that I have very coarse, thick black hair which I can shave with a razor at 5am and have a shadow by 9am! After over 10 years of faithful service, I had to replace my Gently Gold and I vascillated between the AP-18 and the Lighted Caress model. I wish I could say I choose the right one, but I did not. I went cheaper and bought the Caress model, which for some time now has exuded a blackish powdery substance each time I used it (?) I decided it was time to upgrade and bought the AP-18 and what a difference! It is much faster and for some reason, less painful. Starting about 3 years ago, due to problems with persistent, itchy bumps on my legs, I started epilating my entire leg, and yes, the first time was the worst! Even after I got used to it, the areas around my ankles and knees were always the most sensitive, but not so bad with this new model. With time, I had gotten used to it anyway and the pain, to me, was minimal and now, with the AP-18, it is practically non existent. I am so pleased with the speed of it, it takes me about 10 minutes per leg. It also does a much better job on my armpits, but of course, you have to be sure your armpits are COMPLETELY dry (also necessary with the legs). I wish I could tell you that the hairless effect lasts for weeks as advertised, but not so for me. My hair grows VERY quickly and so if I want to keep things fairly hairless, I need to do it at least once a week. I will say though, that the growth that does come in the course of the week is pretty hard to see, unless someone is really looking for it. Even doing it once a week is thrilling for me compared to daily shaving and still not smooth. I cannot say I have tried any other brands of epilators other than Emjoi, but if you are looking for a really good one in their lineup, I highly recommendthe AP-18.
  751. I owned one of the first epiladys many years ago. The theory was great, but the pain stronger.<br />This product with 72 tweezer heads works great. Much less discomfort and long lasting results. I am very satisfied with the product and enjoy not having stubble to contend with.
  752. I have used other epilators with fewer tweezers and have had to go over the same area two or three times in order to get all of the hairs. With the wider head this is reduced. Does in get every hair on the first pass? No, but I don't know of any brand that does. It does have a powerful motor and with the two speeds there is plenty of power. Is it any noisier then other models? Maybe. I think epilating pain is reduced somewhat because you have to make fewer passes. But the sting is really no worse if you are used to it. Personally i think it is less painful in the bikini area and in the area of the Brazil wax. I wore out the other less expensive brand of Enjoli in less than a year. It will be interesting to see how this brand performs long term. For now, I am glad I purchased this model.

I'm Southern European (those that are KNOW that we have not only MORE hair in MORE areas of the BODY, and A LOT of it is Thick too, and it's ALWAYS Jet Black), so I wanted something that cut down (out, completely is what I wish for) the Waxing/Threading time. To keep \\"Fuzz Free\\" I have to Wax (EVERYWHERE from the Chin down, except a small portion of my upper back, and i don't do upper arms, also I THREAD my Face), then THREAD my Face (Cheeks, eyebrows, chin, & where the hair line goes in front of ear. From Wash/scrubbing, set up for lightening, floor protection, mirrors, etc to running back and forth to the Microwave to heat/warm the Wax, to Waxing, then Threading, then Calming the Skin and putting the Mirrors and such away and cleaning the Area(s), it (NO JOKE) can take upwards of 10 Hours, average begin about 7/8. This has to be done about every TWO WEEKS.<br />3. ANYTHING, that cuts down this time and arduous task, is needed ,that's why I looked at this, (Laser is too expensive & ruins Tattoos, & some other products have rather bad reviews). It removed about 40% of the Hair. It was done over 9 hours ago, and I still have bumps & some red pin marks where the skin was caught.<br />Neck/Chest/Upper Abdomen- Removed about 60% of the hairs. Practically felt nothing.<br />Armpits- Maybe I just don't have the technique but MAYBE Removed a couple hairs. I still have bumps & some red pin marks where the skin was caught, more then the ForeArms.<br />Lower Back/ Bum/ Upper Back of Thighs/ Partial Bikini Area - Removed quite a bit, maybe more then 60%!!! I didn't feel anything, EXCEPT the closer you get to the more *fragile* Zones. Left with a few red pinpricks/Irritation bumps, probably less the waxing though!!!<br />Face , Cheeks/ Upper Lip/ Beside the Ears/ Chin/ JawLine - Took (possibly) more then 60% of the Hairs away. Felt a little prickly, sometimes. No Bumps so far!!!<br /><br />So, even if I have to to this once (I hope it will be less, but lets say maybe even 2 - 3 Times a week) and EyeBrow Threading ( Can't/Shouldn't Epilate There! ) It would still take LESS time AND EFFORT/TROUBLE to do this then the Waxing/Threading Routine. I still will Shave some areas, but maybe (and I HOPE) I can get it to where I no longer have to SHAVE EITHER!<br /><br />I will update, I look forward to things getting easier, and more Effective .... I hope!!!

  785. I have very hairy legs and very sensitive skin. I usually have to use an electric shaver but that only keeps me smooth for half a day before I have stubble. I'm no wimp when it comes to pain (I just sat through 2 hours of tattooing yesterday) and while it did hurt I could totally handle it. I prepped my skin like the directions say and sat for hours the first time with my headphones in and watched a movie while I went over and over my leg without much to show for it. I thought maybe my hair was too short (I had shaved the previous day like I was advised) so I let it grow out for a couple of days more and tried again. I would go over and over the same spots but it was only grabbing about 60% of my hair. I even did my armpits and while that did hurt pretty bad it actually worked really well. I only had a couple of stray hairs I grabbed with tweezers afterwards. Unfortunately I developed really bad ingrown hairs under my arms so although it worked I don't think I'll do that again. I did it on my arms with long hair but it really just broke off the hair because they were stubbly the next day. I think I tried it a couple more times on my legs with even longer hair but it never grabbed enough. I would totally sit through the pain once a week if it meant that my legs would be smooth but as it was I was dealing with the pain and the maintenance of shaving angry epliated skin anyway. Worked so badly I returned it.

  789. First of all let me say this is the first epilator i have owned. I used to shave and i am in my late 20's, i was sick of shaving. I figured there had to be another way to loose unwanted hair! I did some research and found out about &#34;Epilating&#34; a hand held device much like an electrical shaver except it plucks your hair with tweezers instead of shaves. I read many reviewers saying Emjoi AP-18 was the best, i also read some reviewers saying it was NOT the best. Many of the reviewers that did not like Emjoi AP-18 preferred the Braun SE7681 Silk-&eacute;pil 7 Wet and Dry Epilator or just the &#34;braun&#34; brand in general. I personally choose the Emjoi AP-18 because i wanted to try out the 72 tweezers. In my mind i think the 72 tweezers would be the fastest hair removal and it was corded so i did not have to worry about battery life. The down side to this is you cannot use the Emjoi AP-18 in water, at the time when i was purchasing i figured this would not be a big deal. Well Now i am looking to purchase the braun NOT because the Emjoi AP-18 does not work but because i think i would prefer using an Epilator while i take a HOT bath. My Emjoi AP-18 works great and i love that it is corded because i do not have to worry about the battery dying. The flip side to this is buying the Braun SE7681 with the battery dying but being able to use while i take a HOT bath, so i plan to purchase the Braun SE7681 Only because i can use this while i take a bath. I also would like to note i have a high pain tolerance and I am able to Epilate sensitive area's like arm pits, bikini area, face. I just think that now i would like to experience epilating under hot water to dull some of the pain i do experience while epilating my bikini area. So to all the women and men thinking about buying your first epilator, these are my personal experiences and this may help you in your decision making with a epilator.

  820. I ordered the Emjoi AP-18 after researching several epilators. I'd read that many lacked power and required several times going over the same spot to get all the hair. After reading the reviews for this one, including many lying lechers who noted that it was relatively pain free, I decided it met both standards and ordered it.<br /><br />When I unpacked it I immediately went to the bathroom, took a shower to open my pores as recommended, and thoroughly dried. I then sat down on the floor, plugged in my Emjoi, and began mass-tweezing my leg hair.<br /><br />Let me preface to say that I'm not a very hairy girl, and I'm actually lucky in the leg hair arena that it's only dark below my knees. At about 1/4&#34; in length I thought it would be perfect. OH and it was. Let me tell you what tweezing with 72 fast-moving tweezers on your shins feels like. I imagine it's similar to dipping your leg in boiling acid, or perhaps peeling your skin off with a potato peeler. After several failed reattempts at starting and screaming like my 3-year old child mid-tantrum, my husband came to make sure I was still alive. Or, I should say, well, because with the ruckus I was making there would be no mistake that I was still living. Much hysterical laughing on his part later, I decided to take some pain medicine and wait a half hour to start again.<br /><br />30 minutes and a chugged Blue Moon later...<br /><br />Back in the bathroom, feeling more brave if not very numb, I begin again, my husband in audience for his own personal amusement. Starting again, the pain was about 98% as horrible as it was the first time, but I was COMMITTED now. I bought and paid for this implement of pain and I was going to see it through to the bitter end! So I continued torturing myself and managed to make a full circuit around the bottom part of my leg. Feeling accomplished, I reach down to rub what I assume will be a smooth, though very red, leg, only to find that it only removed about 70% of the hair. I would have to go over my already tortured skin once more.<br /><br />There was shaking. There were tears. We won't even mention my attempt at the bikini area...there was blood. When you rip hair out from the root, it often protests by bleeding. Oh yes, there was pain. I made an attempt at my knees, but the curved bony area didn't take well to the Emjoi, it barely removed any hair. By the end, I was more relieved it was over than the birth of my first child.<br /><br />Will I do it again? Well I'm stubborn, so I'm betting I will after maybe a few much stronger pain killers in the hopes that after time the nerves will deaden like my eyebrows after years of tweezing. Do I recommend this item? Well, that depends. If you are a man, run screaming. You don't have the genetic capability to handle this much pain. If you are a NSA agent who needs information out of someone, or perhaps a wife with a cheating spouse, this product is for you! IMMENSE amounts of pain while barely leaving evidence of said torture! If you are a woman looking for a new way to remove leg hair, stick to shaving, or waxing, or Nair. Do not, I repeat, do NOT try this at home.

  823. I had more fun watching some of the goofy videos! The more serious ones were very helpful...but the goofy ones were much more fun! I loved the woman jumping around and throwing herself off the couch as she screamed in agony...tooooo funny. Seriously, this works. It takes a little practice and personal preference on how you progress around your body. Some areas obviously are going to be more sensitive than others, though you might be suprised on that subject. I PROMISE YOU THIS, IT WILL GET EASIER...MUCH EASIER...AFTER THE FIRST TIME. The second time I used it on areas that were almost unbearable the first time around, and I was prepard for it to hurt, it did not. Really. You can always feel it pulling hairs, you are tweezing afterall and that is what tells you the job is not done yet, but it was absolutely tolerable and in some cases a complete snooze. I did some \\"tender\\" areas that I thought would be uncomfortable...nothing! Just be careful to get some of that loose skin stretched nice and tight or you may tweeze off a bit of flesh. Suprisingly, that didn't hurt so much as afterward, as would any minor abrasion or razor nick. A little Neosporin to avoid any inflamation (translated: infection) and it was no big thing. It works better after a nice hot shower. I use a long handled stiff brush to exfoliate before...it seems to help prepare the skin. Do not push against your skin. Let it lightly ride along your skin and let the tweezing action do all the work. If the motor slows down, you are pushing too hard. In the very sensitive areas, the first time might be difficult. Take you time and take a break if it gets very uncomfortable. Come back to that area later and work very small areas overlapping as you progress into the unremoved hair. It is not going to hurt as much to pull out 1/4 inch of hair line as it would doing the entire 1 1/2 (or so) inch wide head. So, don't go full bore into a thicker area or sensitive area. Go at it from the edge and work in slowly.If that starts to become uncomfortable, move to the other side of the area and come at it from that side, a 1/4 inch at a time...sort of like cutting grass! Some people complain about how loud it is. Think about this...it is a set of metal tweezer jaws, opening and closing hundreds of times a minute as they rotate around hundreds of times a minute. To ensure they firmly hold the hair to extract it, they have to slam together pretty hard. You don't want those tiny little hairs slipping out, now do you? How in the world do you do that quietly???? Pleeease! DO NOT WASTE THE MONEY ON THE BLACK \\"MEN'S\\" VERSION...GET THE RED ONE AND SAVE THE $40 OR SO DOLLARS. If it lasts a year, and I use it every few weeks (though in most areas it lasts a month or more because it is new growth, not cut razor stubble so it comes in soft and light), then the cost is less than one \\"large\\" area wax and you can do it in privacy. I hope this was helpful. Now, go watch that chick flop around like a fish!

  830. So my girlfriend said I'm a bit too hairy...<br />She bought one of these a few months ago and was using it to get rid of unwanted body hair. In the idea that it will thin out the hair that grows back, like waxing. Yes, this is crazy painful!<br />In fact it's so bad, that it pulled skin from the roots of the hair on my stomach, which is why it hurts so bad. There's no heating element or something, there's no magic ion generator to stop bacterial growth on it, or while using it. I can only assume they mean the tweezer heads are electrically doped with silver, for the same reason they (sarcasm) use silver in medical facilities. (They use \\"surgical\\" steel for a reason.[if i'm wrong here don't blame me, i'm just writing a review.])<br /><br />Also this thing was ~$80 for something that doesn't even have a battery? So in other words, \\"No, it's not something that is mounted to a wall!\\" Seriously, this probably pissed me off the most. And I should give it 3 stars for the more misleading advertisement that \\"it's portable.\\"<br /><br />They do give you a s***ty bag, that you might as well throw away, it's just junk.<br />And the cleaning brush, is too small to do anything. The bristles need to be about twice as long to clean the catch basin, or at least let me remove the tweezer head barrels to actually clean this thing out.<br /><br />Some more notes about first use:<br /><br />It HURTS! If you've ever had a tattoo, it's along those lines of pain.<br /><br />You'll get red bumps that look nasty for a few hours. You just ripped a bunch of hair from those bumps.<br /><br />It doesn't get tiny stuff, so small hair will stay till it grows out, then you can get it.<br /><br />My girlfriend has had major problems with ingrown hairs! This is a big issue, the ingrown hair will cause infections, and pimple like boils. You have to cut the skin open and get the hair out! BEWARE, this is the worst problem from this, but is normal.<br /><br />After you've done an area once, it's not as bad the second time around, as long as you keep up with it. The first time is the worst. But even after you've got the worst, you can go right over it again and get more, and it wont hurt as bad even in the first 5 minutes. So you can go over an area a few times in one night, with the bad pain once.<br /><br />Circular motions! This gets the most hair.<br /><br />Bite your teeth and just do it, I know it hurts... but it'll get better.   849. I have been waxing my legs, bikini, arms, underarms, and face myself for almost 10 years now (I am a licensed aesthetician) and I was getting tired of how messy the waxing process is. I have very course hair on my legs and moderate hair on the rest of my body, and very sensitive skin. The Emjoi is a bit painful, more than waxing, but not too bad. It really does get most of the hair, and I haven't noticed more ingrown hairs than I would get from waxing. The only area it does not work well on is my face, but I use hard wax there anyway which is much less messy than soft wax, so I don't mind continuing to wax my face. It is very convenient (I can do pretty much my whole body in 30 min) and I like that it just plugs in as opposed to having a battery to charge, because I have heard that batteries run down pretty quick on epilators and I never have to wait for it to charge. I would highly recommend that people with course hair have 3 or 4 rounds of waxing (and no shaving) before starting with an epilator, as waxing is much less painful and the hair will start to grow back thinner making the initial epilation treatments much more tolerable. I did try an epilator many years ago before I had ever waxed, and it was too painful so I couldn't use it. So overall it does exactly what I hoped it would do, and does not irritate my skin like waxing and shaving does.
  850. I purchased the Emjoi Emagine a couple of years ago and was originally pleased with its performance. Recently, however, I noiced that it is not picking up short fine hairs and is now missing the long, coarser hairs as well. I use the Emjoi on my arms and legs about once a week (even less during cooler months) and am disappointed that this epilator--which cost more when I purchased it--has lost its functionality after about 100-200 uses. I won't buy this brand again.

  852. I am a seasoned epilator, and thought I'd share my experience for those who are debating which epilator to purchase.<br /><br />Please note that using an epilator WILL HURT the first few times, but after a while, you become so accustomed that you no longer feel pain, but rather a slight discomfort. As a frame of reference, I epilate my legs, arms and am pretty adventurous with the bikini line (I use it for a Brazilian - which is why I own 3 epilators, one is for my nether region only, and I clean it with alcohol after each use. I especially recommend you do this as well if you plan to do your bikini area and other body parts with the same epilator). For some reason I can't stand the sensation on my armpits - IT REALLY HURTS! I also don't feel the need to use it on my face, but I don't think it should be too uncomfortable. Also, epilating will not leave you as smooth as shaving, but it is pretty darn great because you will only have to do it once a month (after the first 4 weeks which you should do it once a week).<br /><br />NOW, HOW DOES THE EMJOY COMPARE TO [[ASIN:B004TGUKG0 Braun's SE 7181 WD Silk Epil 7 Epilator, Orange/Copper]] Series<br /><br />* ****** IF YOUR ARE NEW TO EPILATING -> I DO VERY MUCH LIKE the \\"massaging\\" attachemnt the Braun has (this emjoi does NOT have any attachments). When you are a first time epilator, the rolling beads give you a different sentation and therefore \\"distract\\" your skin so you don't seem to feel the yanking of your hairs quite as terribly. BUT REALLY, IF YOU ARE A FIRST TIMER, IT WILL HURT at least the 1st 5 times.<br /><br />* I have taken the Bruan Epil 7 Epilator into the shower (because it is completely water proof, which this emjoi is NOT), and it really feels the same as dry epilating. Maybe I felt less discomfort with the warm water, but honestly speaking, it takes 20 minutes to epilate my legs and, I am not taking a 20 minute shower! So, to me, it is not a critical feature. In addition, because of the lighting in the shower is not as \\"bright\\", (you know the dim over head light we all have so if you are there with your husband your wobbly bits are not so obvious), I miss quite a bit of the hair on my body. So again, for me, it is not the best place for epilating. I never tried it in the bath, but in the bath the last thing I want to do is epilate. A bath serves 2 purposes: Read and cleanse yourself or invite a significant other to join you. Neither which includes the epilator.<br /><br />* the Emjoy does not have the little light the Braun has, which can be useful in certain areas, but this is not critical.<br /><br />* I have always used both epilators at top speed and the Braun seems faster to me, but again not a big difference.<br /><br />* Here is where the emjoi wins: the 72 tweezers vs. the 40 (the Braun silk Epil 7 only has 40) does make it faster because I am yanking hair from a larger area.<br /><br />***** IMPORTANT ****** Lastly, my Braun's battery fried after 6 months of use. WHICH REALLY STINKS! That is why I would recommend getting an epilator that has an electrical cord. I also own a remington that can be used while plugged in, and this one is about 5 years old (and yes, it still works). The Braun (liked above) I had purchased can ONLY be used after it has been charged.<br /><br />My overall recommendation is that if you are not willing to purchase the top of the line Braun Silk Epil 7 which can be used while charging, then buy this emjoi because all the other one's will last you 6 months if you use it as heavily as I do. I gave this epilator 4 stars, because it doees not have the light, the massaging head and it is not fully water proof which the Braun is.<br /><br />I hope this helps steer you in the right direction.n the shower is not as \\"bright\\", (you know the dim over head light we all have so if you are there with your husband your wobbly bits are not so obvious), I miss quite a bit of the hair on my body. So again, for me, it is not the best place for epilating. I never tried it in the bath, but in the bath the last thing I want to do is epilate. A bath serves 2 purposes: Read and cleanse yourself or invite a significant other to join you. Neither which includes the epilator.<br /><br />* the Emjoy does not have the little light the Braun has, which can be useful in certain areas, but this is not critical.<br /><br />* I have always used both epilators at top speed and the Braun seems faster to me, but again not a big difference.<br /><br />* Here is where the emjoi wins: the 72 tweezers vs. the 40 (the Braun silk Epil 7 only has 40) does make it faster because I am yanking hair from a larger area.<br /><br />***** IMPORTANT ****** Lastly, my Braun's battery fried after 6 months of use. WHICH REALLY STINKS! That is why I would recommend getting an epilator that has an electrical cord. I also own a remington that can be used while plugged in, and this one is about 5 years old (and yes, it still works). The Braun (liked above) I had purchased can ONLY be used after it has been charged.<br /><br />My overall recommendation is that if you are not willing to purchase the top of the line Braun Silk Epil 7 which can be used while charging, then buy this emjoi because all the other one's will last you 6 months if you use it as heavily as I do. I gave this epilator 4 stars, because it doees not have the light, the massaging head and it is not fully water proof which the Braun is.<br /><br />I hope this helps steer you in the right direction.

  865. I am a 19 year old male and I found out about epilators through my cousin who recently purchased one. I hate shaving. I shave my chest because I do not like the feeling of being hairy but shaving causes me to itch and gives me a rash at times. After finding about epilators, I decided to give it a try so I ordered this one. I was expecting to be painful like waxing but not extremely painful to where I couldn't handle it since I know that if it were that painful then no sane person would use it. I received the product today and decided to give it a go. I plugged it in and proceeded to glide it down my chest. It stung so I pulled it back but then I continued without stopping and it just felt like being lightly pinched. It really wasn't painful at all and this was my first time using an epilator (note: I have never waxed or pulled hair out from the roots.) It might be because I have a high pain tolerance as people state, but I never really thought I did. I think part of it is due to determination which causes you to numb some of the pain. The product did everything I was expecting and my chest felt smooth.
  866. *This is my first epilator (and my first experience with epilating)*<br /><br />I gave myself a day between receiving it and using it...for mental preparation. It also gave me a chance to gather my necessary items to accompany my epilating adventure: witch hazel, cocoa butter with aloe, and a nice salt scrub (you can make this pretty easily).<br /><br />Here's what I did that I found worked pretty well:<br />-I took some Tylenol and hopped in the shower<br />-Scrubbed vigorously with the salt scrub, focusing on the victims (my legs)<br />-Finished shower, toweled off, and resisted the urge to moisturize<br />-I let myself dry off completely and took some extra time (about an hour) to get all my things together, set up my area, and made sure I had no dampness left<br />-Grabbed my blow dryer (just in case I got cold, and to reopen my pores without making the hair flexible)<br />-Took a deep breath and got to it!<br /><br />Yes, it stings. For some reason my right leg stung more than my left, no idea why. It took me a solid half hour on each leg, but I really wanted to be thorough. I worked an area until it no longer hurt, then I did a visual check and ran across it again. This thing is NOT a shaver. You CANNOT go quickly with this or else it will break hairs. You have to go slowly, I had to keep telling myself this constantly. Even if you go in circles make them slow circles so it gives the tweezers a chance. I did, by the way, find that circles helped get the hairs that happened to be growing in a different direction.<br /><br />When I finished I:<br />-Immediately applied my witch hazel using a cotton ball on the entire area I had epilated. I let that settle on one leg while I epilated the other<br />-After applying witch hazel to both legs and allowing it to dry, I applied my cocoa butter.<br /><br />My very pale legs were dotted in red for the rest of the evening, but not uncomfortable. I was surprised by how smooth they actually got. From many of thedescriptions I expected to feel maybe a day or two's worth of stubble, but it only felt like a few hours' worth. Not as close as shaving, but pretty darn close. It's a couple days after epilating and I'm still that smooth. I do plan on running it on my legs again (slowly, of course) just to keep up with the growth cycles.<br /><br />So...TL;DR:<br />This thing is a really nice machine and I love not having to charge it. Please GO SLOWLY and don't use it right after a shower. Try an hour or two later (it helps the hair not break). Exfoliate, epilate, get an alcohol free toner (witch hazel), and moisturize with cocoa or Shea butter!<br /><br />If you get ingrowns try Tend Skin or some medicated cream from Bikini Zone, they will help tremendously.

  897. After having this product for 6 months I feel like I can write a good review on it.<br /><br />First of all, I did a TON of research before finally committing to buy an epilator at all. It did and does not hurt at all, it merely feels like someone gently tugging at my skin. I use this epilator daily (only because I cannot STAND feeling anything but baby butt smooth under my arms and due to my very quick hair growth and hairs having different growth cycles, it is necessary for my sanity). When I first used it -before my hair had an opportunity to get on different growth schedules- I could go at least a week and a half before seeing any regrowth. I might start trying it on my legs in the future, but for now I'm very happy with a few passes under my arms after my morning shower and no longer feeling the scratches of razor stubble by the afternoon.<br /><br />I decided against getting a rechargeable one as the ones I looked at would not let you use them while plugged in and there were many reviews saying the battery started going bad and not holding a charge after a year or so. The cord honestly doesn't bother me since I just use it quickly in the bathroom. Some reviewers had said that the corded ones make it difficult to use the epilator while watching TV, but this cord is pretty long. Mine also came with a sweet little carrying bag (for travel) with a plastic divider inside in the center and a little brush to help clean the tweezer head.<br /><br />Overall - love it!
  898. I had this machine for just over one year before it stopped working - given that this is one of the more expensive epilators, I was expecting something a little more durable. After 12 months, the adaptor stopped consistently providing power to the unit and it would start and stop depending on the angle I was holding the unit. So I ordered a new adaptor for about $20. Then within about 3 months, the rotating blades would periodically seize up and jam, even though there was nothing caught in them and I would clean it after every use. The jams became more and more frequent until it was perpetually jammed and I couldn't even use it anymore.<br />I would recommend a cheaper and simpler model - my old Braun Epilady lasted over 8 years (and still works, just too slowly to be effective). Will be getting a single-head model next time.

  903. This item works well and so far we are quite satisfied with it. No complaints. Thank You.<br />Would reorder a similiar product.
  904. OK, so it's a little early for me to be posting this review, as I just ordered this yesterday on my Prime account. For one, they offered FREE one-day shipping so I literally received it in less than 24 hours. For two, this thing is an absolute GODSEND. A little background on me, I have very pale strawberry blonde fuzz ALL OVER my body. My butt, stomach, arms, low back, sideburns…It's just freaking everywhere. I've always been insecure about it, but usually it's not really an issue unless I'm laying out in my bikini. My mom swore by the old school epilators, but according to her they were incredibly painful. I never really looked into it until I started getting some tattoos. Over time I got more comfortable with the pain of tattooing, and I knew this thing couldn't hurt that bad. So I finally broke down and ordered it, after comparing several products and their corresponding reviews. That being said, I can't compare this to any of it's competitors or even to other Emjoi models. But I can compare it to my before furry body and my after, and I am VERY happy with the results. So far, I have done my butt cheeks, low back, stomach and the center of my chest, my sideburns, chin, and upper lip (the face being VERY fine blond hair, hardly discernible). I haven't done my arms or legs yet because I shave both, and have to let the hair grow out a little. The most painful spots were the very center of my stomach up to my chest bone and my low back. I made sure to pull the skin as taut as possible, like other reviewers and the instructions recommended, and that definitely helped. Also, on the more painful spots I would go over quickly a couple of times, so the pain was in short bursts rather than constant. Then, once I'd removed some of it and I was getting it totally smooth, the pain would subside as there was less and less hair to go over. The blond hairs on my upper lip are pretty short, so I couldn't get them all (plus I have a monroe piercing above one side and didn't feellike taking it out) so I'm thinking I might purchase the face model specifically for this purpose. I also think I read that the fine hairs are harder to get and I definitely had to go over spots more than once. But honestly - who freaking cares that it's not one swipe and done? This thing is a godsend. I give it my full endorsement. Oh, and a word of advice for the pain: When I'm getting tattoos I do yogic breathing and hum quietly and constantly to myself, like an OM for those of you who have been to yoga LOL. For some reason it makes the pain bearable for me. I didn't really find that I needed it for this, but you might try it if you've got a low pain tolerance. Happy hair removal!!!

  913. I've owned a number of Emjoi epilators over the years. All have had the tweezer head design, though my previous ones were gold plated (no idea why). However, I've found that the head is too big to use effectively anywhere but my legs and arms. So if you're looking for something for the underarm or bikini areas, this is not it. Also, my previous models were able to remove very short hair. That does not seem to be the case with this one. Overall I'm disappointed. I will say that this is the least painful epilator I've ever used though!

  915. I've used hair removal creams for years but recently they have begun to irritate my skin (even when following the box instructions). So I decided to give this a try and I'm so glad I did. At first, it was a little intimidating because I remember the pain when I first started tweezing my eyebrows. The first time I used the epilator I only took off a few hairs then put it away while trying to get up my nerve. A few days later I got up my nerve, after looking on youtube to find out how to use it properly, and decided to try it again. This time I felt no pain and it worked really well. I had no trouble with skin irritation either. My advice would be to use the epilator as soon as you get out of the shower or bath which seems to eliminate the pain since your pores are still open. This process also worked well when I was using the creams which helped the hair to remove easier. Also, be sure to keep your skin taut and don't push it down hard on your skin. Just glide it across lightly in different directions for the best results. I can't wait to throw away my cream hair removers.

The Emagine is able to remove hair much faster, more efficiently, and somehow with less pain. Yes lady's, I'm sorry to say, but even after removing hair for six years there's still a little discomfort. Furthermore, the rotating tweezers of many other epilators will grab, pinch, or really irritate the skin if you don't ensure that its pulled tight. (underarm for example) I've never had this problem with the Emagine.<br /> Finally, this epilator is much easier to clean. This is easy to use, fast, affordable, clean, and effective. The antimicrobial feature is helpful for preventing irritation and ingrown hairs. It is moderately noisy. The cord is not an issue. I did a LOT of research on epilators before I decided on the Emjoi Emagine. The Emjoi Emagine is one of the larger models; it has 72 tweezer heads that rotate to pick up and pluck out hair from the root. I purchased it from Amazon.com for close to $70.00. While I find that expensive, I figured that once I bought several packs of replacement razors or a few trips to the salon for waxing, this thing pretty much paid for itself and would inevitably save me money. I read so many good reviews and did research on how to prepare your skin for epilation (by exfoliating!). I thought this was going to be the end all be all to my hair removal needs. I was super psyched when I received it and waited until after I showered and exfoliated to try it out. I was apprehensive about the pain because in general, many people said it was quite painful. Having had two tattoos and recently given birth, I figured it would be a walk in the park. I was surprised at how it really was painful. Nowhere near childbirth on my pain scale, but it made my eyes water and it wasn't something I ever really got used to. I used the epilator on my legs, underarms and bikini line. Holy Toledo, my first run at my underarms was AWFUL. It hurt so bad, and the ache/sting didn't go away when I was done. It was a good 24-48 hours before my pits felt back to normal. But they were smooth! To my amazement, my bikini line was the least painful area I epilated. While I didn't expect to have 100% hair removal (I was prepared after reading reviews), I was fairly satisfied with the results. Plus I figured it would get better the more I did it. I did a touch-ups every couple of days and had little to no regrowth for about a week. I have been exfoliating nearly every day during my shower to prevent ingrown hairs. However, within the last few days the hair on my legs has started to come back with a vengeance. My legs LOOK and FEEL terrible. They are itchy, red, bumpy, and irritated. I can see little black dots where the hair is trying to grow back. Between the redness, bumps, and black, my legs look even worse than they did when I was shaving. I am now concerned that it will take my legs a LONG time to get back to 'normal' if they do at all. I am extremely disappointed with the results from the Emjoi Emagine Epilator. When I did research prior to purchasing this, I did see a handful of reviewers who noted a similar [bad] experience like mine, but I figured I wouldn't end up being one of those, but naturally I did. I have followed the instructions to a T and even taken great care in exfoliating and keeping my legs moisturized. I can't say I did anything wrong, it just did not work for me. Unfortunately I will be returning this item and going back to shaving with my razor. While I won't get smooth legs for a week at a time, at least I won't have unsightly and painful legs for days on end.ays and had little to no regrowth for about a week. I have been exfoliating nearly every day during my shower to prevent ingrown hairs. However, within the last few days the hair on my legs has started to come back with a vengeance. My legs LOOK and FEEL terrible. They are itchy, red, bumpy, and irritated. I can see little black dots where the hair is trying to grow back. Between the redness, bumps, and black, my legs look even worse than they did when I was shaving. I am now concerned that it will take my legs a LONG time to get back to 'normal' if they do at all. I am extremely disappointed with the results from the Emjoi Emagine Epilator. When I did research prior to purchasing this, I did see a handful of reviewers who noted a similar [bad] experience like mine, but I figured I wouldn't end up being one of those, but naturally I did. I have followed the instructions to a T and even taken great care in exfoliating and keeping my legs moisturized. I can't say I did anything wrong, it just did not work for me. Unfortunately I will be returning this item and going back to shaving with my razor. While I won't get smooth legs for a week at a time, at least I won't have unsightly and painful legs for days on end.
  966. I love this product. I have had three in the past and I like this one better than the others. You have to angle it a bit different because of the two rotating springs. But it definitely does a great job. I only have to shave my legs once every two weeks. That is a blessing because I am so busy most of the time and I don't have time to shave every two to three days. And when your leg hair grows back, you can barely see it. The first time I used an epilator it did hurt. But after you get through the initial time, it will be different. And each time you shave, you will see less hair that needs to be removed. Definitely worth the price!! I am saving a fortune on shavers.

  976. This is my first epilator so I cannot say that there were any products better than this, but I can believe there are some better ones out there. I got this and used it right away, but the pain made it to the point where it took about 3 days to get all the hair out of my legs. It went good until suddenly these red bumps started appearing. I used lotion, and creams to calm it down, but it was no use. It didn't go away for about a week! It'd break the hairs to the point that it couldn't pick it up anymore.<br /><br />Maybe sticking to a good traditional/messy wax would be better than this.
  977. I'm a male that just hates body hair. I've shaved legs, underarms and chest for years. But thought I'd try an epilator. After reviewing several makes and models, this came out on top. As someone else said, they make a men's model but there really is no difference other then some trim pieces that effect looks and the color. The men's cost more probably due to a limited market. I have a low threshold when it comes to pain. But I was surprised that this was no more than a 2 on a scale of 1-10 pain tolerance. I was able to do my legs in little more time than it takes to shave them. I was really afraid to try the chest hairs but again surprised that I can tolerate it and the pain is no more then maybe a 3. So if I can stand the pain or slight discomfort, so can you. If the discomfort level gets lower as I use this if would be about the same as shaving! I am very happy with the results and the product. Buy this one!
  978. this i s my 2nd epilator and i have got to say that this is the least painful and most powerful epilator on the market. the cord one does not get on my nerves and it stays super powerful, so i will never go back to a rechargeable or battery EVER again. I cam finally tolerate using this all over my body in one setting without wimping out due to pain or time. I do feel that the only negative is that it doesn't work the best on its high settings, i feel it skips over or breaks the hair so i just use the lower setting which is still very powerful. also its bulky and makes it hard to use in certain areas but I've managed to do my own Brazilian w/out much trouble. I would definitely recommend it and buy it again! don't give up on using it it takes time to figure how to hold your skin just right and the direction of the epilator, sometimes i have to go in ever direction. its super easy to clean as well which i love!<br /><br />****adding on beware of ingrown hairs!!!! if you are like me and have thick, kinda wavy hair that grows with like 2-4 hairs for every follicle i would NOT use this. I had to go to my dermatolgist due to ingrown hairs that got severely infected. she said she doesn't want me waxing or shaving bc it has misshaped my hair follicles so the hairs are always going to be ingrown.   994. I have been depilating for over 15 years. I have used many different appliances. This product is POWERFUL. I feel I have met my match! It may be wise to keep searching if you are a first time user or if noise is a problem for you. It has a rather loud motor but it is thorough. Models that are cordless tend to lose their strength so this was a good choice for me. The heads rotate away from each other and get every hair regardless of direction of growth.It is very comfortable to hold and is fast . This is what makes it so good. A beginner can get used to it by using the slower speed and depilating small sections at a time. I could wish for a bright light on the device so that I may see the hairs better. My particular device caused mild scratches on my skin. This was due to a small burr on the rotating disc. I used a nail file to smooth it down and now it is fine. I would highly recommend this product and I would buy it again.

It is just so much faster and easier than any other methods of hair removal. It did not hurt quite as much as I expected it to hurt. Especially in the underarm area. It hurt a little bit the first time. But the pains decreases with every use. Now I hardly feel it. I dont think you can expect any less pain if you are planning to pull out your hairs by its roots.

I noticed if i used it just after i take a shower when my pores are open works better and don't pull too much.   997. I have used several kinds of epilators, home wax kits, gotten professionally waxed etc for over 20 years. I had used the Braun for several years and loved it, but like many other users, was frustrated with how long it took to epilate my legs. I have exceptionally hairy legs with very dark course hair and it would take a total of 4 hours to clear my legs of hair with the Braun, if they were super hairy. Like others have mentioned, the braun clears every single hair, whereas the emjoi, clears ALMOST every hair. (I think it might be because the emojoi breaks a few hairs off instead of pulling them.) If you want that perfectly shaved feel, you would have to spend hours with the braun. For me, I can use the emjoi in about 1/4 the time, and the time savings is definitely worth the few tiny hairs that remain. I will also mention here that because your hair grows at different rates, the first time you clear your legs, whether it be with waxing or epilating, because all of the hairs have grown out, your legs will be much more smooth, and remain smooth for a longer period than subsequent epilations. Therefore, just like with shaving, you have to deal with needing to re-epilate in a few days if you want that perfect smooth surface. Personally, I can live with not being 100% hair free, so I epilate about once a week. That is the best system for me. If I let it go two weeks or more, then epilating becomes much more uncomfortable as you are pulling out so many hairs. Plus it takes so much longer. If you really want smooth legs, and you could afford it, I would suggest buying botht he emjoi and the braun. I would clear the majority of hairs with the fast emjoi and then go over it again with the braun. I haven't done this personally, as I mentioned, I will tolerate less than smooth legs. I do have a few additional suggestions for those of you who haven't used an epilator before. I had waxed for years, using both professional waxers and a home waxing kit. But because of a terrible experience with the old &#34;epilady&#34; of the 1990's I was literally terrified to try to epilate. I finally broke down and bought a braun after my south american neighbor told me how much better it was than the epilady. But I was still scared, and it sat in my closet for months after purchasing it. Finally, I did it, and it really was nothing as bad as the old epilady, but that could have been due to the fact that I had been waxing all those years. If you have never epilated before, I STRONGLY suggest getting just breaking down and paying a one time cost of getting waxed by a professional just once before you start to epilate. If you do that, then just a few hairs will grow back at first, and you can epilate them out without the torture of tearing ALL of them out at once. I have done it both ways many times. Especially when I had the braun, I as a working mom, I just wouldn't have 4 hours to devote to it, so my leg hairs would grow and grow and grow. Even for me, after all those years of waxing, epilating ALL the hairs at once is really terrible. So my biggest advice is keep up with it and you will love it. For me, this is much easier to do with the faster emjoi. No matter which brand you buy, if you do it at least once a week, it will go fairly easily. I epilate everything with the emjoi, legs, arms, tummy, mustache, underarms, and a pretty close (but not crazy) bikini line. And it takes me a total of only about 30-40 minutes with the emjoi if I do it once a week. It would take longer if let the hair grow. I can't imagine how long the braun would take to do all of that. It took 4 hours just to do the legs, but again, I often had let it go so long that my legs were really hairy. I LOVED the emjoi at first. It was SOOOOO much faster than the braun. But the problem is, that it stops working after a while. This is in fact the second emjoi I have bought. And I will probably buy another one somewhat begrudgingly. I loved the braun too, but it just took too long. I will also mention that I am prone to ingrown hairs. One thing that has really helped me is to use a loofah both before and after epilating. I also try and do a quick loofah every time I am in the shower. Your legs will never be as smooth as shaving with epilating. (But they will actually be smother than waxing which may surprise you. The epilators get many more of the tiny hairs than waxing does and fewer of them break.) I could never go back to shaving at this point. My hairs are so course that they are almost sharp when shaved. But with either epilating or waxing, the hair is obviously pulled out completely, so when they do grow back, the end is a fine tip that isn't nearly as irritating. In the end, I do recommend both the emjoi and the braun, as well as the Clean and Easy home waxing kit. Which is the one I used for years and was mostly happy with. If you are going to home wax, it is by far the best. For me, the time savings of the emjoi justifies me having to purchase a new one every year or so.
  998. results are great, chin hairs are disappearing, upper lip....hurts, but eventually I get them off. Someone needs to invent a way to get rid of body hair permanently--this is no fun...but certainly is tolerable in some places.

  1010. Let me start by saying that I have used an epilator for more than 10 years. I have a Braun that is beginning to age and slow down so I ordered this one. I am considering returning it for rather than having to use two to complete the job. It is very comfortable. It makes removing hair from new areas nearly pain free.
  1011. Having used an epilator for many years, this is my 3rd or 4th one. I can say it is the best I've ever owned. I can be finished in half the time it has taken me in the past.   1013. I have very thick, dark hair. I used to shave. It got to where I could not shave every day due to razor bumps and ingrown hairs. But I could not bare my legs because of the dark rough stubble. I then turned to waxing and was very satisfied with that. But waxing your legs in the summer is not ideal because of the few weeks you have to let your hair grow out. For every 2 weeks of smooth legs, I had three weeks of wearing nothing but pants or long skirts.<br />Then my niece asked me if I ever epilated. I heard of epilation, but did not know of anyone that did it. And did not think much of it. When my niece told me about her friend's experiences and I did some online research, I was sold on the idea. After careful consideration I opted to purchase the Emjoi AP-18. The first time I did my legs was probably the longest, maybe 30 minutes? But I was in the process of growing hair out for waxing and there was a lot of it. That was 4 weeks ago. It was not painful for me, but I have waxed and have a high pain tolerance. I was hooked immediately after and continued to do my under arms, bikini and happy trail. I love that it pulls the hair from the root, no more stubble!! I love that it takes time to grow back like waxing, but I can just do touch ups once or twice a week and I never have to have legs full of hair. I am prone to ingrowns, but I am exfoliating and using lactic acid lotion and Tend skin solution to keep it to a minimum. I am so happy that I purchased this epilator. I have not worn pants or long skirts since!! It has changed my life! I will be purchasing the smaller Emjoi to get to my bikini, underarms and facial hair a little better. The larger head on this model is ideal for legs and can do other smaller areas, but with some difficulty. I would recommend any women to start epilating!

  1015. its hurts like hell when using on your body
  1016. Disappointed that there is not a light nor internal battery
  1017. I heard good things about this, but the truth is that it hurts. Now I don't mind a little pain, but this was a little ridiculous.   1022. Though epilators will never replace razors in terms of removing every hair right down to the skin, this one is the best I've ever tried - better than a spa wax! Twice as fast as the Braun Silk-Epil I also have, plus twice as efficient in hair removal and half as noisy. It's a bit pricey, but worth it for the smooth factor!
  1023. I bought this for summer so I could wear shorts and not have to shave my legs so often. I found it works well and is not painful which I was concerned about. It leaves my legs very smooth. I would recommend.

I don't have the patience.<br />It's also incredibly painful and I consider myself to have a high pain tolerance. I rarely need to use it on my under arms any longer, as so little hair grows there now.
