If you don't it does get jammed, but that is user error, not a manufacturing problem.
  1033. I waited to write this review after I had used this product a few times. My review compares this product to the original Epilady coil epilator (made in Israel) and to the Braun Silk-Epil model 5318.<br /><br />First some general comments:<br />1. Pain - all epilation is painful. As a woman from the Indian subcontinent, I have lots of coarse hair and hair removal is something I've lived with for most of my life. I first started sugar-waxing at home in the 1970's - very messy process. But because I've been yanking hair out from its roots for a long time, it doesn't hurt much anymore, especially on my legs. That said, underarms are quite painful the first time you do them. So once you start, don't stop! Because if you let the hair grow out, it will hurt like the dickens again. Also, I can't do my bikini area at all. Too much pain! I use pre-waxed strips instead. Some people mention epilating after a shower. I guess this helps. I always epilate after I shower so that my skin is free of all lotion and deodorant, so I can't really compare.<br />2. Ingrown Hair - yes this is an issue. For some reason it's a bigger problem for me with waxing and epilating than shaving. My solution is to use a loofah in the shower, very frequently. Dry brushing your skin with a mitt also helps. Those puffy plastic mesh things don't work at all, too smooth. Most of my ingrown hair occurs where my legs rub together since I usually sit with my legs crossed.<br />3. Time and repetition - epilation takes more time than shaving and you do need to go over the area more than once to remove all the hair. But I can wait a week or two between treatments vs shaving which I'd have to do pretty much every day so it's worth it. In terms of frequency, I use the epilators on my underarms and calves once a week and on my thighs and forearms once every two weeks.<br />4. Corded vs. Cordless - I had both corded and rechargeable coil Epiladies (original and &#34;Ultra&#34;). I found that once the battery on the rechargeable unit wore out, it seemed to slow down even when it was plugged in. So now I only use corded units.<br /><br />Original coil Epilady - I started using these about 20 years ago. I found them very forgiving in terms of how they had to be held against the skin, and how fast or slow you had to move them around on your skin. You could move it in straight lines or circles. They worked very well and they seemed to remove more hair in one pass than the newer designs. But I actually thought they worked better on longer hair than shorter hair. And their head shape meant that I never could do my underarms. But they lasted a long time - about 15 years! Obviously they were pretty well built.<br /><br />Braun Silk-Epil 5318 - After my Epilady bit the dust, I moved to this product. This older model's tweezers have two metal teeth vs one plastic and one metal. I have seen other reviews that mention that two metal teeth are better than one being plastic. That said, this product works very well for me. You need to follow its directions, though. Move slowly in long swoops and hold the device at a 90 degree angle against your skin. I use the slower speed on the device because I thought the faster speed was causing more hair breakage. Also, I work against the growth pattern of the hair. This device is the best for getting into nooks and crannies and works well in the underarm area, because its head is fairly small and its a bit curved. It works best with hair around 1/4 to 1/2 inch long, and seems to get even the finest hair out.<br /><br />When I was using the old Epilady I had to shave my underarms. But I decided to try epilating them with the Braun and it is fantastic. To give you an idea, I have already had laser hair removal on my underarms which thinned the hair out a bit but didn't get rid of all of it. Now I use the epilator and although I'll never be an underarm model, I am hair free in this area and loving it.<br /><br />Emjoi Emagine - We built a winter home inthe south so I needed a second epilator and I picked this one based on the reviews.<br /><br />First the good: it is fast! The large number of tweezers makes it about 30% faster than the Braun. Also, the dual opposed head means you can go in various directions and it still works great. It's tweezers also have two metal teeth, by the way. You still have to follow the directions. Hold the device at a 90 degree angle (upright) against your skin. Move in small swipes. I use the slower speed. The device works well on shorter hair, just like the Braun.<br /><br />Now the bad - why I give it four stars instead of five. It is loud! Louder than the Braun. This isn't a big deal at my house but I don't think I could take it with me if I was visiting a friend. They'd wonder what the heck was going on. But the more important issue is that it's head is quite large, and flat. So it is harder to use in the underarm and behind-the-knee areas. Also hard to use around the knees (mine are pretty boney and angular). This isn't a deal breaker for me but I suppose it might be for some people<br /><br />If my Braun dies I'll probably buy a new one to see if they work as well as my old model. However, I don't think you can go wrong with the Emjoi, so I can recommend it.the south so I needed a second epilator and I picked this one based on the reviews.<br /><br />First the good: it is fast! The large number of tweezers makes it about 30% faster than the Braun. Also, the dual opposed head means you can go in various directions and it still works great. It's tweezers also have two metal teeth, by the way. You still have to follow the directions. Hold the device at a 90 degree angle (upright) against your skin. Move in small swipes. I use the slower speed. The device works well on shorter hair, just like the Braun.<br /><br />Now the bad - why I give it four stars instead of five. It is loud! Louder than the Braun. This isn't a big deal at my house but I don't think I could take it with me if I was visiting a friend. They'd wonder what the heck was going on. But the more important issue is that it's head is quite large, and flat. So it is harder to use in the underarm and behind-the-knee areas. Also hard to use around the knees (mine are pretty boney and angular). This isn't a deal breaker for me but I suppose it might be for some people<br /><br />If my Braun dies I'll probably buy a new one to see if they work as well as my old model. However, I don't think you can go wrong with the Emjoi, so I can recommend it.

  1048. This is the BEST epilator for those who have thick, coarse hair that needs to be removed quickly and painlessly! In the past, I have purchased two of these and can say that no other epilator is as reliable or removes as many hairs as efficiently as the Emjoi AP-18. Recently I purchased a cheap epilator at the drug store (in desperation, I must add, as it was the only one available!) and there is no comparison. I'm going to order another one of these babies pronto!<br /><br />UPDATE: At this point, I have owned four of these. A new problem: the gears that allow the tweezers to rotate are made of cheap plastic and will wear out in short time, leaving you with a product that doesn't work. I don't recall this happening with the first two I owned, but the last two developed the same problem. The points of the little plastic gears wear down, so they no longer make the needed connection in the related area. You can hear the motor running, but nothing happens because the tweezers no longer rotate...hence, you are left with a useless device. It is great when it is new and working, but the plastic gear will wear out quickly. Why is almost everything (including moving mechanical parts!) made from cheap plastic today? I don't know what else to buy in place of this epilator!
  1049. Okay, so as a college aged male I am stuck in a generation where no one likes hair, even on guys. What people hate more than hair is stubble. So I bought this thing thinking it would be a good compromise. I'm not a super hairy dude, I'm just trying to take preventive action. Anyway, I really like this thing. It easily grabbed and removed hair in areas that are often times touched, grabbed, etc. I think all of the reviews saying this just broke the hairs off were primarily from females with thinner hair. This may be best for people with pretty coarse hair. It definitely took some getting used to, and I had to make sure to have a razor bump gel handy for immediately afterwards, but that's expected with something that is ripping hair out from the roots.<br />I'm going with 4 out of 5 because I feel like it does take a pass or two to make it work.<br /><br />Anyway, if you're a guy and your significant other doesn't care for hair in various places, this will probably work for you. Just make sure to go to walmart and buy some bump patrol or something at the self checkout and you'll be grand.<br /><br />Edit: Also, you may want to think about your pain tolerance when making this purchase. Guys' hair is seriously rooted. Sometimes to the extent that there are tiny tiny droplets of blood from where the hair got ripped out... I have been told that as you keep doing it, the roots get less deep, but that first time is rough.
  1050. After regular blade shaving, I end up with ingrown hairs and someone suggested I try this type of hair remover. Because the hairs grow in at different rates, it hurts less and less. This was the firt time in my life that I got the smooth legs you see on women in shaving commercials. Follow the directions because you don't use it like a regular shaver with long strokes, but short strokes. Go in the direction of hair growth for less pain.

  1056. I bought this epilator because, after reading many reviews on the different products out there, it seemed to be the best.<br /><br />While it works well for the lower half of my shin and calf area, above this it does not perform as it should. Maybe it is because the hairs further up my shin and thigh are quite fine, so they tend to break before they can be tweezed out by the spinning discs. I'm not sure. Also, the shape of the head does not lend itself to corners, such as the bikini line has. It works until the crease where your underpants would sit and then you'll need to tweeze manually the last little bit. But maybe it has worked for other people?<br /><br />I've been too scared to try it on my armpits, after my mum told me how painful it was for her... :P<br /><br />The machine itself is easy to hold. I don't have any problems gripping it, but then I always have dry hands when I use it. The switch could be improved but I assume it is purposefully hard to switch on, to reduce the risk of accidental tweezing. It does make an absolute racket when it's used; my dogs wont come in the bathroom when it's on. It's fairly easy to clean - just blow/brush the hairs out from the tweezing heads.<br /><br />All in all, if your leg hair is thicker than mine, this would probably be a good purchase for you. I still don't regret this purchase, because even though I have to do a little extra tweezing, I am no longer getting the itchy stubble I did when I shaved. Also, I haven't experienced any ingrown hairs. And after using it for a month I've already saved what I would have paid to get a full leg and bikini wax.

The other disadvantage of design of this product is that it is not possible to open the case easily to fix it.   1068. First time epilator! NO PAIN. After bathing and using a loofah with baking soda to exfoliate, I epilate. (Every other day I use a loofah to prevent ingrown hairs but have not had any.) The only sensation I experienced on my lower legs was an occasional slight scraping sensation- like when u scratch your skin too hard with your nails. Small slow circular motions most effective. Was able to see hundreds of long hair follicles on white towel that I had under my legs fall out. It did irritate and scratch some areas as I think I pressed too hard, however, the areas had no discomfort at all. Yes, you do need to go over some areas several times to get all hairs. Even with that a few stubborn ones still remain- no big deal. The hair grows back so slowly and much less of it- it is amazing. It is not perfect. Legs look smooth but do not feel as smooth as a fresh shave. Hair grows much faster on legs from the knee down. Knee area is tricky.<br />I found under arm hair removal more difficult. I sprayed under my arms with Bactine for pain prevention and it also helped with irritation. It did not work great for under my arms. No discomfort (I was pleasantly surprised) just irritated which the Emjoi PX EJ Epilation cream helped with. Not sure if cream slows hair growth as after all Mother Nature is in control. It is difficult to do as it is hard to stretch the skin but can easily be achieved. I was able to see where the hair was actually tweezed out. I would suggest for the first time not to go over the area too much and get it better on the next epilation time. Do not go for perfection the first time as I did and scrapes and irritations will be avoided. Even with that I was able to wear deodorant next day with no problem. But I do have scrapes under my arms and only removed about 75% of the hair. Need more practice I guess. (This is an edit to my original review for under arm hair removal- about 1 1/2 months later. I finally gave up on using it under my armsand went back to shaving every other day. Then I had a crazy idea to try it again. well, after the epilator removed about 50% of my underarm hair without irritation to skin, I then shaved the rest off. This worked ok. Then I became ambitious and tried to epilate again as there was not much hair there. I developed serious uncomfortable skin irritations which lasted 7 days. I am bright red under my arms. As it heals it will probably turn brown- then disappear over time. Not worth it as I can hardly raise my arms. Does any on know of a special way to epilate under the arms? Once I heal, I may go back to epilating occasionally, then still shaving every other day. Poor me.)<br />(I also tried it on my arms on low speed and came out great without redness or irritation. Hair grows back slowly so arms look great- did not realize they were so hairy.)<br />As for the noise, any hair dryer is much much louder than this and I am able to listen to a talk show on the radio while I epilate. Takes less than 1 hour to do legs and underarms. I did my thighs 2 weeks ago and not 1 hair has grown back.<br />On lower legs and under arms I epilated 3 days after first time due to the difference in hair growth and that lasted 6 days. Supposedly it will last longer with each use. I do not see it lasting 5-6 weeks as stated in some reviews. I use the Emjoi PX EJ Epilation cream immediately after which does help with irritation caused by epilating and use it every other day for a few times, then just use a regular moisturizer. Under my arms I use every day for a few days. Others may not need to.<br />I like the idea of an electrical cord as opposed to batteries because as you know batteries loose their strength over time. You definitely want this machine working at full capacity at all times. I recommend this epilator due to the lack of pain and 72 tweezers making for a rapid and easy hair removal experience.
  1069. I have had my Epilator for over 2 years now and i love it. I use it on my underarms and my legs. The first 3 to 4 times of use it did irritate my skin for the first hour but was worth it. During each use it has made my skin softer with no more ingrown hair. My underarms have become much lighter in color than before because of razers. Hair grows back 3 to 4 weeks later and much much thinner. Over all great investment. You will not regret it at all. Downfall if you dont like pain or cant take pain at all this is probably not for you. It does look it lot more intimating that is actually is.
  1070. I think I really did a big favor to myself! This product is really fast, which I love about it. I really recommend it.
  1071. Smooth transaction great product
  1072. This product works every bit as well as waxing does on the legs and underarms, but for much cheaper. Normally, I would have to shave every day, but with this product, I used it once and now, three weeks later, I finally have a few hairs poking through enough for me to touch up my legs again. At seven months pregnant, this product is a life saver!
  1073. I think I have about average hair growth and density, so I cannot promise that everyone will have my same amazing results, but I cannot say enough nice things about this device. The very first time I did both legs was uncomfortable, and because I wasn't sure how my skin would react, I did a separate sitting for each leg. I have never epilated before, so I cannot compare the experience to using a different brand of this same product, but I will say that that to me it felt very similar to when I get a tattoo. Not fun, but certainly not agonizing. Afterward, both my legs broke out in red bumps all over; it looked like some horrible disease. But I needn't have worried, because the inflammation subsided within a few hours, leaving me with baby soft legs. I have only been using it about once a week since then, to touch up stragglers. No ingrown hairs either. It is loud enough that I do have to turn up the volume if I'm watching TV while I epilate, but not nearly as loud as say, a blow dryer. In short, it's worth every penny!
  1074. I'm disappointed in how this doesn't work. You would think that with 72 tweeters I wouldn't have to go over it a million tims.

  1151. Review contains suggestions for pre- and after-care, areas tested, pain levels experienced, results of epilating, and level of satisfaction.<br /><br />=======<br /><br />I am thrilled with this product! Please note that this product is NOT as thorough as waxing; it cannot get all of those frustrating little hairs that your professional will go back and touch up or tweeze - you know... that extra service that you're actually paying for when you see a professional. For the price I paid (less than $70 with taxes and shipping), this machine in one use has almost paid for itself compared to my regular waxing appointments. Caveat - I've been seeing my estitician for 7 years now for regular waxing of my upper thighs, full face, and full brazilian - the real deal one. This is NOWHERE near as painful as repeated waxing (which I did get used to over several sessions); epilating with this machine is more like having someone lightly scratch me with their nails.<br /><br />If my estitician gives A+ service, this epilator gives a low A to high A-. My body hair is so light in color it glows when it catches the sunlight; so my hair is fine but dense and grows very, very long (thus seeing a professional for so many years!). I got all of my upper thigh leg hair in less than 30 minutes - without a silly little light to eluminate things for me, thank you very much. I stood in my bathroom (the cord is long!) and leaned on the counter, sat on the edge of the counter, or proped a leg up on the counter to get to all the spots. Taking 30 minutes is actually probably a high estimate. Also, the unit is really not that loud. It's no louder than any other electric shaver on the market.<br /><br />Prep work - exfoliated the night before with an over-the-counter sugar scrub. The night of, I showered and thoroughly dried before epilating; I did not use any talc or drying powders. I did pull the skin taut when needed.<br /><br />Areas epilated & pain level (0 to 10, 10 hurting like holy heck)-<br/><br />* Ankle (those long hairs that I always miss with the razor and would shred myself if I tried to get) - took seconds to do and was so fast there was no pain (0). I can't wait to try it on my toes; yes, us blondes do get light colored hair on our feet. (Doctor's say it's a sign of a healthy heart. I'm sticking to that!)<br /><br />* Knee - too bony. Did not hurt (1); just impractical. A safety razor is just as efficient. I'm thinking shins are going to be the same on me; so I'll continue using my safety razor for the knee and below. Pfsh, after this many years of shaving (20+) I'm pretty handy with my safety razor and sometimes that just can't be beat with a machine.<br /><br />* Back of knee - Fast! The machine contured to the curve in the back of the knee. I'd put it at a 1 to 2 for pain.<br /><br />* Thighs - I did have to go over a few spots more than once, but in all fairness I've not been waxed since right before the New Year (2012) so maybe it was breaking a few of those long hairs before it could get down to tweeze them. This machine left me just as smooth as if I'd been waxed by my professional!!! For pain, I'd say maybe a 3 on the high side. Up near the \\"bum\\" on the backs of my thighs (where the \\"seat\\" and thigh meet) was a little sensitive; that's probably a solid 3 for pain.<br /><br />* Bikini - Honestly, this machine is too big for such a narrow/tight area where the leg meets the trunk of the body. I would put this upwards of a 4 on the pain level for as little as I got done; the machine really was too big to get any closer than the outer edges of the bikini area. I think I would like to invest in a smaller epilator for these tighter areas of the body. This machine would have done too much damage to the skin trying to pull the hairs out even for a yoga contortionist who could get in there to epilate.<br /><br />* Chin / under chin - YES!!! It worked and it worked well! Pain was practically non-existent(1), less than waxing that's for sure! And oh, to have that smooth feel and look again! So worth it for the self-esteem level increase alone!!!<br /><br />* Cheeks - Again, this machine is a little big for getting up in to these sensitive areas. It worked on the cheeks, but I'd put the pain more along the lines of a 3. And you've got to be careful! You could easily catch or tear your skin with high number of rotating tweezers. But it did work; I just went really, really slowly over my skin and worked small areas at a time checking the work as I went.<br /><br />* Upper lip - I'd put the pain upwards of a 7 - maybe 8. This hurt; I won't lie to you and I did try several times to work up to getting my upper lip epilated. The bone contact was unpleasant, it was too small of an area for that big of a machine, and I was concerned about getting my skin caught. I think I'm going to look for a smaller unit for the face and bikini areas.<br /><br />Aftercare - You will see a lot of red dots; hey, you'd see them right after getting waxed too. You just ripped hair out of your body for pity sake; don't kid yourself here so don't do anything stupid with your skin or think you can run right out in that sexy little skirt. Your estitician would say the same thing after waxing! However, I did NOT see any blood from any pores. For my face, I just used my usual facial moisturizer after epilating. Nothing more was needed; no ice the way I would after waxing. I used Aloe Vera Gel afterward to smooth over my thighs; the cooling helped as the skin is a little tingly (again, it would be after waxing too). By morning, there were NO little red dots on my legs. My skin looked absolutely normal - just fur free!!!!!!!<br /><br />Bottom line, for those of you who are expecting miracles - move along. You'll never be satisfied because you're expecting professional quality results (which you would pay a lot to get) from an at-home-use / personal use hand-held machine. Get real, people!<br /><br />For those of you expecting \\"good\\" results froma small, one-time expense as opposed to the regular expense of waxing to get \\"great\\" results - this product is a dream come true! I'm beyond pleased with my purchase and hope to get many, many years of good service from it. My best friend recommended this unit to me, we did the necessary research, and I think I got a killer deal buying exactly what I was looking for in a epilator product!
  1152. I've had this epilator for a couple of months now. Purchased it during a desperate attempt to rid of my dark, course arm pit hair. Naturally hairy female but I figured it'd be one less body part to worry about. That and it's far too painful to use anywhere else!<br /><br />That being said, it's ok. I've grown to appreciate it. The hair does take longer to grow back as opposed to shaving. If your hair is thick however (I'm talking terminal hair) it'll take a couple of attempts to pluck most of the hair out. My armpit hair grows in different directions so it's a bit of a task getting most of the hair out, let alone the fact it's thicker.<br /><br />It IS painful the first few attempts, but your body gets use to it after awhile. As far as armpit discoloration goes, I feel it has helped lighten the area although not significantly. Expected it to be more efficient in retrieving hairs; I've never been able to get all of my hair and do have to use a razor afterwards for any remaining stray hair if I want to achieve that smooth, hairless look.
  1153. I have purchased 4 of these (3 red 1 black). I like them when they work but they do not last. I have tried everything to try to make them last longer but they keep making them cheaper with soft plastic gears. The first one lasted a year, the last one lasted 3 months. I'm moving on.   1157. I got this to upgrade my Panasonic epilator thinking it would grab more hairs and be an all around quicker experience-I was wrong. First the thing is so LOUD. Much louder than my Panasonic. I can barely stand using it. It seems to miss much more hair than my old one as well, making me go over legs over and over. Sometimes I even follow up with my old epilator to make sure my legs are smooth. I do use the circle method someone else mentioned in a review and that does work much better than any other method. Because of these two things I wouldn't say this epilator is worth the price if you don't need it.<br />HOWEVER, it is much nicer to my sensitive skin. With my previous epilator I was not able to stand the pain to do my bikini line or arm pits, with this I can easily do both pain free. I've found this to be the only thing that outweighs my old epilator. Perhaps this means it would be ideal for first time epilators.<br /><br />Bottom line: Does not impress me with ability to grab more hair, but does work better on sensitive skin.
  1158. I recently had to replace my Emjoi Optima (which I loved and ran many years before its motor finally wore out).
